Hulkster makes some entertainingly bad rock rap pop fusion songs that scream AMERICAAAAAA
What an absolutely beautiful voice this man has. Other than 'I Should Have Been True', the songs did not resonate with me as fully as other albums of theirs have. But there is no denying that voice.
is a classic "road" album in the sense that its songs largely seem written to or about people who are not present

Hiatt‚Äôs first album for Capitol records feels much more country than his other albums, and the closest Hiatt has ever come to MOR. Pedal steel and harmonica make more of an appearance as does an almost spoken vocal delivery on a couple of tracks. The general pleasant yet not noteworthy appeal is only lifted by the two highlight tracks, opener ‚ÄòCry Love‚Äô and the earthy folk ballad, ‚ÄúThe River Knows Your Name‚Äô.

This is phenomenal stuff, rhythmically addictive and the experimentation is both extreme and catchy - a tough combo to pull off.
A lot of post-punk stuff is rather po-faced and/or stiff - not so this. 
It sounds like nothing else from '95 that's for sure, the best sort of oddity. COCK FIGHT!
A Beautiful personal favorite of mine. The classic singer-songwriter with Matt and Keith's own unique flare and wow does it comfort my soul every time I hear this album. Perfect
One of my personal favorites by vertical horizon. The album sounds soo good especially with Carter Beauford of Dave Matthews Band on it on Drums. Overall, Very beautiful and moving.

Vertical Horizon's sophomore album sees them continuing in the singer-songwriter direction that they started with on their debut. This album also has a little rock flare to it on some songs. This album has many beautiful and uplifting songs as swell and I think this is better than their debut. 
Favorite Song(s): Call it Even, Heart in Hand
Least Favorite(s): Candyman
Eric Clapton always gives us a beautiful interpretation of his blues idols, and he delivers very well with this record.

At the crossroad of rock and groovy blues, the 4 dudes from Clutch offers a half-good half-boring record. What I mean is that if you enjoy the first tracks, then it will probably work for you, as they all sound (almost) the same and share similar musical structures.

Much the same as their debut album. It's difficult to identify any differences between the two, so I'd argue that both these albums are interchangeable in terms of quality. The only thing that brings down the rating were unmet expectations of musical progression. The best track might be 'Raindrop'. Would still recommend.

I'm not a fan of emo.
Even as someone who's not a fan of emo I really appreciated the raw guitar sound of this album. It's also within that perfect range of length so it doesn't feel like it's dragging on for so long. I'd recommend this album personally. Still not a fan of emo tho

Tina seems really confused after the first 4 songs, which are the strongest... This always seems to happen with a lot of artists hat had successful albums: most of them can't make a good album afterwards; in Tina case's it took this one to get to Foreign Affair, one that is more consistent and confident of itself.
Very fun and beautiful singing + guitar melodies. Definitely a sleeped on album that came out in the 70s.
notable (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ)

Durazno sangrando really brings back some of those beautiful Artaud compositions and while a song like Encadenado Al √Ånima might be a little aimless at certain points, they make up for it with great melodies and production. That middle section in Encadenado Al √Ånima reminds me alot of Dogs from Pink Floyd and this was 2 years before that. Excellent album and a real step up for Invisible.
Her most pop and perhaps most misunderstood work, composed during a darkest period of her life, this album exudes stress and emotion - and I love it.

Kinsella might remain the token "difficult" artist in the indie pop collection of University students, but Joan of Arc are as Chicago, low-class, unknown, and unappetizing as Green River cola. 
 will be their Spoonsize Horrible album.
further cements that fact and continues their status as one of rock‚Äôs most thought-provoking, fun, and masterful outfits today.

Yeah nah. Clutch's "Sunrise On Slaughter Beach" is a middling and ineffectual piece of Stoner Rock with next to no impact. It's hard to find words to articulate my thoughts on this album because I truly have very little to say. The riffs and instrumentation are OK, but nothing special; the vocals are fine but sometimes reach a level of corniness only rivaled by Power Metal. A mediocre album that ultimately leads to nothing of substance.
is brilliant by consciously avoiding brilliance.

Not sure why, but I always lumped Promise Ring in with the "boring" emo bands of the 90s without ever really listening. Joke's on me I guess, since this is a pretty affable and catchy record that I liked now, but would probably have loooved if I first heard it when I was like, 22.

Jesus fucking christ, this is FRESH AF. Spotify algorith surprised me once again. ‚ÄûArtificial Light‚Äú is perfect single. Love the vocals ‚Äì very mature and youthful at the same time. Production is very solid, the way I like. The sound of the entire album is original, there are pop moments significant for the era album was released. Very impressive ‚Äì talking about that zeitgeist of early 2000s in US.

A release in the emo world that transends the genre and takes the music to unique places and atmospheres. I find this album to be much more textured compared to the groups debut project which read like a standard post hardcore record
Overlooked emo classic

With her first studio album in 4 years Barbra updates her sound, with current 80s pop music while once again giving it her own twist with her amazing voice. I really like how consistent and dynamic this record is, making it one of her best.
Highlights: Here We Are at Last, Make No Mistake, He's Mine and Clear Sailing.
Barbra delivers as always. Balads and up-tempo songs are all sang amazingly and a great concept of representing as something different in each track. One of my favorites
Kinda catchy

You shouldn‚Äôt need me to tell you to buy this‚Äîany self-respecting fan of rock music should own 
 already. And if you do, buy it again. The remastering is great, and the bonus disc is the rare add-on to a classic album that genuinely sheds new light on the recording.

Whatever your pleasure, 
 has long been considered the Stones‚Äô greatest album. It also marks the end of their classic period. 
 fans, line up to the right. Everyone else, remain in the past.
A thrilling addendum to an album confidently reiterating its claim to be their most vital and satisfying.

Woah, it's my 50th review! Thanks to the 3 people that consistently like my reviews. Despite that, I don't have much to say about this album. It's an eclectic listen filled with many whimsicalities and genre-hopping. The 12 dreams of Dr. Sardonicus is not for everyone, but you're guaranteed to get something out of it.

This was a rather good album from a band struggling to make a name for it's self. Spirit may not have achieved the success they strived for, but they did manage to give the world a well crafted album that is a classic in every sense of the word.
It's natures way of course.

I found this record a bit all over the place, with a few too many influences on the songs. You have jazz, folk, rock, pop but I found most of the songs quite repetitive
Nonetheless there are some great tracks like prelude or Mr. Skin
Kid Rock serves up plenty of attitude mixed with enough heartfelt emotion to satisfy consumers of many types

One of the more entertaining displays this year of alternative rock tinged with grunge, Southern rock, and 80's hard rock. It charges forward like a stampede, and tosses listeners onto a horse to ride with them. It's refreshing, since so many similar acts prefer to let their albums trample listeners into unhappy pulps. I'd much rather ride on into the storm.

With their fourth album Caravanserai Santana developted themself by integrating more different musical styles. That improved their artistic aspiration and decreased their commercial success. I'm not really convinced with everything of this album (some vocal contributions didn't please me), nevertheless I have some favourites:
All the Love of the Universe
Look Up
Stone Flower
... represents the band‚Äôs switch to acoustic material and their best studio work.

I found it nearly impossible to close my eyes, and disappear into the music, but it was basically the perfect background music. Great music to play in the background while tinkering in a garage. There is nothing wrong with something being just listenable and not super impressionable
Country Rock classic

This is fine. Strangely it feels like every other song is hard to listen to, as tracks seem to alternate between melodic and clashing. They have a meager narrative thread sprinkled in about commenting on or critiquing pop music, but it doesn't go anywhere. It concludes strong with probably its best song, but that doesn't cloud my conclusion of it being decent, but not great prog/psych rock.

OMM56005
The overdone guitar roars.
A very unique piece with over-the-top psychedelia and foggy atmosphere, and excessively deformed distorted sounds. It is a work that can be said to be the earliest period of German progressive rock. Listen to the end and I'll be full.
That said, I'm not good at Guru Guru.
# CD

The last gasp of the Dead during their identifiably interesting experimental/psychedelic era is great but has some weaker numbers that lessen the overall punch. It holds several total classics that illustrate their potential for brilliant psych like China Cat and St Stephen, but they would never again be so sonically bold, despite making their best records right after this.
Right from the heart of West-Africa and the Caribbean to downtown London, this group combines its natal spirit with the urban elements formatting a unique world vision.

Aerosmith may not have completely obliterated their stature as classic rock greats, but in the storied halls of rock and roll, 
 resides in the geriatric wing.
If you can get through the whole boring 80's pop record, and not just play Dirty Laundry a few times, you're a stronger man than I.
Very underrated. Tons of catchy songs. Love this album
With catchy hooks and noisey, playful guitars, it's about the most fun psychedelic album you can think of. Great for blasting out loud while on the highway, but it does get repetitive at times.

I love this EP so much. The instrumentals are far and beyond amazing, vocals are a little off though. It has this weird effect to it, like they're compressed to hell or something. I don't hate it but it just doesn't sound as crisp and punchy as the rest of the band does. Other than that though, this EP is next level in terms of this genre and really pushed the envelope. Saosin is just a great band all around.

Pudding En Gisteren is great but it is weaker than the previous 2 for a couple for some reasons. The album has a strange unorganized structure with a short track much like their biggest hit She Was Naked which is Radio which is their other big hit. A weird interlude followed by a nice pop song similair to higher then to an experimental 12 minute track? The closer is the best part of the album but the album just feels incomplete.

Cool doom metal record, with plenty of interesting and heavy moments
Wartime, Day of Reckoning are the standouts for me with great rhythmic ideas and an overall dark atmosphere
If I had to say something negative, the album lacks variety: most of the tracks are pretty similar, though the finale is really amazing!

the vibes are immaculate 
yeah the vocals are standard for the genre but as the pioneers of it its pretty cool to hear

I absolutely loved this record and I thought it was very memorable and grabbing. The vocals are so weird and out of place when compared to the music that is being played and I love that. The riffs and solos are insanely catchy and groovy and the simplicity of their sound works perfectly here. 
Favorite Song-All Your Sins

I liked the atmosphere and energy of this one a lot. Yes, the vocals are pretty standard for the genre but the overall atmosphere of darkness is quite amusing! I also enjoyed the guitar work on here and the dynamism in sound as compared to day of reckoning, which I found more boring at times
A pretty decent metal album. Amazing instrumentation, ok vocals and lyrical content. Kind of got stale towards the end.
Short progressive record that didn't really hold my interest. The last track felt like a predecessor to Mastodon's "The Czar", which was cool.

Absolutely beautiful progressive rock album with 5 distinct songs. Excellent album although I will say that while Lady Fantasy is excellent, it is far from being one of the absolute peak progressive rock pieces with Nimrodel coming closer in that regard.

Beautifully more simple than any of our mythmaking delusions, 
 is Ocean‚Äôs life as he experiences it: fluid and fluctuating, one man in motion. This is what freedom sounds like.

On the whole, 
 is more assured and consistent than 
. It inherits the bagginess of his overstuffed debut, but lacks the thrill of groundbreaking novelty. Frank Ocean is an outlier, an artist who can produce an album this phenomenal and nevertheless fall a bit short.

For an album that is at times intentionally difficult to follow - for all its vague and indistinct meanderings between subjects, between minds and bodies, between place and time, 
 remains a highly accessible album - and not just sonically.

It‚Äôs just about impossible to live up to the hype that an album like this has been subjected to, but Ocean comes pretty close. 
 is often a bit of a sprawling mess, but with some patience it becomes one of the most rewarding albums you‚Äôll hear all year.
No gimmicks, no massive production. Just beautiful songs with depth, feeling and passion.

delves even further into Ocean‚Äôs creeping sense of mortality than 
, but with the kind of focused songwriting and production values befitting the intense level of fan expectation that preceded its release.
An undoubtedly reactive work, this is undiluted and progressive nonetheless.

It's ya boi, unpopular opinion here. This album, to me, is really really boring. I don't know the appeal of it but whatever. I tried but couldn't get into it. It's too skeletal for me
Edit (52 -> 90): I didn't think I would get much more out of this, especially due to how dull I still think Nikes is. Blonde is brilliant poetry, and mind blowing but subtle production. Jarring emotions, and no happy ending. In other words, it is beautiful art, and I am proud to finally appreciate it.

Her ambitious third record marks another giant progression in an already distinguished career, and offers provocative thoughts on sacrifice and identity that should long outlast its 48-minute runtime.

While some tracks will surprise established fans, to say that 
 is a departure or style swap for Olsen doesn't really take into account the album as a whole. The elements that are new here play out like a means to an end for a songwriter with a tale to tell, one chock-full of raw emotions.
Angel Olsen‚Äôs fearless and eloquent embrace of raw emotions in all their messy splendor ultimately feels oddly uplifting, the way it always does when you witness a gifted artist at her best.

Individually, all of the songs are strong, self-contained bits of cleverly written and emotionally gripping indie rock ... Olsen has always been a compelling songwriter, but more than ever she showcases a range evident in just how versatile that songwriting is.

From the surreal, cloudy opening of ‚ÄòIntern‚Äô to the wild and noisy guitars that close out ‚ÄòSister,‚Äô 
 feels like an authentic trip into Angel Olsen‚Äôs mind. It may not be perfect - and it‚Äôs certainly not all roses - but it‚Äôs real.
The perfect example of an artist moving forward, without losing any of the magic that first brought her to our attention.
amounts to Olsen's most ambitious work, its contrast and contradiction fitting no neat narrative.

In terms of composition and production, 
 is Olsen‚Äôs most ambitious album yet. Taking a more polished ‚Äî though not straight-up glossy ‚Äî approach, Olsen sounds more vulnerable for having made her vocals more central to the mix.
What is consistent is Olsen's musical personality, which feels perfectly at ease and singular, irrespective of producers or genres or other boxes that might try to contain it.
As with her previous efforts Olsen‚Äôs unique vocal steals the show, but this is the singer opening up all the other parts to her personality. The more we see, the more there is to love.
is a record coated in the sounds of radio‚Äôs past, a potpourri of classic rock gestures and doo-wop sway, yet Olsen‚Äôs mindset is anything but nostalgic.
It‚Äôs more ambitious than her last one; better too. But I simply don‚Äôt think the formulaic songwriting is worthy of praise, nor the very notion of being more ambitious.
It‚Äôs an album steeped in 1960s jangle pop, swirling psychedelia, and other classic influences that further breaks Olsen‚Äôs music away from anything that could definitively be called folk rock.

MY WOMAN is a stunning singer-songwriter showcase. Angel flips between the lilt of Motown ("Never Be Mine"), the croon of Dolly ("Sister"), and the wailing immediacy of Siouxsee ("Shut Up Kiss Me") with ease as she incorporates various genres throughout the record. Her powerhouse vocals underscore the turmoil inherent in the lyrical conceit of the album: the inherent struggle to find and maintain your identity in the face of love.

This is the quintessential Angel Olsen record and also is the perfect transition between BYFFNW and All Mirrors.
HIGHLIGHTS: INTERN, SHUT UP KISS ME, HEART SHAPED FACE, SISTER, WOMAN
WORST TRACK: THOSE WERE THE DAYS

This isn't a bad album, but I didn't enjoy it too much. The instrumental work was pretty cool, nothing ground breaking, but something about the vocals made me not enjoy. I'm not sure if it was the vocals themself, or the lyrical content.

Next stop on my 1998 anniversary musical journey: Finland. Nightwish's second album Oceanborn provides an opera-like symphonic powerful metal sound with the theatralic and expressive vocals by singer Tarja Turunen, even a duo with Tapio Wilska of Sethian (he also contributes the lead vocals on "The Pharaoh Sails to Orion"). Good musical export from Scandinavia.
With its relatively short running time, it makes for a fine introduction to Nadler's work, the sparse instrumentation highlighting her beautiful voice.

In the end, it‚Äôs a bit disappointing to see her regress from the bold moves she made on 2011's 
, but it seems to be the trade-off we‚Äôve made for 
 lyrical clarity.¬†
gromg really good symphonic power metal

8/10
exceptional
Fav tracks: <all songs>
He's a singularly idiosyncratic and brilliant songwriter, one hitting an arresting stride on this uniformly superb album.¬†

His outlook is fresh and remains interesting. 
 may not stand as the zenith of the man‚Äôs catalogue, but it‚Äôs a highlight worth exploring and a dreamy journey for the taking.

proves to be much more easily accessible than some of his previous efforts whilst still keeping its charm, an album in the more conventional sense without the dense weirdness and cryptic lyrics that could often be found in his earlier work.

¬†
The record has an intensely intimate, navel-gazing feel, and meanders its way dreamily through Spanish folk, pastichey pop and techno.
¬†

Another excellent album by this extraordinary artist. Just listen to the first three tracks, you will be convinced (then continue and be ready for some more stunning songs with one or another surprise) or not, then simply stop listen to Devendra.

Some adorably cutesy (yes, it's cutesy) indie folk that recalls Grizzly Bear, Bon Iver, Sigur Ros/Jonsi (occasionally) and most obviously Foreign Fields. 
It goes down easy, like a spoonful of sugar stirred in water.

This album has some really special orchestral qualities to it. Some of the compositions are remarkable. My main drawback is the vocals. High-pitched, drowned out, and a little whiny, they work within the aesthetic, in a way, but I just wasn't a fan personally. A unique and very admirable record though.

title: Down Where the Spirit Meets the Bone

reviews.content:
Quite a bluesy one - and a double set? Really?
I'll allow it - this flows quite smoothly for a double album.
Although he's now logged as much time as a solo artist as he did with his former band, Isbell sounds he's still finding his voice.

'Here We Rest' is when Isbell really gets into the groove with this smoother, more commercial sound - this is the first of his solo albums you really get the feeling he's totally abandoned those Truckers trappings. 
His voice is given top billing like never before and the confidence is clear. Pop songs like 'Heart on a String' rub shoulders with radio ballads like 'Stopping By', good ol' country numbers like 'Codeine' mix with the old school boogie woogie of 'Never Could Believe'.
Although it‚Äôs neither as purposeful nor as prescient as many of his earlier EPs, Sam Beam‚Äôs latest release carries far more weight than its self-deprecating title implies.
Under rated, smooth and easy to listen to. I love his story telling, his soft guidance through emotion, he's a leader in the genre and in each song. Great quality for how short it is.
His latest LP is as reliably fine as a new film from the Coen Brothers.
Apocalypse is certainly less accessible than its predecessor, perhaps even wilfully so.

I loved this album. It was a very creative and innovative take on a sound I already like. Interesting production is usually something that lacks in a lot of folk, even the great stuff. Lyrically and vocally Bill is excellent putting together some of the best lyrics of that year with buttery vocal delievery
Right where the alternative country ends and the desert rock begins, Bill Callahan has delimited his musical boundaries, determined not to overcome them, no matter the cost or the pressure.

Will Oldham's latest could be the evil twin of the singer/songwriter's career peak, 1999's 
: If that 90s record plumbed the bleakness of life, 
 finds peace in the modest pleasures of friends, family, and music.

My introduction to the band which instantly reminded me of Tim Buckley, Nick Drake, Neil Young, and other sing-songwriters of this nature, and put Molina in with contemporaries like Wil Oldham, John Darnielle etc. Dark, sprawling guitar and vocal work that sticks with you.
The golden voice, the beautiful lyrics. I guess this was recording in an almost 'live' setting. Maybe its not as fleshed out as his later work, but there are plenty of great tracks on here.

Americana artist S.G. Goodman addresses all the complications of romantic love alongside critiques of our economic system in her heartfelt new LP, 
.

This album is one of my favorites of 2022. S.G. Goodman not only does the Alt Country Singer Song Writer well but gives us a diverse line up of rockers and sensitive songs filled with introspection. When I suggest this artist to others I often say its like what if Big Their and Jason Isbell had a beautiful sensitive heart felt baby (who knows how to rock to boot)

is H.C. McEntire's third solo album, and with each release she has demonstrated that she's a major talent who deserves to be recognized by anyone with a taste for a well-told story of one woman's life.

This is where Vic rediscovers his mojo and unleashes those painful, thundering guitar solos again. 
'Fodder on Her Wings' is one of his most intriguing vocal performances, hushed and ghostly, a rare Chesnutt song that instantly captivates. 
The album isn't perfect, it's a bit of an ungainly sprawl, but probably worthy of a top 4 placing among his discog.

The album‚Äôs main musical ingredients‚Äîfinger-picked guitar, lightly brushed drums, relaxed though subtly emotive vocals‚Äîknowingly recall the quietest, most pained cuts on 70s outlaw country records and the twangiest numbers on that era‚Äôs rock-leaning singer-songwriter LPs.¬†

Neko Case has crafted an album whose quiet drift only adds to its power ...¬† this disc sounds a bit like Case's version of 
, a personal exploration of the heart and soul that proves sad and beautiful can often walk hand in hand.
A beautiful alt country record with amazing production and vocal performances and a sound pallet that is so dreamy yet still true to country. An amazing record everyone should check out.

Sounds like a marriage of Tarentella's gothic country sensibilities with some Tori Amos-ish vocal stylings. For me, this is a perfect union; I don't generally like country, but this dark and vibrant project is something to behold.
It's an album of striking and stark beauty, with finely crafted songs that feel stripped to their bare essentials, and just allowed to be what they are, unadorned.

An excellent release that straddles multiple genres -- rock, folk, Americana, country -- and nails all of them. The approach is varied, but never comes off as overly scattershot. The melodies are always strong, and the rollicking nature of the tunes and the vocals lends a sort of rambunctiousness to the songs that seems like they must be from a different era, in the best way possible.
The Oregon songwriter‚Äôs 12th album is replete with beautifully crafted songs that celebrate fresh starts and new beginnings.

title: A River Running to Your Heart

reviews.content: qualifies as a complete triumph and one that serves Fruit Bats‚Äô legacy well. To describe it as simply exceptional doesn‚Äôt say it all.
Johnson‚Äôs almost impeccable songwriting that touches so many musical bases, while at the same time keeping that folk pop base that the band is so good at.

A cute little indie pop album that sounds like I'm taking a trip down memory lane. This album feels quite nostalgic with songs like 'We Used To Live Here' which paints this image of going through all of your old toys and whatnot, reminiscing about the past. However, sometimes it tends to feel quite repetitive throughout the album, on top of being a genre that I don't find much enjoyment in anyways. But it was great nonetheless.

A nice collection of indie folk songs, while I think some of this could have been elevated it's an enjoyable listen all the way through. It's got a sweet immediacy to it. 
"I never knew that it could feel this nice,
Jesus Tap Dancing Christ, 
it feels good to be home"
Favourite Tracks: Rushin' River Valley, See The World By Night, The Deep Well, Jesus Tap Dancing Christ
Least Favourite: Waking Up In Los Angeles

Fans of Elliott Smith or Cass McCombs at their most purely acoustic and lo-fi need look no further for a female vocal equivalent in 2023.
73% non qualifying rating for 2023

Old school country (Prine?) meets old school folk (Dylan, a lot of Dylan here) - and while this album could be accused of sounding too reverential and studied it also boasts real song craft and vibe.
My 2019 rating to watch, this one could grow and grow....or drop off to a mid 70 something rating.

The only Americana/country record that impressed me so far for this year with its poignant storytelling style that tells the backstories of smalltown life, its quite miseries and the people that inhabits it. A record of surprising depth and diaristic nature that is truly something special.
The melodic charms are epic, the lyrical insights about romantic disappointment universal.

With her 2015 follow-up 
, Pratt does little to change the hermetic alchemy she began on her debut, offering up only the subtlest developments to her already mesmerizing style.¬†
, Pratt's exquisite second LP, both reinforces the 27-year-old's place in the folk tradition and sets her apart as an exceptional songwriter who is a master of nuance and minutiae.
Despite the fact that the album is still almost entirely solo ... the songs seem poppier, trippier; far more open-ended.

Its warm, home-recorded atmosphere is more dramatic and distinctive than 
: finger-picked psychedelia, lucidly layered harmonies, hissy tape effects, an overcast haze.

With 
, Jessica Pratt has crafted a record that is as accessible as it is complex, two traits that she proves are not mutually exclusive.
is a poignant and melancholy listen; one filled with gentle warmth that rings just as appropriate for both a slowly rising morning or an unwinding evening with a glass or two of wine.
The sophisticated songwriting nods to Joni Mitchell and Sibylle Baier, but an appealing playfulness is evident too.

Wrote the Slant review for this one, if you want to read my full thoughts. In short: this is a new country classic, a hugely ambitious album with heartfelt stories centered around queerness, addiction, grief and more. 
Don't miss out on Critterland!

Hushed, soft, vulnerable-sounding, and moving vocals sway over Salsburg‚Äôs guitar and beautiful string arrangements from producer James Elkington at times (like on the track ‚ÄúWhen the Light is Dying‚Äù) giving this a feel not dissimilar from some of Joe Boyd‚Äôs production work for Fairport Convention, Sandy Denny, and even Nick Drake‚Äôs string-laden 
.
Pratt has provided for herself a successful introduction to the world, where her unpredictable melodies and vocal tics proudly display strengths and weaknesses with unwavering confidence

Pretty much the only sounds that appear on 
 are Pratt and a closely-recorded acoustic guitar, picking spidery melodies and pleasing circles that form the backbone of so many post-‚Äò60s folk songs.¬†

This debut is better than expected - very little to separate it in terms of song writing quality with the following two albums.
It‚Äôs more sparse and the production is basic but it doesn‚Äôt hold the album back - if anything it adds to the timeless feel and kids us into believing we‚Äôre listening to a hidden folk relic from the mid ‚Äò70s.
beautiful

If 
 doesn't break new ground, it does offer comfort and compassion wrapped in a honeyed, effortless indie folk that honors the project's now-long tenure.
indescribable feeling of folk at night, a fresh and classic style that remains simply when you finish the album without realizing it

Kind of like a lighter more vocal focussed The War On Drugs or Kurt Vile but without all of the quirks and studio obsessiveness and upfront instrumental musical moments that make those artists great.
I don‚Äôt often like albums where the music is always pushed so far back behind the vocals but I‚Äôve read that this album grows so I might come back to it another day.

came about as a way to work through problems; problems that we've all experienced. Although the voice is from another time and the imagery is dramatic, the themes are universal - and that's how we connect with this toweringly talented song writer.
debut album, new indie-folk, chamber pop
Bonny Doon have proven their ability to transform their complex songwriting and vivid melodies into experiences that resemble those long hours of elusive conversations we crave.

may lack a big breakthrough tune like Whitney‚Äôs ‚ÄòNo Woman‚Äô and some of the songs are overlong, but right from the gentle title track and opener to the sleepy blues of instrumental and closer ‚ÄòWalkdown‚Äô it‚Äôs a record I will no doubt go back to again and again this year for that loose Americana fix.
Bonny Doon's Woodsist label debut sticks with the ambling, Pavement-descended indie rock that has defined the quartet's sound, but makes some significant updates.
‚ÄòLongwave‚Äô is a gently simple record but one which manages to exert an almost hypnotic pull.

The Detroit quartet's first album for Woodsist is at times striking and catchy, but also finds itself digging up the same nostalgia-seeking melodies that showed some promise for Bonny Doon to begin with.
pastiche can be beautiful

Cleary an homage to the 1960s it lies somewhere between John Denver, The Beatles, The Beach Boys, Elvis and Country music. While probably a little bloated and samey at some points, the vibe is quite nostalgic and very enjoyable. This is an album perfect for a road trip in the Sierra Nevada mountains or the Mojave Desert.
cut worms has a super specific tight style with so many minor variations between tracks which makes for one of my fave folk country records

Mhm
 Some cool folky roots. I‚Äôm too sure what to feel about this record because I‚Äôm not super familiar with folk. I think a lot of the songs have great stories, and the instrumentation is pretty stripped back. The longer ones, especially are satisfying when he fleshes things out.

Almost a perfect album and definitely a personal favorite. Favorite tracks: Venture, Fruits of my Labor, Sweet Side, Real Live Bleeding Fingers, Those Three Day. Unfortunately, I will never like the song Atonement no matter how hard I try.
An all time classic from my youth that still oddly holds up to this day.

I am going to see Brandi live in two weeks, so I thought it was time I refamiliarized myself with her discography, starting with The Story. I really love the title track, it is one of those songs that I think will just be appreciated more with time, its raw emotion and smart songwriting makes it a classic. The sweet vocals and intricate harmonies on songs like Cannonball are pure honey, so good. Nothing too extraordinary, but it is an above average singer-songwriter album for sure.
This is an album full of wistful, hushed vocals, gently plucked acoustics and some beautiful harmonies. No alarms, no surprises, but it does make for a lovely listen.
Songwriting this unadorned requires melodic strength and confidence, but the pair never waver from their acoustic guitars and occasional violin.

While Kings of Convenience don't cover fresh territory with 
, they do what they do as impeccably as ever here and offer a handful changeups and hummable tunes along the way. It should serve as a welcome return for any established fans.

There are moments when you can almost hear the gurgle of a coffee machine in the back- ground, but 
 is sophisticated without being easy, a quiet storm all of its own.
It‚Äôs just so good to have them back. It doesn‚Äôt reinvent the wheel from their previous works, but after 12 years of absence, this is the perfect dose of what I needed.

Isbell's solo career kicks off with the all round solid 'Sirens of the Ditch' - yes, as expected it sounds a lot like an album made up of his usual contributions to a Truckers release with a little more 'tasteful' piano embellishment to buff things up. 
It reaffirms he was right to go solo...though at this point you're unsure who'll come out of the deal better, Jason or his former band mates.
A low-impact but endearing detour into indie folk.

title: No Trail and Other Unholy Paths

reviews.content:
A marked improvement on his debut and shows an awful lot of development. 
This release takes more risks with instrumentation, vocal tone and performance - plus the songs try and be more impactful (memorable?) in general. 
If the debut was 'cult TV drama' then this music is increasingly cinematic in feel. It's a big album, grand even, and the gothic country vibe is appropriate and all enveloping - the perfect example of the style being the sweeping 'Cemetery Rain'.

Pet town is a really cute album, really easy and fresh to catch some ears.
I do think that it could have been more because if you come to each tracks at hazardous moments, you will ear few changes. The problem seems to come to the arrangement and the production in order to have something very clean and beautifully packed. 
It doesn't deliver much huge moments but each moments are ok so it's an ok+ album.

'Ghetto Bells' is somewhat of a placeholder among Chesnutt's oeuvre , though the orchestral opening track is certainly worth your time.
NR

title: Let Me Go, Let Me Go, Let Me Go

reviews.content: Jason Molina is a strong lyricist who evokes feelings of bleakness and sorrow with sparse instrumentation on his solo project. This also has a stupendous vocal performance‚Äîvery impassioned and country tinged. The lo fi stark sound serves as a great contrast with his blockbuster Magnolia Electric Co. album. No real standouts‚Äîsave for the opener and closer‚Äîbut a great album for long drives.
is an effortless transition for Banhart from an obscure lo-fi artist to a slightly more accessible songwriting talent. Let's hope he manages to keep this up.
Welcome to the third collection of Devendra's primitive, folk tales which enliven slowly, right in front of our eyes, within a poetic world where courage fights fear, in such a fascinating way.

Extraordinary folk! Each song is so damn calming and sounds INCREDIBLE
What an amazing artist and guitar player to add
Just beautiful work
As a french resident, not only he senses a deep affection for Baudelaire's spleen but he also feels that this spleen has been installed in his soul and from there, it conducts his musical needs.

On the whole, 
 lives up to the promise of its vague title. It‚Äôs a document that allows you to come away from it with any number of different messages and poignant observations of your own.

Like 
, 
 is a challenging listen, and some might view it as Kozelek's most indulgent album yet. But his brilliant musicianship and guitar playing combined with his fascinating storytelling skills ensure that his music is as poignant and life-affirming as ever, and the album is yet another success in his remarkable catalog.

Universal Themes finds Mark once again displaying his masterful skills as a storyteller however this record does feel a tad unfocused.
Best Track: Littler Rascals
Worst Track: Cry Me a River Williamsburg Sleeve Tattoo Blues

winter city ghosts instant classic
send it to oslo instant classic
With a bit more classical influence Mark makes a very beautiful sounding album recorded mostly as a solo act. Though that means it is some of his most intimate and beaitiful material
Nice Folk album from Mark Kozelek's most known project, and like how it is classical guitar influenced.
is a stunning debut and one of the best records of 2002.

This lofi acoustic folk-country record is a very hypnotic expierence that took me by surprise. It is extremely well constructed and one of the best in this style I have heard. I wanna come back to this more it was very soothing.

Great indie folk record. The sound is incredible and the lyrics are great. From what I've heard from Iron & Wine, I'm pretty sure their sound gets worse, but their writing gets even better. Saw him live when I was like 12 or 13 years old, at the Red Rocks Amphitheatre. I don't remember much of my childhood, but I remember that. My standout tracks are: "Bird Stealing Bread," "Faded from the Winter," "Lion's Mane," and "Southern Anthem."

This lofi acoustic folk-country record is a very hypnotic expierence that took me by surprise. It is extremely well constructed and one of the best in this style I have heard. I wanna come back to this more it was very soothing.

Are You Gone is the depressing sound of Harmer‚Äôs talent aimed at the singular goal of appeasing CBC DJs. I wish she and Paquin hadn‚Äôt put so much work into making these instrumentals sound so normal. Makes pretty lame what could be filled with character (and what has been throughout a lot of Harmer‚Äôs musical career).
Colourless and flat classic rock devoted to a worn tradition.

This fourth album from Matthew Houck's Phosphorescent project originally came out in May but is being reissued so soon simply to tie in with Houck's early September UK tour. As its title might imply, it's not exactly the most radical or original of 2010 releases. However, its handling of various Americana and alt-country tropes is so assured and lush that it certainly deserves a second push.

On Matthew Houck‚Äôs (aka Phosphorescent) last all-original full length album, 2007‚Äôs Pride, Houck looked inward to his own personal struggles and chose to record the album entirely on his own. Since then, Houck has opened up a bit more, working with a full band on his 2009 Willie Nelson tribute album, To Willie, and incorporating that full band sound on his latest album, Here‚Äôs to Taking It Easy.

What a find on Alexa's machine. This group holds you like Garcia and swoons you like Metheny. Soft country gem with only an upside to their musical presence, Go! Scott and your band. You had me and and my wife Elyse right from Blue Rider. The rest of the album was wine time. Don

The combination of the sister‚Äôs voices on this material is stunning in its natural beauty. Stripped-down arrangements and producer Teddy Thompson‚Äôs light hand help accentuate the words, emotions and the interwoven singing.

Each singer takes turns on lead vocals, with tight harmonies also featuring strongly. There is just enough difference in the two voices to keep things interesting, while producer Teddy Thompson corrals an A-list of session players.
's unadorned, low-key sound is key to some of the album's more radical feats of imagination.

is a beacon, a glimmer of the possible. It's a stark, beautiful recording that hopefully proves something to both Lynne and Moorer: That what's here is a new beginning and that there is much more to explore.
succeeds at proving the band is more than an assemblage of talented players.

This time around in particular, there‚Äôs an eclectic, almost electric sort of sharpness to Shires‚Äô voice that not only ensures she takes centre stage, together with her songs, but also allows her to harness the power and precision of a great country singer while all the while performing as an artist more styled to the southern rock genre that‚Äôs growing in popularity.
Singer/violinist Amanda Shires avoids easy lessons and genre expectations in crafting a catchy and challenging new album.

At ten songs and a filler-free 32 minutes, 
 is relatively brief, but it marks a substantial ‚Äî and very successful ‚Äî shift for Shires towards a progressive, literate and ambitious blend of rock, folk and pop music.
The rising Americana singer-songwriter flips the script on her ambitious seventh LP, with help from husband Jason Isbell.
Musically progressive, it‚Äôs Shires most ambitious work to date; nasty, stomping Southern rock sits next to poppier fare and several moments of quiet introspection.
is well worth your time and attention, regardless of how you feel about country music or indie rock.

Shires arrives with her most vulnerable, cohesive and pristine record to date. To The Sunset, as an idea and as a body of work, it is a well performed scenery from her inner chaos.
FAVS: Parking Lot Pirouette, Leave It Alone, Charms, Take on the Dark
LEAST FAV: Mirror, Mirror

Amanda Shires is worth giving your attention towards. Her take on country music with an gritty, loud, anti-folk spin on it is a breath of fresh air. The effects and production shed more change than her actual singing style and rhythm sometimes, but it's not to the point it's distracting. From Shires words to her guitar, To The Sunset has many shades of comfort, inspiration, and wonder.
The final track is transcendent

It's only mid-July, 
 still seems like a lock for record of the year in a throwback genre expanding beyond cassette-collectors and Brain Records lovers.

Both beautiful and terrible at once, 
 is the aural equivalent of a scuba dive in the open ocean.

Lopatin dissects elements of sound and arranges them into new magickal sigils, making 
 not just a collection of tracks but an indivisible and cohesive whole, held in place this time not by grids and zones but by atmospheres and plumes.¬†

Perhaps the most humane action Lopatin‚Äôs performed on 
 is to trim it, keeping things tight at a prompt forty minutes.

Returnal is as disturbing as you can think of but also a very peaceful album with many unique textures and sounds. Oneohtrix Point Never creates a bizarre atmosphere that is quite hard to get for the first time but is most satisfying and amazing.
This album marks Lopatin's turning point from ambient drone to progressive experimental electronica, and it succeeds at merging the two styles into a captivating listening experience.

The first 4 tracks all in a row are pure transcendence. The Other 4 songs are good too. Nil Admirari sounds like death (in a good way) and everything else is pure electronic beauty. The return of the glitchiness in Preyouandi is pretty sick too. Plus the vocals on Returnal are totally unexpected but really sick. If I had to pick a favorite track though, it would be Stress Waves. It feels like waves of stress leave me every time I put it on. Listen this album is a good.
A great americana record with a singer that has a perfect voice for the genre. She has a great knack for storytelling and while it sags a little in the middle the album is very well paced

8/10
exceptional
Fav tracks: Revelator, My First Lover, Dear Someone, Red Clay Halo, April the 14th, Pt. 1, I Want To Sing That Rock and Roll, Elvis Presley Blues, Everything Is Free, I Dream a Highway
Um retrato fino de uma introspec√ß√£o grossa e direta, ao mesmo tempo que crua, muito bem pontuada e finalizada em quaisquer aspectos.
A great americana record with a singer that has a perfect voice for the genre. She has a great knack for storytelling and while it sags a little in the middle the album is very well paced

Grab the nearest hammock and prepare to snooze - this is a double set!
Yes, I feel you - a double serving of the band‚Äôs trademark ‚ÄòSigur Ros and Slowdive writing nice incidental music together‚Äô style sounds like a tall order...and so it proves.
Always more than pleasant...never rouses itself in an attempt to join the pantheon of shoegaze, post rock or ambient greats.
After eight albums and nearly 20 years into their musical adventure, this is as impressive as any of their releases.

is Kleenexgirlwonder's 
, every track a scruffy pop nugget waiting to be discovered by intrepid listeners.

a big wall of teenage emotions. this album was a bit daunting due to how many tracks there were, and by the end i did have some burnout, but overall this was a really really fun and enjoyable album. not a bad song on here and i can see myself coming back to this a lot and getting addicted to the super catchy nature of these songs. recommended

A sprawling slacker pop album with a good knack for melodies. There‚Äôs some 60‚Äôs influence here‚Äîbut the whole album holds up like a fine wine. Lo-fi production and a cool guitar tone also make this sparkle.

There are moments on 
 for which words fail-- particularly the cover of David Bowie's "Let's Dance", where Ward's low-key, acoustic delivery reveals a surprisingly emotional, fragile piece-- and while that may be an extremely uncomfortable position for a music reviewer, for a listener, it's the best place you could possibly be.
Its a little darker and more conceptual and it works in the album's favor. M Ward delivers a solid contemporary folk album with much consistency
If I were to describe the album in one word, it would be blissful

'Drunk' lives up to its title by being a bit sloppy and unpredictable - more one to cherry pick the better offerings from (the acoustic gem 'Supernatural' and the R.E.M'ish 'Naughty Fatalist'). 
A transitional album.
The lyrical content is perhaps more relevant than ever. I feel like this album gets a tough shake from critics.
is simply a wonderful, balanced gem of an album from a masterful songwriter.
Arrangements are simple, bluegrass-inflected and rich in acoustic textures. Warm and thick as a hayrick.

for an album cover like that i expected more grittiness and raw music but it's kinda just vibing out there on a swans-y note, the best song on here is by far just an actual swans song anyway ha (blind, from white light)

For somebody who loves swans, I‚Äôve never actually listened to a Gira solo project. But I‚Äôm glad I did. Because this album is very good. It‚Äôs just solidly written singer-songwriter sludge from the boy. Despite not having swans attached, it feels like it. I wonder why.

The songs on 
 are undanceable, unhummable, yet compelling. Ultimately, Mazzy Star's hypnotic music, like Sandoval's voice, is as entrancing as the reflection of an ominous night sky on a lake. And its effect is just as disquieting.
didn't know i needed country tinged dream pop in my life.

I envy the Mazzy Star fans who got to discover this album in 1990 and experience listening to their next two as a fan when they got released... Apart from a few songs feeling a little bit too long, and their influences shining through a bit too much at times, the genre melding uniqueness of this album is flawless and makes total sense for a band that was about to perfect their sound.
i enjoy the country dream pop
No one's going to mention how Be My Angel has the exact same instrumental as Fade Into You?????

although i didn't save many songs from this, it all comes together to deliver a really nice experience. throughout this whole thing i was at ease and blanketed by the sound of this. it sounds like you could be right next to them performing this album, in the middle of some woods. just beautiful stuff.
Folk n' drone nocturnal desert ambience par excellence - the cover art for this one is 100% the perfect match.

title: A Collection of Songs Written and Recorded 1995-1997

reviews.content: Bruh why tf this album rated so low, you guys don‚Äôt dig lo-fi music or something?

Gorgeous ambient textures that are slightly unsettling, with certain dark and jutting sounds appearing here and there. But it‚Äôs still an incredibly human and beautiful piece.
Standout: Aerial Roots
Favs: Akaschic Serenade, Spawn knot, Winter cherry twilight, Oniyanma, Celosia Channel, Quantum lament, Agave
Least fav: Luciola

Hi, i have two things to say
1. im suprised that this album only have 1 critic review and 1 user reviews (now 2 now because i review it)
2. the album cover art is awful and look confusing, the genre should be harsh noise for this (idk how blackholefriend think this is good)

the OST for Silent Hill 4 is just as despairingly beautiful as the Silent Hill 2 OST. Future sound of ambient and progressive electronics inspired by William S. Burroughs.
https://ginandplatonic.bandcamp.com/album/spiritual-decay

The songs are very peaceful and the best way to introduce you to an entirely new world. The nostalgia factor is strong in this one. The combat music screams epic and the calming travel songs make you want to just stand still and listen. Nerevar Rising makes you just want to get out there and explore Morrowind.

A mix of quietly emotive, violin-led symphonic song and distorted, dissonant, percussive orchestral noise, 
 delivers tension and off-kilter anxiety in both hushed and hyper musical moments.
There‚Äôs no center, no soul one can really discern among heavily processed industrial noises, seemingly relentless static, and the occasional synthesizer.

Really solid avant-folk album! Kinda wish it pushed some of the sonic ideas a bit further, but it's got some really striking moments that make me excited to delve into the bands' discography a bit more.

3 unnamed kittens 2019-2019
emily 2015-2017
this ep hurts to listen to, i can't stop myself from sobbing my eyes out when it comes on. absolutely perfect in every way
notable (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ)

With this album and the EP "stanza", Thomas Meluch let the minimalist sounds and the simple and beautiful melodies take part on his catalog. And because of these we can expect much more to come, if he probably add this kind of creation to the lo-fi riffs he use to play. The best ambient record of the year so far.

title: Small Craft on a Milk Sea

reviews.content:
Don't expect another 
 or 
, expect some clever hybridization and enjoyable tone clouds to brighten (or darken, depending on your current mood) your day, the Eno way.
seems a likely record for this stage of Eno‚Äôs career: a set of instrumental studies exploring a varied group of settings and directions that display the breadth of his craft.

While the instrumentation is rather sweet, some of the vocals and layering of the instrumentation make for a pretty unflattering listen at times. Still much to enjoy here nonetheless. 
Standout: O Anti-Fado
Favs: Trad-Mosh, Can√ß√£o de Rejei√ß√£o, Mudar de M√©todo, Mem√≥rias de Paco Forcado, Vol. 2, M√≠nima Aten√ß√£o, A Mula e a Raposa
