Fun disposable 80's pop

Goyard Comin': Exordium is a great side mixtape by Ghais Guevara that include, amazing production, great energy, and vibe, and charismatic performance by Ghais Guevara. Nothing new about him but still his style is fresh and great to listen to.

Debut record of the short-lived new wave band is an infectiously catchy, funky release with some experimental moments that holds your attention very well. Grab your dancing shoes and let's get kickass dancing!

title: The Pariah, the Parrot, the Delusion

reviews.content: Weird prof rock with some brilliant tracks, not quite as good as what came before but within spitting distance.

This album is dark, moody, and edgy. But it needs more care with it. Many beats sound overly synthetic in their production and are underwhelming in a genre that emphasizes this aspect. The vocals are mediocre and the sound is just generally boring and uneasy. Flowers is by far the standout.
While the album showcases the band's equilibrium and by now unquestioned versatility, it does mean that amidst the intended dissonance and vocal cameos, Black Thought's verses are not as prominent.

Despite the record‚Äôs production, some of the group‚Äôs most ambitious to date, it feels incomplete, seemingly ending five or six songs early. It‚Äôs a grower, yes, but there‚Äôs too much to unpack for it to sound vital to modern hip-hop‚Äôs equilibrium.

One of the more accessible sounding additions to The Roots' discography, although the lack of noticeable experimentation is a bit odd. It's like seeing your favorite stripper in street clothes. That.. that might not be the best analogy. Whatever, at least I'm not a fucking cousin killer.
A pretty mild ending to a previously unparalleled career and flawless track record, not much special to not on both the instrumental and lyrical sides respectively
A fierce, poignant melody which, from opening sonic squall to closing delicate fade-out is utterly immaculate.

A very unimpressive power pop album that borrows a lot of its style from The Kinks. The only great song on this entire thing is ‚ÄúWhat I Like About You‚Äù‚Äîwhich is fire. The production is pretty raw‚Äîkinda neat. Otherwise I was quite bored by this.

The Romantics get an "A" for effort. It wasn't for the lack of trying that this band never truly resonated with the masses, it may have come down to an inferior ability to put together a cohesive album front to back. This album contains the break-out hit "What I Like About You", but offered little else in support.

If 
 had a certain pop perfection that brought everything together, 
 was the sound of everything falling apart, which proved at least as compelling.

As humdrum as their debut, sound power pop rock with some single remarkable tracks such as the unusal long opener "O My Soul" or "September Girls". More surprising songs such as the short "Morpha Too" are too little on Big Star's second album Radio City.

I‚Äôve never really dove into old power pop so I don‚Äôt have too much of a frame of reference to compare this to but it sounds rooted in sounds from ten years prior or so. Some real old head shit. Some catchy songs here but mostly music I don‚Äôt care to explore any deeper

title: If It Weren't For Venetian Blinds, It Would Be Curtains For Us All

reviews.content: Very clever, catchy emo-ish rock. "Grace Kelly With Wings" is a classic track. Earworms for days.

In 
, Archive have created an album that does a fine job of representing their eclectic ethos, but this eclecticism also leads the album to occasionally touch on the edge of incoherence.

ABBA self-titles their first release as superstars, rightfully so, before even knowing this one would propel them even higher globally. "Mamma Mia", "I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do" and the phenomenal "SOS" would further cement them in pop culture until their explosive arrival to pop pantheon in 1976. The tracklist goes through some up and downs but there's enough proof of their remarkable talent to make this a solid listen.

"Yesterday's chains have broken in two"
Boney M is always fun. Ma Baker is a classic and this album features what may be my favourite Boney M song, Plantation Boy. The CCR cover is also quite nice. Not a breathtaking album by any means but it's a laugh.

Elton John goes disco, arguably one of his most fun listens but not in the way he probably intended. John managed to make an album that is such an absolute failure it‚Äôs entertaining to listen to.
Key Tracks: Thunder In The Night, Born Bad
Weakest Track: Johnny B. Goode (Goode lord that sax solo lmao)
Inspirational verse: the sax solo

The first album I hear by Boat was their 2000 release Listening Suicidal. And that album was a bouncy, dancy and fun indie rock album with squeeky vocals. Good time reminded me of like The Happy Mondays and Cornelius. This album is like completely different for some reason. But it is the best emo/post-hardcore/noise rock album I've ever heard. It is still a tribute to joy and happiness but now with so much passion and intensity behind it. Well worth a listen.
a disco classic but i like prisoner more

"„Ç∞„ÉÉ„Éâ„Éê„Ç§" is amazing. There is no song in my life that hit me the same as this one. The video clip is as good as this treasure too. It feels so intimate and yet so brightful. it's hopeful, it's true love, it's the sunset, it's art, it's life, it's toe. This summarizes everything I've been feeling lately, such unique and beautiful song

For the first time, Personal Life aggressively follows a pure power punk sound instead of hinting other forms of punk rock. Though there‚Äôs enough three-chord goodness to pass around, The Thermals are also starting to rest comfortably on their layered riffs.
It almost seems as though there are two EPs that make up Personal Life: one comprising crisp pop songs with infectious sing-a-long choruses, and another filled with slower, contemplative snoozers.

Portland, Oregon trio Menomena take a lot of disjointed loops and tear them apart, spin them round and reconstruct them. It's a bit of musical puff-puff-pass, with each band member contributing something and feeding the data into a band-built looping computer program. Sounds alarmingly avant garde, right? And perhaps it is, in theory, but Menomena come across as surprisingly accessible and pop-oriented, even in the midst of all their computerised hyperactivity.

they can‚Äôt keep getting away with this
what can i say about menomena at this point? they‚Äôre without a doubt one of my favorite bands right now, and maybe one of my contenders for the best band post-2000. sure, maybe they drifted away from the experimental stuff of I Am The Fun Blame Monster or Friend And Foe, but they‚Äôve calmed and settled down. how they‚Äôre here to form Mines, another beautiful project.

It‚Äôs Be Your Own Pet!!! What‚Äôs not to like?? Contagiously energetic bullshit!! Jemina‚Äôs wild vocals, the fuzzy guitars and frantic drumming, catchy basslines and angsty lyrics, Get Awkward is something!! It‚Äôs extremely hard to hate this, it‚Äôs insanely fun!!
(Favorite Songs: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre A Waste‚Äù, ‚ÄúFood Fight!‚Äù, ‚ÄúHeart Throb‚Äù)
(Least Favorite Songs: ‚ÄúBummer Time‚Äù)
For better or worse Taking Back Sunday delivers what they always have: glossy yet bouncy pop rock with adorable bitterness, but goddamn if it isn‚Äôt still fun for a few tracks.

This album reminds me of being at school when I went through my Offspring phase. Listening back, there's some utter dross but it was also fun and catchy in places.
Essential track - Summer on the Underground
I‚Äôm honestly not sure why I bothered listening to this, but to my surprise it‚Äôs actually pretty decent. As far as late 90‚Äôs pop punk goes, you could do a lot worse.

It‚Äôs honestly just a solid pop punk album from the 90s. Do not expect the highest from this album or you‚Äôll have a frustrating time lol. It‚Äôs pretty much my summer album since the vibe is a very summer feeling! If you go into this album with a perspective of a fun, cheesy but charming, positive optimism of the 90s then I think you‚Äôll have a fun listen. Very harmless
With the reputation of a genre called post grunge I would expect something incredibly early grading and hard to listen to, but this album is really great. All the hooks are very catchy.
is an album of uplifting optimism that substitutes vulnerability for bravado, and heartfelt sentiment for boisterous thrills.
contains more hooks than most pop groups manage in their careers.
keane will always have a place in my heart, and this album holds so much to me. nostalgic and timeless record.

On his first solo album, 
, he shakes off his early-century doldrums with his finest batch of songs since 
.
As the sardonic crooner fronting Britpop vets Pulp, Jarvis Cocker fused epic, wall-of-sound pop and barbed social commentary. Happily, his killer solo debut offers more of the same.¬†
There are songs here that easily stand up to any of Pulp‚Äôs high-points, and sound totally unique against the backdrop of 2006.
Fears that incipient middle age has mellowed the misanthropy of Pulp‚Äôs ex-frontman Jarvis Cocker are allayed by his solo album.

Jarvis Cocker‚Äôs solo debut is not so much a curate‚Äôs egg as a game of two halves. The first ‚Äúside‚Äù triggers a sinking sensation reminiscent of hearing Morrissey‚Äôs ‚ÄúKill Uncle‚Äù for the first time in 1991: has our hero truly lost his touch?

Like a polarizing, neurotic Elvis Costello with his fair share of musical quirks and big ideas. It's all held together and kept grounded and accessible by the amazing energy and powerful sound of this music.

Perhaps they're happily stuck in the past, but there's no denying that when they have a hook or melody -- and when they have a savvy producer like Sitek supporting them -- they deliver the retro goods.

Although the musical advance Beady Eye have made in 
 does not extend to the clumsy lyrics, Liam shows he is not just a balls-out bawler and the band sound sharp. It looks like they might be around for a while yet.

Gloriously basking in the ethereal ones before them, their debut 
 is a shoegazing twist of emotional bliss.

This is about as Post- as Britpop could possibly get. Atmospheric, dramatic, beautiful songs from one end to the other. It's an indie rock classic, to me. I don't come back to it very often but it's always a great experience when I do. Really great record.
this is so creative and emotionally potent, and yes, not everything works, but a couple of these songs are ridiculously perfect

Lush go full Br*tish, sadly. But nah this kinda threw me off at first, and it‚Äôs kinda just good, nowhere near Lush‚Äôs immaculate standards of dream pop in the past, but overall a really solid indie pop/Britpop album. I unironically think a lot of the vocals are too British for my liking, but it has some solid hooks, plus Ladykillers is an iconic feminist anthem and it really picks up towards the end

But nah this kinda threw me off at first, and it‚Äôs kinda just good, nowhere near Lush‚Äôs immaculate standards of dream pop in the past, but overall a really solid indie pop/Britpop album. Lush following the changing trends of the mid 90s without falling completely into the genre of brit pop.

My best friend had this on CD when it came out and I never really got on board with it. Listening back now, I finally get what made it so appealing. This is a charming slice of British pop, full of lovely hooks and melodies.
Essential Track - You Showed Me

If it had been released in 1991 (the year it was recorded), it would have probably taken a different course in its impact, but fortune took over and turned this album into a lost, britpop classic that's worth listening.

Their 2016 debut album concentrated largely on Oasis and their aftermath ... while this second LP broadens their scope to take in baggy, shoegaze, jangle pop and even some ill-advised bits that sound like Travis.
is so good that in 20 years the discussion about the hot new indie guitar band might well focus on how much they look and sound like DMA‚Äôs. It‚Äôs an outstanding debut.
DMA's deliver the goods with enough vitality and pure pop acumen to temper some of the criticisms that their obvious affinity for all things Oasis and Stone Roses will no doubt invoke.

As the album progresses, the two styles reach a blissful compromise that, while not quite attaining the loveliness of the Go-Betweens' past orchestral arrangements, nonetheless mesmerises. And the lyrics have lost none of their heart-stopping bite.

12 years after their latest album, they are back, thankfully in a very good mood, to remind us how good they are in creating simple but effective melodies that we long to hug and then share.
What a great band!

Go-Betweens fans should be very happy with 
 and glad the band decided to stay together and continue to make smart, exciting adult pop music.

Ultimately, I'm glad the Go-Betweens have decided to stick it out, because they're still making some great songs, but their best material is definitely behind them, on classic albums like 
 and 
.
Taking their guitar-pop stateside, they maintain their affection for melody but they also use a stronger pepper to make it more suitable.

I forgot to write a review!
The Flamingo Trigger is chaotic. Sasscore is the genre I'm trying to get a grasp on and starting my listening journey through this (almost) unexplored genre with this album is an extremely great decision. The production and writing is unhinged. The band sounds like their having a party while recording this LP. The whole vibe this radiates is artistic. I never expected to have so much fun listening to this!

The most dramatic stylistic shift by an extreme band in 2006, 
 is a mere glimpse of what this immensely talented band is capable of.

While Canada Songs was an assault the the senses, this record refines, underlines and increases the intensity and musicianship to create a truly unique and fun experience, with more memorable and interesting songs being made in the process. Its a great mathcore album that's just waiting to be explored.
Favorite Jams: Recorded Inside a Pyramid, The Fuck Whisperer, Hyperventilationsystem
Lest favorite: X-ray

Yeah, it's good. 
A lot of people say they can't stand the vocals on this one, and I completely disagree. Marshall's unique delivery sounds so human and so real. Sometimes, the best thing in the song is his vocal performance. 
I'll definitely come back to a lot of songs from here, but if I would choose the best one, it would probably be, the underrated Fuck Whisperer. It's a really good way to end this thing. Really brutal. 
Overall, it was nice. I probably should listen to the self-titled.

Earliest Sonic Youth album that doesn‚Äôt sound like a literal toilet. That is mostly for the better, but it still is more unpleasant and dissonant than their later shit (no pun intended), it just feels a lot more melodic for a no wave album and quite uniquely textured, kinda post-rocky. I really felt a lot more glad to listen to this, yet I still felt the dissonance, so it‚Äôs pretty easily their best no wave album so far

Oh god, what a fucking sound this album has!!!!! 
Certificate hood classic fr

It's hard to unpack everything that makes this album incredible. Black Eyes unique arrangement style featuring two bass guitars, two drum kits, a noise-drenched guitar, and manic vocals are delivered in an unashamedly flamboyant product with their self-titled record. An incredible fusion of sass, post-punk, noise rock, and no wave.

EDIT: I relistened to this today and it grew on me a lot. Esspecially that last song. It is like a post punk symphony 
Their artsy approach at blending the sounds of post punk with classic punk rock makes for one of the genres more interesting releases of the early 80s.

A cold, pummeling, relentless record, 
 is a quintessential side project: far more extreme and uninviting than Doom could afford to be on his solo-billed records.
Is not the best of its genre but still cool.

C'mon, i
t's a classic

I myself can't connect with this album emotionally and thematically, mostly because the whole theme of the album is a bit irrelevant for me.
But I love the sound on this album. The sounds are kinda same throughout the record but they are always almost engaging, with also using some odd time signatures and elements of math rock. (which still is a very weird and interesting genre for me)
The vocal dude is ok, still, doesn't move me but he's doing great.
Very good record as a whole.
is a stunning debut ... It seems that the phoenix from Nirvana's ashes has finally arisen here.
succeeds even when its musical resourcefulness is undermined by Flemmons‚Äô overwrought lyrics.

In a genre stacked with pathological mediocrity, 
 is a relatively sure-footed success - at worst enjoyable fluff, at best a provocative, quietly electrifying treasure.

But the instrumentation and mixing don‚Äôt often match the bold storytelling, which is strange since 
 feels like the most Rock (with a seriously capital ‚ÄúR‚Äù) LP that the Truckers have put out since
.

Meticulous and ephemeral, 
 recalls Isbell's 2013 critically acclaimed solo album 
, a solid and stolid collection of sketches that didn't turn into watercolors, of homilies whose guitar tunings were as private as prayers.¬†

Southern rock mixed with pop just makes me want to gag up the cucumber water ive been drinking today. Even when one track brings interest back ("When He's Gone"), the next track brings you right back to cringing.

Merritt's effortless songwriting ability and talent is on full display on her sixth studio album, 
.

The album is probably most similar to the scruffy, country-influenced 
, but it feels deeper and dustier, its upbeat numbers more ragged and howling, its slower ones tipping into a well of soulful melancholy that's worthy of prime Rolling Stones.

In 
, Merritt beams bedraggled and beautiful as ever, as if watering the roots she wrangled, proving roots that are uprooted, are straining as ever, for a new ground to land upon.

title: Mowing the Leaves Instead of Piling 'em Up

reviews.content:
As a one-off placeholder until Wednesday‚Äôs next full-length of original material comes out, 
 makes for a perfect spring time stop-gap.

really nice debut from a local st Catherine's artist! very well produced and arranged, her voice is beautiful, especially on the closer track. Lots of really nice indie folk-rock tunes here, with a good amount of personality in the lyrics. Really good stuff! Check it out
"It's alright
And it's okay
'Cause we all get bored
And nothing's gonna change, anyway"
Favourite Tracks: If I Knew Now, Isn't It A Pity, Queen of Spades, Why Do I Miss You, Thistle and Thorned

Some really mid lyrics and average singing masked by some nice instrumentation and catchy choruses most of the time. 
Best Track: Nobody's Nobody
Worst Track: Rollercoaster [the last thing this needed was a piano ballad]

Some moments fall flat ‚Äì Lonely is cloying, paint-by-numbers EDM-pop that doesn‚Äôt fully land. Still, 
 is a polished collection that spans both pop and rap with confidence.

South Korean rapper RM comes through with a smooth, well-produced pop rap album. Like with j-hope's album from earlier this year, I'm not going to pretend I don't like this because its associated with BTS. Also like that album, this one features contributions from some legendary names like Erykah Badu and Anderson .Paak, who RM has good chemistry with.
Favourite Tracks: Yun, Still Life*, Wild Flower

I'm not very familiar with BTS, but as far as I can tell, this is just a really good pop rap/R&B album by one of its members. The sound is smooth and polished, particularly in the more rap sections of the album, and RM has great synergy with his features. The bottom half does drop off somewhat, leaning into a softer pop vibe, but it's still good. Definitely looking forward to his next solo work.
Favorite Song: Still Life
Quite the project from the Member, best of the BTS solo projects.

Margo Price has broken free from the shackles of country music on 
, pivoting effortlessly and elegantly towards a classic rock sound.

There's a confidence in her vocal performances that reflects the album's spirit: She's comfortable following her obsessions and idiosyncrasies to their logical end, resulting in a record that comforts and challenges in equal measure.

A pleasant little country album! Though aside from a few stand-out tracks, this is less ambitious and ultimately less satisfying than her previous works. 
Top Tracks: What Happened to Our Love?, I'd Die for You
Rating: 6/10

The lyrical twang. The arrangements. The stories, all country. But there's something else in the variety pulling me in here. In places the songs lose themselves in all out rock anthems. The muddy blues-rock of Twinkle Twinkle and the electronic vibe of Heartless Mind keep it fresh and engaging.

I think my main problem with country is the lyrics. The lyrics are made for a completely demographic of people and those of a different lifestyle. And when your genre is completely based around those lyrics, it‚Äôs hard for those outside of the niche to really like it. So I think this album really suffers from that

Combs isn‚Äôt reinventing Nashville‚Äôs four-wheel clich√©s on 
; he‚Äôs merely giving it a fresh coat of wax and removing the more ostentatious add-ons. But his detail-rich songs make 
 a big-time country album with a tip-jar-worthy intimacy.
The Top Dawg Entertainment-signed rapper and singer makes her latest bold statement with this punchy and rebellious release.

title: Stories From a Rock n Roll Heart

reviews.content:
As it swivels between rock hymns like the Boss-backed New York comeback and country laments like Jukebox, it becomes a primer for newcomers, not a unified statement on a par with 2020's raw 
 or the landmark 
. Still, it is a triumph that this exists at all.

The buzz of this album may have been blunted slightly by excellent 2013 releases from Kacey Musgraves and Ashley Monroe. But while this album is a little bit more understated, the songwriting quality here is top-notch. Small-town disillusionment is even more prominent here than in those records, and Clark offers a nuanced but potent take on this theme.

Though admirable in its attempt to further flesh out Reason‚Äôs emotions, 
 would have benefited from some more risks in its instrumental palette and subject matter.

Kirke raises the bar on 
, crafting empowered, retro-leaning songs that feel like the kind of polished country-pop artists like Dolly Parton and Juice Newton excelled at in the 1980s.
Playful homages to country at its most synthetic and dancefloor-friendly ... bridge the gap that once existed between Madonna and the Mandrell Sisters.

With her second solo album, 
, she finds herself amid the brightly-polished 80s country-pop whose resurgence seems a natural reaction to buffed-up bro-country.

Love this man and his discography. Once again Paisley creates an album that perfectly blends classic folk stories of loss and love along with goofy over the top modern country. Almost poking fun at the culture while completely embracing it. There is never a dull moment as the album swings from heartbreak to laughter in an instant, but never loses impact or charm.

So, you are here to enjoy Daniel's unique suit and to cry with his classic tunes. 
Be sure, you are in the right place.
In spite of much of ‚ÄòCHARLIE‚Äô missing complexity or a distinctive flair, the album remains punchy and bright and what Puth lacks in poetry, he makes up for with glimpses of pure pop excellence.

24 > 10
I was way too easy on this thing the first time, and now having relistened to it I realize just how terrible it is. It‚Äôs the most basic pop crap you could imagine, and this time there‚Äôs no so-good-it‚Äôs-bad factor, it‚Äôs just bad. At least I can laugh at 7 Years and Strip No More, but this is just the epitome of soullessness, and I hate that these guys were ever popular.

'The Road to Here' doesn't have much of an identity other than a band making good 2000s country music. The singles are unmistakably the highlights for the most part and they do a good job in showcasing their group dynamic and musicianship. To grow from here, the road only needs to be paved with more thought-out album developments.

The dignity and sharp poetic instincts on 
 are all classic Cash.

Now I don‚Äôt know if this album will stay a 10/10 (it didn‚Äôt but I still think the whole series is a 10) but I really enjoyed this as someone who listened to the American recordings in order the process of him turning to Jesus more and more as a way of coping with wife‚Äôs death was really cool to see but hard to listen to all the same it‚Äôs hard to explain without sounding religious but this album is beautiful listen to it
very personal album for Johnny Cash, his emotion shines through each song and it is beautiful
Four albums in, this is his finest solo foray yet, remarkable for Miller‚Äôs skilfully-woven fretwork and plaintive moonlit moan.
Given that portions of the album feel like unused material from Crazy Heart, at times the album feels too much like a companion piece to the film as opposed to a true solo record.

title: If I've Only One Time Askin'

reviews.content:
Thematically 
 is a triumph, a massive step forward that finds Romano pushing himself both in terms musical and lyrical, looking to get to the booze-soaked heart of country music.

Currently listening ... back in a few.
1.5 songs in, I like what I hear (I'd actually never heard of this guy before: will have to check out his back catalog). Kind of a good ole boy who seems to be a skilled songwriter. I like his voice and his arrangements, which are both pretty classic country without any of the trite crap.
Initial rating of 80.
Their debut has the same easy charm and command of pre-rock pop as Jones' albums.

is the curious product of one man's obsession with his favorite artist, and it feels like the musical equivalent of Gus Van Sant's remake of 
: too close to the original to be a worthy reinvention, and too flawed in execution to feel like a successful homage.
The album is essentially packed-full of pleasantly put-together hooks, enjoyable melodic settings and observant if easy-to-slip-past-you lyrics.

This is pop-country, not pop pretending to be country. Maddie and Tae's debut strikes a nice balance between traditional and contemporary, and though their lyrics can sometimes betray their young ages, they are more often wise beyond their years, and their most successful songs are the ones with an edge used to make a cutting point.

This tension between the head and heart, between the country and the city, is what fuels 
, placing it on a warm, hazy plane that feels simultaneously sophisticated and down-home.
Amzingly well done classic country.

What could be a better cred-building exercise for a young indie-folk songwriter than to cover the works of Willie Nelson? Yet Matthew Houck, aka Phosphorescent, isn't interested merely in demonstrating the depths of his scholarship and reverence for the forerunners of his craft with his all-covers tribute to the Red Headed Stranger, To Willie. He wants, as Hot Chip might put it, to half nelson full nelson Willie Nelson, to wrestle intimately with the man's songs and what they're capable of communicating. In doing so, Houck proves himself an adept interpreter of Willie's piercing Christian grace, while indirectly revealing by the limitations of his scope-- the true remarkable human breadth of Nelson's artistry.

The folk rock and country legend Emmylou Harris stumbles into new territory with ‚ÄúStumble Into Grace‚Äù but doesn‚Äôt detach from her true essence. The song writing is strong here and combined with a pop finish. Don‚Äôt over look ‚ÄúCan You Here Me Now‚Äù and ‚ÄúTime In Babylon‚Äù. I wouldn‚Äôt classify this as a must hear classic in her catalogue but it does offer a few great tracks.
Essentially, it is a near perfect blend of blues and rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll of times both past and present.¬†

A soulful and bluesy record which is just oozing with southern charm. The vocals sound hoarse and drenched in whisky whilst the guitars have such a great bluesy bite.
Best Track: I Found You
Worst Track: You Ain't Alone

When you think country music you tend to think of acoustic guitars and cowboy hats and whilst country superstar Jason Aldean features both of these in his latest album Old Boots, New Dirt the multi award winning singer also brings along a new pop-rock like style which is sure to generate mixed reviews. http://renownedforsound.com/index.php/album-review-jason-aldean-old-boots-new-dirt/

The revised sound and songwriting on 
 isn‚Äôt an extreme enough alteration to alienate existing McPherson fans, but it results in his finest set yet and signals that he‚Äôs pushing boundaries and staying fresh in a business that doesn‚Äôt embrace change.

If you want to listen to a good modern rockabilly/ jukebox shit, undivided Heart & soul by JD McPherson Is perfect for you.
And it's.... Wow. It has a lot of skate 3 soundtrack vibes.
üíØ Cuz it's fucking Rocky.

The songwriting and performances on 
 pop when he integrates up-tempo and driving qualities with soft and steady vocal deliveries ... But, Outlaw closes the album similarly to its opening: quiet, subdued, and largely opposite the feelings he creates in its middle.
Leyla's meditation on Ha√Øtian heritage makes for a poignant and haunting listen. Breaking the Thermometer is an album of sadness, pain and residual wrath but, above all, acceptance and beauty.

On his sixth solo album, M. Ward turns in a star-studded set that feels at once a logical progression from 2006's 
 and a step closer to that all-out classic his preceding suggests; an assimilation and appropriation of American blues,
His latest disc could be his best yet. While it has Ward‚Äôs trademark low-key sound, the troubadour tackles multiple genres like folk, blues, rock and country.

As close to a country supergroup as we've got -- three individually very talented stars come together for a debut that's full of fun and very tongue-in-cheek, and can approach touchy subjects without getting preachy. Manages to emphasize their individual talents without any one singer upstaging the others.

With his latest album, the lefthanded, Tuareg guitarist testifies that there's still life for rock music, even if we didn't believe it!
A fine example of celebratory, saharan rock that will take us directly to the heart of Africa.
It‚Äôs an ambitious collection with its moments of excess, but overall the roots veteran pulls it off.
Not only does Undercard not disappoint ‚Äî there are more than a couple earworms here and there ‚Äî but it‚Äôs brilliant and fresh from two musicians who aren‚Äôt exactly freshmen to the scene.

Great (full) debut studio album, a dozen of years after the release still a great indie folk album without unnecessary artistic efforts. Rough and clear with the unmistakable voice of the famous British singer-songwriter (composer and musician) Benjamin John Howard from Richmond, south-west London, Every Kingdom was - after three EP's - another harbinger of great things coming.

Although simpler and arguably less inventive than his later efforts, there's a clear expression of raw talent here that's both consistently charming and sometimes stunningly gorgeous.
Favourites: The Wolves, Promise, Old Pine, Black Flies
Least Favourites: Keep Your Head Up

Great (full) debut studio album, a dozen of years after the release still a great indie folk album without unnecessary artistic efforts. Rough and clear with the unmistakable voice of the famous British singer-songwriter (composer and musician) Benjamin John Howard from Richmond, south-west London, Every Kingdom was - after three EP's - another harbinger of great things coming.

This is one of those cases when the label is given a talented promising artist but they're too young and overjoyed for being signed to have much input to make a great album. Also, the corporate morgue isn't interested in giving her a proper executive producer and too much is lost in that process but she gets a hit(!) and that changes everything. now you'll get three more that work amidst some ok moments until she gets better resources next time around.

Not as great as her second album but definitely one of the most interesting released by new country girls. Sounds too pop sometimes.
Best songs: XO, Peter Pan, Sirens, Secondhand Smoke

Grasped me a lot more then I personally thought it would. An album about self reflection, discovering his beliefs and the loss of his father. While I wasn't initially a fan of the vocal mixing, it grew on me really fast. Being someone with country roots and has experienced the loss of almost all my older relatives; this album hit quite close to home.
Fav Track(s): Elohim, By the Way, I Love you Always‚ù§Ô∏è

Norah unfortunately outshines Billie, but it's still good nonetheless. I'd like to hear them together again under Norahs more jazzy stuff. I think he'd shine there. I'm not sure why people hate this album

In contrast to the frenetic tempo of their earliest albums, this album suffers from a lack of energy which has characterised their best work. Helmed by legendary producer, Don Was, this release is much more MOR and many of the tracks are therefore largely forgettable. The two highlight tracks are the title track and the whimsical ballad ‚ÄòThe Greatest Hustler of All‚Äô.

Sometimes these archival releases come around, and it's really surprising to see how little success what's inside managed to achieve. No doubting a few tracks got touched up by Numero prior but the songwriting and compositional skill is top-notch. Way better than most classics at their time. Very charming and quite a pleasant listen, as multiple Nashville tracks are finally given their cold attention over 50 years on. Quite fascinating to hear how the more surf-rock tracks have aged.

American primitivism indebted acoustic folk with some more classical and ambient flourishes - a detailed listen, and close to symphonic in places, but strangely also one that can be put on for relaxation.
This is a discography I need to explore further.

I did not expect to love Liquid Sunshine as much as I did! This album is super creative, charming, and soulful--the first track, Hello Heavenly, was what sold it for me. The beautiful crescendo that exploded near the end came out of nowhere, and that kind of unexpected beauty was present everywhere else on the album.
For her first solo album in nearly two decades, Alison Krauss resorts to the safe solution of country covers, something that she can handle easily thanks to her huge experience.
American Idol‚Äôs best-selling act kicked off her discography with a delightful country album featuring big choruses, soaring vocals and memorable melodies.

Carrie's debut was an aim to crossover pop and country listeners, and somehow it worked. However, some songs sound repetitive, blended with uninspired lyrics or melodies, just taken by her vocals hoping that whoever is listening to it don't get tired through.
HIGHLIGHTS: Wasted, Before He Cheats and Jesus, Take the Wheel

This is a remarkable debut album that unveils one of the most powerful voices in music. The collection is filled with youthful lyrics and meticulously crafted melodies, showcasing Underwood's exceptional talent. The album stands as a testament to her vocal prowess and ability to convey emotion through her music. One standout track, "The Night Before (Life Goes On)," exemplifies the album's overall charm and adds a heartfelt touch to this impressive debut.
What a colorful and beautiful album!
This is a refreshingly honest pop record‚Äîand whether you‚Äôre a casual Kylie fan or a devoted one, it will undoubtedly make you feel much closer to her.

When Kylie stops trying too hard to sound like Dolly Parton and just concentrates on making great pop songs, 
 is a damn fine album.

Por favor fa√ßa parar...
Ele pega o que rolou de pior no pop dessa √©poca e ainda adiciona uma camada de country pelo amor de deussssss. Nada salva, s√£o 54 minutos de pura tortura.

It can be something of a clich√© to point out how much better the underground female alt-country singers are than the bro country stars, but all it takes is one listen to an album like this to see why. Angaleena Presley, the least famous of the Pistol Annies, has concocted a remarkably assured, complete, and cohesive portrayal of disillusionment of Southern life -- not as flashy as a Musgraves or a Monroe, but more understated and slow-burning. One of the best lyricists in the genre.

This album could've used some refinement to be perfect but as it stands it's enough to easily crown itself as one of the best country pop releases of the last decade. Kelsea upgraded her sound as quickly as the resources became available and she's been on a great trajectory.

Definitely one of the best Country/Pop albums of the 2010s. 7 out of 12 tracks are perfect and the other 5 are still amazing. There are no songs I don‚Äôt like off this album. Songs like I Hate Love Songs and Music had to grow on me a little bit once they hit I really liked them. There are so many amazing songs but my favorites are Graveyard, High School, and Legends.

title: Diplo Presents Thomas Wesley: Chapter 2 - Swamp Savant

reviews.content:
Never though I would hear Kodak Black on a country pop album by Diplo, and I prefer if I didn't.
Favorite Songs:
Least Favorite Songs: All of them

Nothing groundbreaking here, just an immaculately produced, exquisitely voiced, traditional album that hearkens back to the pre-countrypolitan Nashville era. Some calypso/indie folk touches make the sound more diverse and palatable to 21st century ears.

Aoife O'Donovan sounds like a breath of fresh air. Her album encompasses comforting and familiar singer-songwriter folk, while subtly experimenting and pushing herself (and her genre) forward. I could see some dismissing this as too low-key, but O'Donovan is too specific and skilled as a songwriter for this album to be boring.

His first solo album, it's important to have in mind he was not acquainted with work by himself. Here we can see his evident inspiration in singers like Justin Timberlake, but it was not yet the time.
Best song: What Can I Do?

SUBSTANTIALLY better than Lorraine, this is easily one of the best country albums of the 2010‚Äôs with its incredibly heartfelt and robust songwriting, and charming instrumentation.
Standout: Giving up on your hometown
Favs: The Bird & The Rifle, We were cool, If whiskey were a woman, Always want you, Halfway home, Wreck you
Least fav: All these things

The record oddly parallels another album of the year frontrunner, Vince Staples‚Äô 
. The stories are divided by thousands of miles and musical motifs, but both artists brook no bullshit, as concise as they are vivid.

Isbell‚Äôs increasing skill as a storyteller, and the natural affinity he has for melody, combine to make 
 a masterful piece of work.

Navigating between crestfallen country ballads and rollicking rockers, 
 showcases Isbell‚Äôs musical diversity without sacrificing a pinch of lyrical precision.

makes clear 
 was no fluke; the insights Isbell gained as a songwriter are just as evident on these 11 songs, and as a performer he's attained a nuanced maturity that demonstrates how far he's come since his days with the Drive-By Truckers.

, retains 
's intimate acoustic-based feel and heavyhearted lyrical matter, but it's even more smooth-edged and lacks the emotional gut-punches of its predecessor.

title: Micah P Hinson and the Nothing

reviews.content: Hinson‚Äôs tales work in context of the music that soundtracks them. And in this case, his tales of being temporarily crippled are strengthened by its tone-perfect instrumental base.

If you ever ask me which member represents Brown Eyed Girls better in their solo career, I'll SCREAM "GAIN". For a group known for its "adult image", the singer fits its concept perfectly, and made history with her "controversial" themes. "Hawwah", however, isn't that glamourous. Consider it as a compilation of possible B-sides from a BEG album.

title: The Greatest Gift Mixtape ‚Äì Outtakes, Remixes & Demos from Carrie & Lowell

reviews.content:
The album is certainly a must-have for Sufjan Stevens fans and provides background insight for those interested in the evolution of the exceptional 
 recording.

Though too scattered to stand alone, the various demos and remixes culled from 
 add new context and dimension to Sufjan Stevens‚Äô masterful album.

may not contain all the insight and manifest artistry of one of Stevens‚Äôs studio albums, at the very least, it reasserts his perspicacious understanding of his complex emotions and propensity for self-evaluation.

Not as good as the original material but a wonderful companion piece that is beautiful in its own right. The original tracks are also fantastic.
Essential Track - Wallowa Lake Monster

Ignoring a few demos is actually a dream bubble electronic ballad, Wallowa Lake Monster's magnificent arrangement and epic three-minute outro are really beautiful, and the new Exploding Whale's dreamy drum arrangement is also great
beautiful stranger trapped in 2012

This EP makes me smile lol. It have a nice mix of attitude and genuine reflection. 
Only G-Dragon has the balls to sample Daft Punk. It's Veridis Quo, too. That's how you know he's a real fan lol. 
 If you need some pop rap songs that are a blast to listen to with great production, here you go.

Purple Beck is one of these rookies you just WANT them to succeed - but they never help us with that. No matter how much I cheer for them, knowing of what they can do, their agency will never let them release something that'll make the group unique in any way. "Starry Night" is not necessarily a bad release, the intro track is good enough, but the cheap synth vibes in "VALENTi" and Mr. Krabs' smallest violin (and piano) in "Tearful" are just... Tearful? Yeah.

A solo kpop album, the second this week, and even tho this is upbeat it's mostly a weak attempt at being creative, its totally generic and mostly sang in english, which makes it kinda awkward, totally forgettable

Ah, yes... The sweet moment your personality is having silly looks. JI JIN SEOK's "Half&Half" won't really tell you much about the R&B singer, but definitely will show you some of his musical traits. Consider this just a cute EP to try out without thinking too much.

MAMAMOO is, alongside LOONA, my favourite kpop girl group, because I think they sound incredibly unique in almost everything they do... My problem with this EP, is that it lacks of originality, literally sounds like every other kpop girl group, so yep, not a big fan of this one.
Least faves:
- Self Camera
- AAH OOP!
- a little bit

This EP really lacks a defining theme or sound, and proves that no amount of vocal ability can save a truly mid song.
Freakin Shoes // 42
Um Oh Ah Yeh // 66
A Little Bit // 78
No No No // 60
Self Camera // 71
Ahh Oop! // 83

Ap√≥s mais de um ano de hiato por causa do alistamento militar, exo volta com um √≥timo comeback, com uma title track √≥tima, e 4 excelentes e bem feitas b-sides n√£o decepcionando os f√£s que ficaram por tanto tempo esperando um comeback do grupo.
Don't fight the feeling - 8.2/10
Paradise - 8.7/10
No matter - 9.3/10
Runaway - 9.5/10
Just as usual - 7.7/10
Final score: 86/100
A capacidade da BoA de carregar tanto seus trabalhos dance pop e os seus projetos r&b com seu vocal carismatico me assusta.

Piano Man was kind of a banger but Gentleman was a bit more of a flop. The vocals were great and the title was a catchy song as a whole. A very short mini album, but still solid. 
<3 Piano Man

This release basically proves that NCT has one of the best vocal lines out there.
Imo one of the best releases in 2023 when it comes to Kpop. Even tho I'm really satisfied with "Perfume" as a title track I'd probably still go with "Kiss" as my favorite song here. The only miss on here is "Ordinary" imo. 
If ur into Taemins or Kais music you'll probably fw this as well.
The album was a decent-sounding one with its cute and fun-sounding Korean pop songs.

Not very good as a whole. Mostly just boring R&B, but not done particularly well. They‚Äôre good vocalists and the Hwa Sa solo was decent, but I just didn‚Äôt like it. 
<3 Mr. Ambiguous, I Do Me

Brilhante e intimista, com composi√ß√µes delicadas que s√£o um descanso para os ouvidos em um mundo cheio de ru√≠dos ca√≥ticos, a voz de Yerin ajuda a compor a atmosfera on√≠rica do √°lbum se mesclando com o instrumental de uma maneira bel√≠ssima.

Yerin Baek is a talented singer and songwriter (and producer), but her style of music just always bores me half to death. Everything here sounded mostly the same and I genuinely felt like I could fall asleep at any moment. I like listening to her music because it is objectively really good, but I don‚Äôt actually enjoy any of it. 
<3 Maybe It‚Äôs Not Our Fault, Dear My Blue, Our Love Is Great

Um √°lbum de uma vasta produ√ß√£o art√≠stica, com letras profundas e vocais no ponto. Gostei de como "1719" foi passeando entre os ritmos de um s√≥ estilo, mesmo sem perder a coes√£o. √â incr√≠vel ver mais uma faceta de um idol desvenda quando se lan√ßa um projeto solo com uma maior liberdade art√≠stica, podendo ser para melhor ou pior, mas Yeeun faz isso com uma maestria invej√°vel.
For a pretty generic and commercial genre that is EDM, this album is pretty solid
a fun and lighthearted album that showcases Ugly God's unique sense of humor and catchy beats. Tracks like "Water" and "Bitch!" are definitely standouts.
Uma boa introdu√ß√£o ao trabalho solo do artista.
, with its use of melody and subtle production, is by far 21‚Äôs best mixtape so far.

With Metro becoming an architect for what‚Äôs trending in Hip Hop today matched with 21‚Äôs raw rhymes that attract more new listeners, 
 is on course to be one of the best underground releases of 2016.

Finished my First Listen. The production from Metro and the performance from 21 Savage was great on the first 3 tracks but the rest was pretty forgettable for me due to 21's lack of catchy hooks & the production just being less interesting but there's something to build on.
Favs: X, No heart, No advance

10cm: *called 10cm*
I'll tell ya: It could have been worse. From the most basic folk pop style to the most generic french-ish ballad, 10cm's "2.0" is just another boring guitar hangout at the beach. Emotionless enough to be heartful, and misleading enough to have an album cover with a cis woman taking off her clothes and silly songs like "Red Dragonfly", the world forces me to approach this album as a boomer's doing.

A few years ago, between the Pistol Annies and her debut solo album, Angaleena Presley delivered a one-two punch of working class solidarity and Southern religious devotion. This is what makes her long awaited followup such a disappointment. 
 lacks ambition.

Nicely done and subtly written country/Americana album. I was worried after reading the Exclaim review that I'd have heard this all before, but while Angaleena's themes are similar to those of her debut, it's a testament to her songwriting -- which is among the best in the genre -- that she makes the words and melodies sound so fresh.

One of the records I listened to the most in my teenage years. Revisiting it recently, I was expecting it to have aged badly, which was not the case, surprisingly! 
The more melodic vein suits the band immensely (I dare say it's Danny Worsnop's best performance as a vocalist), and despite some songs that I don't really care about like Poison and Until The End, it's a pretty solid album.

While the no-bullshit lyrics and get-in, get-out nature of 
 work to make the band‚Äôs politics perfectly clear (at 47 minutes, it‚Äôs a contender for DBT‚Äôs shortest LP), it still has unique lyrical details that separate it from other protest music, even protest music of the loud and pissed-off variety.

Every time DBT releases a new album, I tune in, and remember why I don't ever re-listen to their songs. I'm down with the lyrical content, but I can't get past how boring the overall experience is. Maybe next time.
is stunning for its intimacy, its lack of studio artifice, its warmth and its timeless, if hard won, songcraft.

The way Welch and Rawlings have assimilated the old songs and embody classic ballad singing, you‚Äôd think the material was written back in the 30s. The only giveaway is a lack of surface scratches. There‚Äôs no need to highlight any song, each one is equally exquisite.
The Harrow & The Harvest is simply one of the richest, most expansive roots albums to be released in some time.

It's a rich portrait, full of unexpected imagery and odd turns of phrase, which means that even though Welch has sung about drunks and prodigals so many times in the past, the songs on 
 sound both pleasingly familiar and starkly new.
Brilliant debut from a brilliant band. The title track really stands out. Would recommend for a beginner metalcore fan.
Minus the soft moments, great melodic punk-metalcore
No doubt. A classic album, the best of the Led Zeppelin self titiled albums. Immigrant song is a top 10 rock song on its own right. Amazing.
It's more intimate and accessible than its predecessor, focused on the textures of everyday life and the odd, stirring power of Mitchell's voice.
The album is a sleek and shiny blast and one that should be the perfect soundtrack to these dog days of summer.
‚ÄòSongs For The General Public‚Äô is in turns bewildering and heartbreaking, a potent pop statement and a dizzyingly bizarre melodic belch.
is shining example of how the musical old school can combine with modern sensibilities.

For those so inclined, 
 is a giddy musical roller coaster ride through the poppier aspects of the 70s with more twists and turns perhaps than are necessary. Hang on tight and enjoy the trip.

The 12-song album is a metaphoric, eclectic house of mirrors, inside of which every song reminds of a different prominent musical act as if the listener is seeing themselves in some distorted reflection.
Each song recalls the essence of a specific segment of '70s pop excellence, with just enough bizarre twists thrown in to keep things interesting.

If shiny, overstated hooks and operatic melodies are your thing, stick on the Twigs‚Äô latest LP right away and you‚Äôll have a ruddy glorious time. But for many, 
 will be an overwhelming, even frustrating listen.
The ideas in ‚ÄòSongs For The General Public‚Äô are rich, creative and often funny, but its musical staying power is lacking.

Despite 
‚Äôs classical forays into tragedy and depression, 
 somehow presents itself as more cynical and contemplative.

the long island brothers present some glam rock tunes. the music is so many genres, yet it‚Äôs also genre defiant. it is typically overextended and sorta cheesy; although, it do be boppin (listen to ‚Äúonly a fool‚Äù).

At their best, and that is emphatically here on 
, the Old 97's are the very definition of that thing we like to call alt-country: country music washed in melodic pop played by a bunch of punks.¬†

If this leans more to rock & roll than Texas honky tonk, it still sounds like classic Old 97's, and
 shows these guys can commendably hold up their rowdy side while making the kind of elemental Lone Star music that still makes them a kick to hear.¬†

The back cover‚Äôs somewhat clich√©d advice of ‚ÄúPlay this album loud,‚Äù should be heeded for maximum enjoyment of a rollicking set that nearly two decades in, stands as some of the Old 97‚Äôs finest and most exhilarating music.

The sheer musicality of 
 is something to be in awe of, let alone the inspired messages of female empowerment and the in-depth analysis of relationship culture. It‚Äôs a classic high-quality, well-arranged and passionate album from First Aid Kit, but this time ‚Äì it‚Äôs not so innocent.
Drawing on a range of classic influences and captured expertly on record, ‚ÄòRuins‚Äô cements First Aid Kit‚Äôs place in the Americana songbook.

Fans of 
 will find a familiar bright, assertive sound, with Klara and Johanna's trademark tandem vocals bringing a certain air of resiliency to an unexpectedly lively set of songs.

Though a few missteps keep 
 from being First Aid Kit's best album, it's still packed with well-written, well-performed, and well-produced folk pop songs.

The follow-up to 2014‚Äôs major-label breakthrough 
, 
 tweaks rather than overhauls Klara and Johanna S√∂derberg‚Äôs brand of pop-savvy Americana ‚Äì yet the trademark harmonic couplings and rolling romantic surges can‚Äôt disguise a troubled undertow.

While not their best, 
 certainly stands as First Aid Kit‚Äôs most cohesive album, focused on the determination of moving forward from heartbreak.

It‚Äôs also still impossible to knock the fluttering vocals between the sisters. That‚Äôs still golden ... But that can‚Äôt stop 
 from sounding like a failed copy of previously delightful pastiche.
Despite, First Aid Kit taking a more safe approach to this record, at some aspects the folk duo crafted some well-written and pleasant indie folk tunes.
certified girlfailure classic

The companion piece in essence to their previous album, this features all the laid back tracks which didn‚Äôt make the playlist of ‚ÄòToo Much Guitar‚Äô, but other tracks are more garage soul versions of some that did make it. Neko Case hasn't produced a disappointing solo venture yet, and between 
 and 
, her recent production is the strongest of her increasingly beautiful catalog.

M Ward and Garth Hudson, members of Giant Sand, Los Lobos and Calexico are all present and correct on

still stands out as another strong entry from a woman who is more than proving her mettle as a revered indie veteran.

It‚Äôs tempting to conflate the fact 
 is less outre than her last couple of sets with the fact it last week cracked the US top three, but there‚Äôs nothing particularly sell out-ish about it, and certainly with her lyrical gifts and that incredible voice still firmly intact, it‚Äôs hard to even really be that disappointed.

Neko Case's "Middle Cyclone" shouldn't be praised solely for being "Fox Confessor Brings the Flood"'s successor, but for being its own alternative country treasure. Cunningham is pitch perfect on this time travel expedition to the post C-86 era. a bit slicker and synthier than others still practicing this sound, like Strawberry Whiplash, Bubblegum Lemonade, and the other bands on Matinee Recordings, but an honest take on a fading sound.

Whoosh sounds like Australian indie meets Wes Anderson, which makes for some fun tunes, but also makes for a lot of muted repetition. To the point I actually thought the same song was put on here twice. The beginning and the end are where The Stroppies actually have some tracks that will make me remember them and their weird name as something original, but the middle slags and brings down the record as a whole for me. Hopefully these guys only improve going forward.

Hastings post-punk four-piece Kid Kapichi prove the accuracy behind BBC Radio 1‚Äôs description of them as ‚Äúa force‚Äù with their highly anticipated debut record 
, which combines conflicting emotions and catchy soundscapes without skipping over the nuances of their individual personalities.

It's a prosperous time for post-punk and Kid Kapichi are just the latest band on the wagon, thankfully it's a great sound, with purpose.
This is one of the more similar attempts to IDLES i've heard since Joy took off in 2018, albeit with some crushing riffs which sound amazing particularly on the opener.
It's a good album, just the 4th best Post-Punk album i've heard this year and we're only 5 weeks in.

Kid Kapichi's debut album is a success. It's not something we never heard but it's a recipe that works : a fuzzy voice, a heavy bassline, catchy choruses, loud drums and effective melodies. A very good rock record.

title: You Can Get There From Here

reviews.content:
For Rays to refine their sound like they did and come up with something classic-leaning and still full of spark and life was a more impressive feat, and fans of old-school, non-twee indie pop really owe it to themselves to seek out 
.

A sort of 
 for a new generation, 
 finds Portner going back-to-basics, taking listeners on a psychedelic but steady trip over 15 tracks with atmospheric and shifting samples ("Lunch Out of Order" Pt. 1 and 2), 
-style guitar work ("Jackson 5," "PJ" and opener "Season High") and spaced-out instrumentation (the twisted "Boat Race" and lo-fi drone of "Dr aw one").

There are a few too many noodling sound collages across its 15 tracks, but at its peak ‚Äì on the delicate, maudlin Ms Secret or the chirpingly melodic Jackson 5 ‚Äì 
 reminds you of what made Tare and his bandmates such a thrillingly different prospect in the first place.

He‚Äôs revisiting some of the most fertile soil of his past work - bringing together his childlike enthusiasm with his penchant for gloomy undercurrents - and making it all sound as fresh and blissful as ever. It‚Äôs undoubtedly Avey‚Äôs best solo work to date

stands unexpectedly far apart from much of Avey Tare‚Äôs solo output, dialing in his usual unhinged zaniness for a calm, collected stream of songs that flirt with accessibility without sacrificing their loose, dispersed sense of assemblage.

Recorded with Animal Collective part-timer Josh Dibb, Avey Tare‚Äôs 
 could never be accused of pandering‚Äîno album as slack and rickety as this has sights on the masses‚Äîyet in some ways it embodies a romantic ideal that‚Äôs nearly as sure-fire as 
‚Äôs imagining of a perfect pop album: the reclusive, personal record, written seemingly with no expectation that anybody will even hear it.

Calls back on some of the childlike and eclectic acoustic ideas of some of Animal Collective's early work with a blend of soundscapes and movements that swell and morph into stunning highs and remind of the emotional lows felt on Down There.

As it progresses,

Pretty but not boring, eclectic but not overindulgent,

The problem isn't with 
's expansive instrumental palette, but with the way that the record struggles to use its sounds to captivate, often letting each part float away into the ether ‚Äî including Gibson's voice.
is built on indulgence: a gratuitous, unpredictable experience that sometimes leaves the listener on the outside of an in-joke.

The band‚Äôs unique mix of Turkish Psych, retro-futurism and Pet Sounds style guitars, 
 is a riot from start to finish.

Every second of 
, the debut album from instrumental quartet Los Bitchos, is unconventional, rule-breaking, and mind-bending.

It feels very intercontinental post-mod and present, and universal. From the funky ‚Äô60s flavor of ‚ÄúLas Panteras‚Äù to the quasi-prog rock of closer ‚ÄúLindsey Goes to Mykonos‚Äù the whole shebang is very well-rendered and highly entertaining.
They take a playful, feel-good approach to their creations, which consistently feature circular, danceable grooves.

This album is fun to listen to with its funky and psychedelic instrumentation, but it is kind of forgettable, especially because it doesn't have any lyrics. There are some great instrumental albums that keep you entertained until the end and leave you wanting more, but this album doesn't do that. It is instead just a fun experience, nothing more and nothing less.

UK surf rock outfit's fifth record is a melodic take on variety of musical styles with an unhurried orchestration composed of percussion beats, playful basses and jangly guitars that would launch instantly summer feels and nostalgia. Indie pop at its most catchy and undeniable charm.

It's complex music delivered with ease, and although the duo's preoccupation with clean sound and self-consciously sophisticated arrangements would eventually lead to a dead end, 
 is a shining example of jazz-rock at its finest.
The strength of this album, and the 14 that precede it, is the immense healing and soothing found in the sheer beauty of Amos‚Äô vocal delivery.

Like the best of Amos‚Äô work over the past 20 years, what makes 
 exceptional is its complexity: songs are laid out like puzzles, ready for the subjectivity of the listener, with no obvious interpretations.

One of pop‚Äôs most inventive composers returns with a braid of political, maternal, and celestial statements. On 
, Amos‚Äô intricately arranged songs are passionate and despairingly poetic.
is not one of Tori‚Äôs sexier albums, nor is it as playful as she‚Äôs demonstrated herself capable of being. But it‚Äôs strong and unwavering in its commitment to being muse-driven and unafraid.
After unrepentant geraldines tanked this perfect album comes out

What. This is unlike anything I expected with onkyo. Alongside the sinewaves and unique improvised textures onkyo is known for, you'll find pummeling drum rhythms, aquatic synth melodies and samples from symphony orchestras to god knows fucking what. Confusing, unsettling and batshit-crazy, but strangely exhilirating. I call this phenomenon the "Otomo Yoshihide effect".

Free Jazz on top of bird sounds and field recordings - not going to be for everyone, in fact most people. But there is something charming about this especially as someone who loves birds. Might be a good project to induce focus on a different task.

title: Grind Madness at the BBC: The Earache Peel Sessions

reviews.content: John Peel's sessions were instrumental in bringing Earache Records and the English grindcore scene to the masses. This compilation features 8 of these sessions, from the earliest bands on the label - namely, Napalm Death, Extreme Noise Terror, Carcass, and Bolt Thrower, among others. Of course, the material on these sessions are far from new, so if you're a fan, you would have probably heard most of it by now, but this compilation is still a decent way of holding all of them in one place.

Portico Quartet are an instrumental music ensemble from the UK, but nothing about them sounds overtly English. Their sound is comprised of saxophone and auxiliary percussion matched to a conventional rhythm section, yet they are not jazz. Their new album Isla comes to us courtesy of Peter Gabriel‚Äôs Real World label, yet any implications of this being considered ‚Äúworld music‚Äù feels too broad, generic, and undermining. Isla is also produced by John Leckie, but it has nothing to do with Public Image Ltd., XTC, or the Stone Roses. So just who in the name of warm lager and Abbey Road studios are these guys, and what exactly is their style?

Despite the fact that John Leckie at Abbey Road produced it, this is jazz first and foremost, and there are segments of wild improv sure to turn off fearful jazzophobes. For less sensitive ears, though, this is a rich, rewarding, thought-provoking listen.
boldly showcases an unconventional combination of instruments and melodic ideas, a revolutionary musical terrain that Portico Quartet will hopefully continue to explore.

The silvery ring of the hang may be the Portico Quartet‚Äôs trademark sound, but in the end what lingers is the expressive playing of saxophonist Jack Wyllie, the graceful melodic hooks, and a general air of antique melancholy ‚Äì leavened on a track like Clipper with something more rough and energetic.

title: It's OK To Listen To The Gray Voice

reviews.content: Easily a favorite project from saxophonist and composer Jan Garbarek along with Wayfarer, ECM essentials. Now, he's able to develop further that style making it even more his own than on Wayfarer.

Beautiful work, absolutely will continue to keep coming back to this.
