title: The Child Septentrion Danced for Two Days

reviews.content:
oh hello
freak folk/raw black metal/dark ambient that sounds like it was recorded on location by the enigmatic red person on the cover
Songs dip and dive in and out of focus, smothered in a swooping filter one minute, breaking into glorious groove or melodic joy the next, like changing channels on the fly.

The reliance on the squeaky clean quickly becomes 
‚Äôs undoing. For every moment of greatness the listener is met with two or three tracks of airy paisley pop.

Do ya know cybergrind? It's a cool genre blending extreme metal and extreme techno with mindbending results.
Fire-Toolz is at the forefront of this genre, with her avant-garde approach to music and edgy style. At times vaporwave, at times grindcore infused electronica, this album never chases to amaze and puncture my neurons with unexpected ideas.

With the arrival of Winter, this double-album ‚Äì which is how it will no doubt be categorised in the future ‚Äì stands proudly as a whole, thoroughly complete work. It‚Äôs unified, enterprising, and truly progressive for the group.

Sure, it would have been better if Weezer leaned into these strengths, instead of adding wanky prog breakdowns and unnecessarily fussy rhythmic shifts. But they're a nice reminder that Cuomo hasn't lost his knack for golden melodies.

These days there are plenty of ABM-Bands, that sound the same. That's why I'm looking for albums, which set themself apart from this particular sound. What makes this record special, is the amount of memorable riffs. As usual great acoustic guitar passages and great influence from bands like Caladan Brood is obvious. The only major downside are the vocals imo, because they are almost completely buried underneath the rest. But I feel like in this gerne, you can get away with that.
Absolutely wonderful atmospheric black metal with a heavy use of melodic passages and a strong character. You rarely see atmoblack albums of such high caliber.

One of the best albums from this genre I‚Äôve ever heard. The thick as tar atmosphere and its heavy texture makes this one of the best records I‚Äôve heard that tries to portray this anxious end of the world feeling. It‚Äôs balanced with very beautiful and well put together post rock passages that make the next drop feel even more heavy and powerful
is a startlingly unique addition to the band's catalog, and the most dynamic and interesting album that Aaron Turner has ever created.
The result is a bracing expression of visceral emotions that refuses to go the easiest, most comforting route, as well as the most focused Sumac album yet.
Subtle and accomplished, this is mood music perfect for a rainy night -- real or imagined.
If Christian Death makes raw black metal

Get past the goofiness of those Al Pacino moments, and what we‚Äôre left with is one of the strongest hard rock albums of the year. 
 bursts with energy and charisma, from the catchy anthems to the brooding, depressive numbers.
I'm torn between this being catchy and really annoying & artificial.
While I think there were rlly catchy moments, they faded quite fast

Their latest incarnation is no less intense, and no less fiery. When blackened death metal is delivered this good, there‚Äôs no need to reinvent the wheel ‚Äî just raise your horns and bang your head.

From the beginning you can feel the combination of melodeath and melodic BM. The vocals, use of cymbal and blast beats sound very much like black metal, but the guitar tone and clearer production point towards melodeath. The sound is similar to THRON, but the sound is richer and more dynamic. I really like blackened singing and the guitar style of melodic death, so naturally this album would be great. Fast, catchy and most importantly well mixed music.
Very well performed and unique sounding! Great structure and cohesion

A band that deserves more recognition as time goes along, however a few tracks have a repetitive, backing orchestral that never sounded dynamic enough to make them distinct. I would say these guys are insanely talented beasts that I would love to hear more what they could do in the future.

Here is my favorite side of Black Metal. Its ambiance, tone, the way the guitar and drums are used, the success of brutal vocal form a perfect whole. Angry, stirring and dark. It is a complete concept with the harmony of the Anarchy, Revolution, Anti-fascism themes used in the lyrics with the album cover used.

The Finnish artist Jaakko Eino Kalevi's "Chaos Magic" album is a competent yet uninspired addition to the psychedelic pop genre. While Kalevi's songwriting is still elegant and his production is stylish, the album lacks the surprise factor needed to truly stand out and feels far to familiar. 
Despite its pleasant melodies and minimalist textures, "Chaos Magic" fails to leave a lasting impression and ultimately feels like a rehash of a rehash. - Samuel Garuba

I've never been a fan of Akon's music, but this project kind of took me by surprise. It's a really enjoyable pop rap album with some super catchy hooks and surprisingly conscious lyrics. I was honestly really surprised that such an introspective and lyrical album came from an artist who I previously associated with mindless party rap. It's definitely nothing amazing, but it was a ton of fun to listen to and it left me smiling when it was over.

It doesn‚Äôt feel as radically fresh and inventive as his earlier work, but the tradeoff is the high level of craft and confidence that Lidell brings to the proceedings.¬†
errs on the side of caution with its inherent love affair with Prince but remains playful and original in almost every other respect, which is what makes it such a cohesive and enjoyable listen.

An unbroken set of slickly-produced pop tracks, 
 feels as though the Beck-assisted soul vocalist from 
 woke up in the '80s, corrupted by Stock Aitken Waterman.
is rich and inventive because the producer has the technical chops to bring a far-fetched idea into fruition.¬†
At its strongest, though, ‚ÄòJamie Lidell‚Äô triumphs in offering an exciting mixture of layered synths and artfully manipulated samples.

‚Äòs success lies in this warped musical schizophrenia, which pays homage to a litany of influences but doesn‚Äôt shy away from its electronic roots, allowing Lidell to craft the finest and most coherent account of his vocal and musical talents to date.¬†

Everything that makes Lidell unique is buried under a fog of spot-the-reference touchstones, a predictable pop funk pastiche that points towards the obvious forerunners but doesn't do much to expand on the form.

One of my top 50 favorite records ever made and easily one of the best live albums by a solo act ever! More musical collage madness from Asleep Country! It's uneasy and feels hand stitched. The sheer scope of it is excitingly mystical. Three hours of music where nothing makes logical sense. It forces you to feel the music. The dizzying and in your face clutter of sounds. It forces you to stop thinking by dumping you in this mess of broken and fragmented things - not asking you to piece it together, but to accept it as it is.

Despite its lengthy runtime, this album has managed to be constantly engaging with its chaotic, beautiful collection of sound. Whether you listen to this in batch or in it's entirety, I highly obliged you to listen to this.
Am I a sucker for musically simple and elegant musicals with moments of complex emotional portrayals? Absolutely.
Great feel-good musical

I'm not going to set a rating, or a proper review for this recommendation, and here's why:
I thank Josh for showing me this musical, and giving me time in my day for experiencing it. It's truly a great story. However, I feel like with musicals, you have to be there in order to fully experience it, or even critique it. It seems unfair to walk into a musical without seeing it and giving it a full grade.

Mega Man X4 Sound Collection is a must-have for any Mega Man X fan. 
This comprehensive audio collection features every sound effect, music track, and voice clip from the classic game Mega Man X4. The sound quality is exceptional, with each note and sound crisp and clear.

Solid power metal here on Sonata Arctica's debut. Vocals are clean and intelligible, nice melodies, good guitar riffs. It isn't anything special by power metal standards however, so I can really only recommend it to people who enjoy the genre.

This album denotes a great passion for power metal and also a great level of professionalism to be the first material that this band released to the market. With a melody present that always grabs you, incredible vocals, easily discernible lyrics and a typical great instrumentalization of any song in this genre, without a doubt this is an album that deserves a lot of recognition on the part of any average rock fanatic.

Although there are good riffs to be found here occasionally, the majority of "Undisputed Attitude" is characterized by obnoxious, painfully on the nose lyricism, ugly vocal performances, terrible production and mixing and a dated, stale hardcore punk sound that makes Slayer feel decrepit and long past their heyday. Unless you're a hardcore Slayer fan, I'd say skip this one.

From Chaos is a solid 311 record. It's got a better mix of heavy and relaxing, and overall is more focused than it's predecessors. It's still kinda formulaic in the end, but the stellar singles make up for that. Especially the euphoric Amber.

For as dated as the band's songwriting is (and how their albums covers look), they're doing pretty alright with what they've got. The production's pretty nice with a good sense of rawness and I like the sprinkles of doom metal put on the album's more thrash metal focus. The lyrics are pretty simple, which can be charming on some songs. I just feel like they haven't gone anywhere since their last record, so the score will therefore be the same.

title: Grip It! On That Other Level

reviews.content: Not too unique soundwise but only shit is this great. All three members are great rappers, especially Scarface. Yes the album is edgy as fuck and that might put some people off but that's what I love about this. Mind of a Lunatic is an especially great track.

So they hadn't developed their own sound yet, having just added Scarface to the band, but their bars are still fantastic. The LP also features several famous classic rock and disco/funk samples that were uncleared and not legally used; so, we got "Geto Boys", a remix album of these, next. 'Scarface' is one of their best.

Their breakout album that sold well enough that, you may have picked it up in the store circa 2002 thinking it's southern rap only to find out it's Christian rap with a very clunky aughts production sound that may feel dated almost 20 years later. If you want better production and conscious/christian content hear their album, Factors Of The Seven, a more jazzy boom bap endeavor that has more of a Gospel feel as opposed to the Dollar Tree brand knockoff-Neptunes production on this record.
Is it wrong that I prefer this to Nick Cave's solo and Bad Seeds material?!

Thematically and content wise, reminiscent of earlier acts (Public Enemy namely) and later (Little Brother), the storytelling and bars are examples of success at more ambitious songwriting. They cover a lot of ground and do so immaculately never sounding out-of-depth or in over their heads. The tight theming uses excellent devices to convey its weighty but not convoluted messages, heavily relying on the 'media''s response to the socio-political ideas touched on.

Michael Franti and Rono Tse's latest project finds them experimenting with hip hop beats, industrial noise and a sharp, political speech, trying to set up West Coast's resistance to the huge expansion of the Bomb Squad.

is a sequel to recent modern classical composition 
 and is similarly pleasant if sometimes syrupy.

Even on the quieter, reflexive and refined 
 they play to emotion first and head second, with stirring vocal surges and gentle, string-led swells that Charles Stepney would have been proud of.

The five-track instrumental 
 follows on from 
, which was surprise-released back in April, and conjures anxiety and paranoia through orchestral soundscapes.

¬†is another sumptuous classical effort, essentially functioning as a sequel or companion piece and at 5 tracks and 25 minutes it presents a more focused, leaner and less indulgent collection than its predecessor.

This is what Deerhoof do best: write incredible hooks, then shake them around, put them in a blender with a load of raw energy and a dash of 'who-gives-a fuck', then see what comes out.

Even on these songs, it feels more like Deerhoof are coming full circle than looking back; that they've been able to put different but cohesive spins on their sound so well, and for so long, is truly remarkable.

The best moments on 
 evoke the inventiveness of Deerhoof's classic albums and their ability to explore seemingly limitless possibilities within their own (admittedly unique) framework.

A lovely bookend to last year's incredible Remember Your North Star. Some surprising house-inspired detours here (which land very well) but my personal standout is "on the pisces moon" which is textbook Yaya: homespun, sweet, warm and vulnerable. Highly recommend this to anyone else who loved her album last year ‚Äî it's a very short EP so it's super digestible!

There is a case to be made for 
, the debut album by serpentwithfeet, to be sensibly understood as seminal before even being granted the benefit of hindsight. It‚Äôs incredibly rare that a creative talent of this magnitude arrives at all. It‚Äòs astounding that they would also succeed in presenting a vision of such striking lucidity across their first major work.

With 
, serpentwithfeet deeply engages with the complex membranes between the self and a loved one, the self and the world. Few albums attempt this much nuance in articulating love; Wise‚Äôs success in his ambitions feels like a gift.

It's this need to share so much of himself -- with his listeners as well as the ones he loves -- that makes Serpentwithfeet's music so compelling, and 
 captures a passionate, complex artist coming into his own.

is an album that delves into the dirt of passion, be that artistic, romantic or religious. For every moment of ecstatic energy there‚Äôs another equal moment of debilitating disappointment, for every igniting of love, there‚Äôs wilting relationships. It‚Äôs a deeply personal album, but one that is often relatable.

Since his 2016 EP, 
, Wise has evolved from histrionic oversharer to keen songwriter with a sharp wit. On his debut album, 
, those qualities bloom on tightly written pop songs that probe his innermost fears, neuroses, queer insecurities and desires.

Now I love this record. I listened to it all the time when it came out and kind of fell off of it for a while, but every time I revisit, I'm thoroughly impressed by the song concepts and excellent vocal control.

Kelsey Lu's EP is a fascinating exploration of negative space. She has a beautiful voice that pairs well with her smooth cello playing. The entire EP was recorded live in a Brooklyn Church, which helps build the atmosphere of this work. I like that she unafraid of winding vocal lines, I hear elements of Bjork in the way she stretches out notes to draw out their maximum emotional potential. I love the experimentation, and I cannot wait to hear what she does with a studio album!
listening after blood, stunning
Full of 90s and 00s nostalgia, from Destiny‚Äôs Child to Caf√© del Mar, the Danish artist‚Äôs second album boasts witty lyrics, outlandish soundscapes and beautiful pop melodies.

Erika de Casier comes off as someone who has a vast musical lexicon and the taste to use it in the most effective manner. She is an amazing songwriter, a tremendous producer and full of substance and smarts.
Whether down to Erika‚Äôs understated vocal, or the shallow pool from which many of the musical textures come, things do elsewhere get a little samey. A shame, as ‚ÄòSensational‚Äô starts so bright.

The rhythm and acoustic texture of singing in a calm atmosphere make listeners feel calm and comfortable. It's an album that's so relaxed and comfortable for listeners. Listening to songs like "Busy" makes it natural that she worked with New Jeans.

Eclectic and eccentric rootsy spiritual jazz, widely diverse and exploratory; but also disjointed and uneven. The vocal can get a little grating at times as well
Standouts: Sometimes I Forget How Summer Looks on You, Aunt Lola and the Quail, Mestre Candeia's Denim Hat, I Be Loving Me Some Of You, Slightly Before The Dawn, S‚ÄôPhisticated Lady, We Gon Win
Dropouts: I Once Carried A Blossom

I had the fortune of seeing Ben LaMar Gay at this year's Berlin Jazzfest so I can't but help noticing the stark difference between the recording and the live set. Live the band was extremely tight and direct, it was funky and in your face. On the record, many of the songs I first hear live seem overpolished and some of the hooks have been over-extended into some type of orchestral pop. It's still a brilliant record, but I just wish he'd choose someone else to produce the next one.

Avant-garde jazz outfit Onyx Collective continues to embody the highs and lows of NYC with 
, their most polished and straightforward set of tracks yet.
Swinscoe and Smith have produced a powerful and polished record, cementing their esteemed position in alternative British music.
is a worthy return for The Cinematic Orchestra, developing their sound while keeping the trademark fusion between electronic and orchestral that Swinscoe and co. do so well.

The Cinematic Orchestra just doing what The Cinematic Orchestra have been doing for the past decade: making gorgeous swirling musical patterns. This LP is jazzier than some of their earlier work that I am familiar with but maintains the beauty of that earlier work.
Essential track - To Believe

The Cinematic Orchestra just doing what The Cinematic Orchestra have been doing for the past decade: making gorgeous swirling musical patterns. This LP is jazzier than some of their earlier work that I am familiar with but maintains the beauty of that earlier work.
Essential track - To Believe

is the work of a few seasoned dance gurus in full flight. The Brothers utilize all the weapons in their arsenal, from infectious pop joints and hypnotic ravers to the A-list cameo appearances, but there‚Äôs extra oomph behind these 11 tracks.

The latest from the U.K. duo hits harder and lower than their last album, 2010's 
, with guest-vocal turns from artists as varied as Q-Tip and St. Vincent over tracks that could've torched an outdoor rave in 1995.

The Brothers put more features in their music with the likes of Q-Tip, St. Vincent, Beck, and more. All of them perform so well.
They do what they are best known for doing: making unique electronic dance music with catchy hooks. They show no sign of grinding their creativity to a halt, making their best album since Push The Button.
Favorite: Under Neon Lights
Least Favorite: I‚Äôll See You There

The precise beauty of their production work, specifically the refusal to dump gratuitous instruments into the mix, places 
 at the top of Ratatat‚Äôs catalogue. Stroud and Mast let guitars beat at the album‚Äôs heart, and their balance of bubbly and peaceful elements ushers a return too fluid to ignore.

Ratatat are musical marmite ‚Äì they‚Äôre too experimental and abrasive not to be. And whilst I don‚Äôt think this LP is going to do that much to change that, as a lover of both Ratatat and their yeast extract counterpart; I think their latest offering 
 is just that.

Some criticize Ratatat for sticking too closely to their stock in trade of electric guitar hooks, psychedelic synthesizer loops and plush beats. The Brooklyn instrumental duo‚Äôs fifth album ‚Äì their first in five years ‚Äì stays true to the formula while also bringing a fresh tone and mood.¬†
drags a bit, as can often be the case with instrumental tracks centred on repetitive patterns, but it demonstrates the band‚Äôs commitment to their oddball signature style.

All the way through, 
 feels fresh and, more importantly, refreshing.

If the shaky performance of his debut was a wipeout‚Äîto mix a metaphor‚Äî
 sticks the landing, sustaining over its running time without stumbling and occasionally providing some thrilling moments.

Thoroughly enjoyable, albeit a little too long, collection of electro-jazz tunes from Moritz Von Oswald, Heinrich K√∂bberling, and Laurel Halo. The album plays to all of their respective strengths and seamlessly ties them together. As a whole the album pushes the boundaries of jazz and its fusion with electronic music, making for a surprising and thrilling listen
, isn‚Äôt just ‚Äô80s posturing; the musical idiosyncrasies and thematic shifts propel this album rapidly past the expected and the easy.
acts not as one large sonic blur, but eleven unique tracks that stand well on their own but are ultimately united by the albums production qualities and dreamy agenda.

boasts some of the best dance music of the year, thanks to McCandless' exact yet poignant vocal delivery, the band's proficiency at bending and layering synths and the sonic cohesion provided by long-time collaborator/producer Dan Lissvik.
Young Galaxy have made a body of work that is as thoughtfully passionate and lyrical as it is mechanically perfect.
has great work on it, but not a cohesive balance to carry on that power down the road.
This shit is catchy it made me want to make a dnd campaign so i can use these songs for it

This album is cool. The most notable songs are Black Water (because of Tear Along the Dotted Line on Netflix and I've always loved the incorporation of that song) and the following track, Goodbye (Breaking Bad and Netflix's "Dark"). I liked Black Water more.
But overall, this album doesn't touch those songs.

Brain juices go brrrrrrr, I like this, some good ol brain tickle music, apparat got some interesting apparatus for affecting me, and it works, this is a certified hood classic of an album, the run from Goodbye to the end of the tracklist is sooo big

Bursting immediately at its seams with the serrated dual guitar blast of "Yellow Number Three" and "Built in Girls"' steam-engine roar, 
 welcomes with a warm immediacy rare in even the most revered pop treasures, and a density whose every layer hides another secret synth melody, jagged hook or vocal harmony. The depth of realization in this record is unparalleled: every angle is perfected.

Chock-full of meticulously put-together songs, spanning a range from angry, restrained punkish attitude to pure down-in-the-dumps loveliness, the Wrens fill out their music superlatively, and use contrasting space with perfect expertise.

It's possible that 
 might be a "better" album if it were more focused and logical, but there's something to be said for its immersive, stream-of-consciousness approach.
A stunning return filled with irresistible pop of all varieties ... Note to major labels: you missed a gem.

Interesting how some complained about the mixing, I thought the mixing was just fine and complimented the raw feel of the album. The tag is right, this album definetly has an emo flair to many of these songs. Overall it is a really tight indie rock album with a strong tracklist with good variation. Despite being released in the 00s, much of this album sounds like a by product of the 90s, mostly in a good way though.

[Genre: Bass]
That was cool... I guess. Basically, if you've heard one song from this, you've heard the entire 54 minute album. I can't say I'll ever come back to this to be honest.
favourite tracks: 3dOS
least favourite: Rocendal
Summary: Tbh this sounds like something Toasterqueen12 would give a 3-4/10
There are literally only TWO albums on this whole site with the genre Bass, plus they both have the Techno genre tag so I'll safely assume this is just going to be techno music.

What 
 lacks in boundary-pushing experimentalism, it makes up for in wildly energetic and danceable electronic jams.

These four tracks may cry out for proper soundsystems and bear many of dance music‚Äôs hallmarks, but their lengths (they add up to nearly half an hour), discordant layering and meandering structures render them more suited to body listening than the dancefloor.

Bob Moses has definitely stayed true to themselves with this latest LP, but much to my boredom. When first discovering Bob Moses, their sound was fresh and fascinating, but after 4 straight albums of relatively little-to-no mixups, they have become a derivative of themselves. That being said, the tracks are still pretty solid and production is clean. I was just hoping for some more evolution in their sound.
Favourite: Love Brand New
Least: Broken Belief

Mild, electronic beats that may be fun and creative at times, but not nearly as compelling as they try hard to be. Few moments on this debut deserve a comeback, despite the playful and otherworldly palette of sounds thrown around the album's runtime.

Chill and catchy
There's not too much to this EP, just 3 pretty great electronic/rnb crossover tracks. I really like this thing for its simplicity, and lo-fi aesthetics. Chet Faker's vocals sound great over these Flume beats. I don't love the last song quite as much as the first 2, but still, this is just a short set of bops I'd recommend everyone hear.
Favorite Tracks: Drop the Game, What About Us
Least Favorite Track: This Song is Not About a Girl

Yall remember this classic
Honestly it‚Äôs quite good you know
sounds like it could have been snatched from the late ‚Äò60s, veneered of course by Bundick‚Äôs characteristic knack for pop melody and production.

is an ultimately perplexing collection of songs ‚Äî a mishmash of Bundick‚Äôs best and worst musical ideas, but nevertheless a glimpse into an artist who is unafraid to shift into new sonic territory.¬†
is a bright, sunny chunk of laid-back indie pop; it's Bundick's heaviest use of organic instruments, and it's the best thing he's done in a few years.
is about as successful a transplant as he can make into a fresh setting.

Take this album for what it is: A retro look on classic psych rock and pop from the golden age of those respected genres. Sure, Toro Y Moi doesn't try to reinvent the wheel with this album, but nonetheless, it is a distinct and catchy record on all cylinders. This effort has to be respected. Much different from any of his previous work, it doesn't feel forced or awkward. Toro Y Moi stepped out of his comfort zone and into another comfort zone.
The songs fade into each other, often making it difficult to observe a track change, with certain lyrics or melody choices ringing true
Spencer's best solo record. 10 years later and it's still nigh perfect.
It is so beautiful that it takes my breath away

If you like the new slowthai album ugly this is perfect for you. Mourn is an ambitious and extremely depressive project by Corbin. Everything on this album makes me sad. The vocal performance is raw and sometimes this rawest of the vocals adds depressing feelings with lyrics that are great in terms of dark poetry and storytelling. Production is varied and polished, I like how this album can balance Coldwave instrumentation with some Emo Rap aesthetics.
This is by far my favorite album of all time. Every song gives you raw emotion while also pleasing the mind with the eerie atmosphere they present.
The production on this is utterly immaculate. It's about an hour of EDM-infused emo trap bangers that is utterly cohesive and has no lulls in it. Don't miss out on this.

Great album, great remix, great representation of this genre
Best Track: Project 100

as infected mushroom gets this feels like the a beautiful combination of their strange artistic twist on the psytrance genre. my ears really liked this one :) 
[TOP 3]
- Herbert the Pervert - 
- Poquito Mas - 
- Saeed -

They pretty much hit the nail on the head with this one: plenty of variety, tight songwriting, and impeccable vibes. Only real complaint to see here is that I feel like it could have been a bit shorter.
A solid EP, but it's mainly a production focused tracklist with very few replayable songs

The cover is good, the music don't. Just feels like a bunch of hard techno stuff mixed it together and deliver an awful performance, yeah it is pretty danceable but not so good to be replayed again tbh.

Genre defining masterpiece. This is the first Psytrance album i've heard and it's the one that got me into the genre as a whole. Amazing groundbreaking production combined with hypnotic drums and one of the funnest album experiences you'll ever get.

The fact that every single track here runs at full throttle and features a very creative and demented use of sampling (even the croaks of frogs make their way into the aptly named "Frog Machine") makes for one of the most entertaining IM albums.

This album actually surprised me quite a bit. It's not inventive at all but there's some pretty decent trap bangers on this. The whole project has a good vibe while it's on, and it would make for great background party music. The constant "thanks Ugly God!" ad-libs over every track get obnoxious pretty quick though.

One Two
Jaguar
What's Up?
Hold Up

Hello

Back to the Basics
Hahaha!

it‚Äôs not bad for a debut. namasenda shows she may have potential, but she only actually starts to use it on her most recent singles. 
hot_babe_93 lacks a good production and originality, yet it‚Äôs a very danceable album and has some decent hyperpop songs
fav song: here
least fav: donuts

Brilliant album I'm so happy I discovered recently. Ravenna has been intriguing me with her newer singles but I wasn't aware she had a complete body of work out and it's a brilliant, dark, vibey pop record with amazing often trap based production and good songwriting. Great stuff!
funky
assumes an endless pallet of instrumental exploration while still remaining easily digestible.
O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs voice is beautiful and his songwriting often adventurous, but there are times when the aim isn‚Äôt as true as it could be.¬†

This one surprised me. I don't know what I was expecting, but it wasn't this. While it isn't an incredibly exciting release, it is ambitious, melodious, and enticing. It does have a lot of lyrical trip-ups, it seems, as sometimes a strange lyric will tear you away from the soundscape itself. However, that aside, this is a playful folk album taking cues from both Bon Iver and tUnE-yArDs. If weird folk is your thing, give this thing a spin. It might surprise you too.
The latest batch of sonic terror heralds more than just reminiscing by numbers, the band have clearly explored and expanded their tastes and ideas for what this new LP should be.

Like every Pissed Jeans album before it, 
 is a unique balancing act of dumb and smart, as nimble as it is brash.
rocks in the perverse way only Pissed Jeans can, and like past releases, it‚Äôs a slab of flank steak in an indie world rife with tenderized veal.¬†

Vicious, raucous, and one hell of a good time, Honeys is exactly what I expected after hearing "Bathroom Laughter". One of the best indie punk releases of the year so far. So much fun, I may have pissed my jeans. Oh wait. Yep. Definitely did.
The songs so consistently mine the same material that it starts feeling like a portrait of our era as a deeply sad one, where lost souls abound.
"Me and the Devil" is an epic song, haunting and unforgettable.

Really surprised this album has not gotten more attention, it is sort of a dark horse right now. This is a really sophisticated, difficult record, a natural fusion of atonal eastern music with European folk songwriting. The musicians here are an unlikely trio but absolutely brilliant in the way they feed off of each other. Check it out.

An inventive way of uniting her body of work, 
 furthers her legacy as a promoter of peace and understanding.

She continues in this spirit with 
, albeit without the all star backing this time around, opting instead for a stripped back, almost lo-fi approach.
This time their brutality became accessible and the intense guitar riffs ruled the entire territory, asking us to sit and wait until the last breath of Edkins words.
He takes care to meticulously strike the perfect balance between dark and contemplative versus downright depressing.
is a wild flower that self-seeds and grows tall alone. The cadences of the phrase also suit Shirley Collins in the present, and there is confident calmness in her ninth solo album in 61 years.
is beautifully rendered, presenting Collins‚Äô voice in reverent focus amid acoustic guitars, mandolin, and the occasional fiddle.

The Freebandz rhymer uses 
 as a precursor, another opportunity to get his intoxicating melodies in the forefront of hip hop heads' collective sonic pallet.

Dababy remixes some classics like Caroline by amin√© and Bad and boujee by migos. It's a pleasant listen considering it's his first baby talk, but there are no creative or very melodic flows like modern baby uses. He also uses the worst rapper tag on every single song "that ain't da baby, that's my baby"

Focusing on tracks from their 2012 album 
, Segall's band keep things relatively tight in structure and loose in delivery, giving listeners a keepsake version of a gritty, sweaty, earsplitting rock show.

goes a long way towards validating all the attention I&W have been getting; it's their best, most diverse and listenable record yet as Beam and co. take another leap away from the lo-fi one dude in a bedroom beginnings of the group.
is Iron & Wine's most diverse and progressive album yet, a deft transition to a very different sound that explores new territory while preserving the best aspects of Beam's earlier recordings.
is the most successful merger yet of Beam‚Äôs meticulously constructed songs with adventurous arrangements that move further and enthusiastically away from the band‚Äôs pious beginnings.

Beam invests each track of 
 with a unique tone and a singular, even gimmicky arrangement.

Edit: 89 -> 98
Effortlessly creative, flawlessly executed, passionately crafted, and beautifully composed. In my opinion, maybe the greatest folk album of all time, only held back from the acclaim it deserves by its experimental nature. For me, a distinctly American flavor of nostalgia incarnate. At the crossroads between his early acoustic work and his later forays into more complex material, Beam has created a true masterpiece.

What 
 and now 
 demonstrate is that, within Moore‚Äôs modus operandi and musical idiolect, there is still space for dynamic progression.

Refining the sound of last year‚Äôs sprawling 
 into more focused riffs and songs, 
 suggests a renewed dialogue between Moore‚Äôs experimental instincts and his desire to rock.

Not likely to rank among my favorite Thurston Moore records ever, but far from his weakest effort. Pretty solid material and sound harkoning back to late 80's Youth, but not too much, he also keeps it pretty fresh and current.
It's almost like this album aims to be music in its purest form; dry and intimate vocals, raw and stripped instrumentals, effortless ambiance, poetic yet direct lyrics. What a beautiful piece of art.
I wouldn‚Äôt have expected Jon Hopkins production to work well with folk but after hearing the pairing it makes perfect sense.
My dads favorite album of all time and this is emotionally the most important album to me. Ever. Beautiful to every last note. King Creosotes magnum opus and exceptional work by Jon Hopkins.

A beautiful album. It‚Äôs top-heavy as all the best songs are the first 4, but it‚Äôs an album with a consistent chill vibes & stunning production. An easy listen beginning to end.
Favorite song: Bats in the Attic - one of the best folk songs I‚Äôve heard in a very long time.

An enjoyable project from WWPJ, a lot more catchy and interesting songs than previous album
Favourite Songs: I Keep It Composed, Disconnecting, A Part Of It

Six years ago, folk singer-songwriter Patty Griffin released her best album to date, 
. Her new one, 
, might top that stunning achievement.
successfully recaptures Griffin‚Äôs acoustic roots in haunting and moving fashion.

I can¬¥t count the goose bumps these songs give me.
A classic of soul searching stripped down Americana. 
For me as perfect as Lucinda Williams¬¥ Car Wheels on a Gravel Road.
Try Ohio for a start and never mind the genre this is music in it¬¥s best sense

Patty Griffin continues her streak of releasing some of the best Americana in existence by hitting all the right spots to induce nostalgia, hope, hurt, and a million other emotions. The instrumentation is classic, the lyrics are certainly Patty, and the final product is fascinatingly good. Sweet, but with a world-wise edge.
With her new album, Diane has greatly improved her ability to write about familial and relationship tension in a manner that‚Äôs simultaneously unique to her and comfortingly familiar to us.
This album takes the understate melodies of its predecessor and pushes them into any and every logical musical path they could go down.

Mount Moriah's debt to Dolly Parton is apparent from the get go. This is a good thing, as Dolly Parton is one of the best performers and songwriting voices in country music. This similarity especially helps "Younger Days" to stand out as a rapturously beautiful track, and the rest are nearly just as good. For fans of Americana and classic country, this is sure to be a favorite of the year. It's a solid album, through and through.
Gloriously Sloppy. It taps into something unique and valuable, interested to see what Dinosaur Jr. type adventures this band will get as they have the potential to age like fine wine

A nice blend of indie rock and noise rock, but with a modern post-punk vocal style at times, similar to bands like Drug Church. The guitar work on this album is fun and energetic, but can also be sinister at times... I also love some of the clever lyrics, like "I'm getting high to the music, losers do it, there's nothing to it."
dirty three drummer Jim "white", used to be nick cave's tour band, instrumental folk

This album's got some pretty fun moments. Overall it is a pretty by the books indie rock record with a few shinings of something more. I don't really see myself actively returning to it, but it's pretty good while it's on.

A fun indie pop/dance record which maintains consistent quality throughout. A great run at the beginning outweighs a slightly underwhelming conclusion, however I certainly wouldn‚Äôt say the ending songs are bad by any means. Big hit Trojans and also If So, as well as dance-tinged Back Seat are r√©al stand outs here.
Favs: If So, Trojans, Back Seat, Don‚Äôt Make a Scene
Worst: All These Girls, Through the Glass
is beautiful and subtly splintered and cathartic in an honestly incomplete way. And it is, finally, that rare kind of album: one worth getting close to.
Slowly making my way through her discography. This one is beautiful
Traditional folk album with shining vocals and beautiful imaged lyrics
If these songs are any indication, things will stay as gloriously sad as ever, but gain some sonic strength and polish.

It‚Äôs still pretty dark, but this isn‚Äôt weepy music, unlike some previous recordings; it‚Äôs well-rounded and welcoming, which is possibly attributed to the band sharing songwriting duties with Hutchison for the first time.
Never too far from what you might expect from the band, yet presented in an emotionally and sonically cohesive way that makes the songs here come off as unnecessarily simplified.
It‚Äôs a perfect adjustment, allowing them to explore the carefree college rock nostalgia that their debut hinted at.
It's fairly good if you liked their 2010 album the year prior. It's nothing groundbreaking but it can leave fans with something a little extra until their later work.
A bit inconsistent,some tracks are indie by numbers.I'm sure they'll make a great album one day but this isn't it.Not bad for a first effort though.

This is both incredibly underground and incredibly fun! With under 200 monthly listeners on Spotify (excuse me?!), the Indie fusion is pulled off flawlessly, however I give it more of a Folk vibe overall, no issues there at all. The vocal combinations, the musicality, all of the album brings a ton of feelgood and melancholic emotions without going overboard in either. I fully expect these guys to blow up soon, if they don't, I'll happily roost on this until it turns to a diamond.

This album starts off sounding a little... chipper. Of course that soon changes and becomes a formulaic Eels album, beautiful sad and a little depressing, just like the excellent artwork.
Still a fantastic band.
Essential Track - Of Unsent Letters

Pleasantly surprised by this underrated record. I feel like if these guys came out with this in the 90's they would have been huge. A fun record that feels like a coastal holiday with its indie surf punk sound.
Best Track: All I Wanna Do
Worst Track: Strange Fruit
SPLASHH's debut is one of the essential albums of the surf punk genre

Early 2010s indie obsession with the west coast culminates in a jubilant shark album with a good sense of humor and vibes. Like Vampire Weekend and Animal Collective if they were a part of the Wavves/Best Coast scene. Ahead of their time in getting cancelled too.

Early 2010s indie obsession with the west coast culminates in a jubilant shark album with a good sense of humor and vibes. Like Vampire Weekend and Animal Collective if they were a part of the Wavves/Best Coast scene. Ahead of their time in getting cancelled too.

quality alt country indie folk type crossover with a fantastic first half. the second half really falters though, very boring.
best tracks: northwestern skies, get on the road, point me at lost lands, dead american writers, held in the arms of your words, pieces
worst track: i am a landslide
Even though several of these tracks got kind of stale this dude can play acoustic damn well, and the highlights like Chinese Translation were super engaging
Some days just call for a nice slice of 2000s indie folk.

I love this record. It's bluesy, off the wall and incredibly soulful. The vocals sound classic and bluesy whilst the guitars feel fresh with a modern edge.
Best Track: My Children, My Angels
Worst Track: You Lie
One of his best, a perfect record and very underrated.

This doesn't blow me out of the water, but I do find it a consistently fun record. It has a little New Wave vibe in it I like. They write catchy songs, and I also love the color gradient on the cover. That fuschia gives me life.

This doesn't blow me out of the water, but I do find it a consistently fun record. It has a little New Wave vibe in it I like. They write catchy songs, and I also love the color gradient on the cover. That fuschia gives me life.

title: I Love You Like a Brother

reviews.content:
Her debut album, 
, is chock-full of catchy tunes, clever wordplay and guitar riffs galore. It‚Äôs the kind of record that sounds classic and fresh at the same time, with a high-energy pulse that‚Äôs made for bouncing around a club.

is a remarkably focused set of sing-along choruses, punk-pop dynamics, and casually witty observations about relationships. If it never quite matches the breathlessness of that first impression, it confirms the 24-year-old music-degree dropout belongs on her globe-trotting trajectory.

A really fun pop-punk record, filled to the brim with personality, tongue-in-cheek humor and relentless energy. I just had so much fun listening through this album.
Highlights: Everyday's The Weekend, I Love You Like A Brother, I Haven't Been Taking Care of Myself, I Want U

is a powerful album, raw in its unflinching honesty, experimental in its lyrical and instrumental balances, and deeply moving in its frank exploration of all that Ansell and Carter have made it through to reach this point.

, quite candidly, is a virtually perfect record. There‚Äôs nothing about it that‚Äôs out of place. It draws on the best parts of the band‚Äôs past history, catchy choruses, glam-rock guitars, electronic riffs that don‚Äôt leave your mind for days, mind-blowing lyrics ‚Äì all combined with a glamour that lurks at the edge of the hometown you escaped, as the sun slowly sets.

Fate, it would seem, has led the band into new and interesting avenues that makes 
 positively pulsate with a pop nous not previously notably present.
is an exceptional album.
Lacking the punch of the earlier albums. Just a very average indie rock album
Lacking the punch of the earlier albums. Just a very average indie rock album

title: The Master's Bedroom Is Worth Spending a Night In

reviews.content: A top Thee Oh Sees record for me, just a fun brusk walk through diy psych pop revival. Its a prevalent late 00's vibe, perfected here.
The strong, 90s diva-ish mood suits Clarkson‚Äôs belting vocal style, as she ushers in a more soulful phase with class.

Rating an album everyday 88 / 365 
Pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed the album. Heat and Move you are in my top songs by Kelly and I think the RnB, Soul vibe the album brings suits her voice. I hope she continues this type of genre in future projects.

Even 5 years after its release, this EP stands as a high watermark for Korean R&B. DEAN‚Äôs vocal melodies throughout this are an absolute treat, and the production is consistently fresh and dazzling. It‚Äôs not a groundbreaking release by any means, but DEAN demonstrates a mastery of his craft on this EP that elevates it beyond almost anything else I‚Äôve heard in this genre.
Favorites: Pour Up, D (Half Moon), I Love It

Right in direct competition with trot music, South Korea's R&B segment, while close to being eaten by the k-pop hype, it's not fully absorbed yet, and amazing artists still hold the genre tight with close arms. DEAN's "130 Mood : TRBL" is the perfect solution for those struggling with Hollywood's spotlights focusing solely on troublemaking artists. "What 2 Do (feat. Crush & Jeff Bernat)" is one of my favorite tracks of all-time in the genre, no joke.
This album is the best that DEAN can offer. The production is flawless and solid. Literally has no bad songs on it. I recommend to everyone that likes k-pop to give this album a chance.

By no means a feel-good record, 
 is rich with enough black humor, sharp perspectives and tight muscular music to make it one of the best rock albums of the year.

Mclusky‚Äôs first two records were antidotes to everything twee about indie rock in the early ‚Äô00s. Packed with biliousness and hilariously over-the-top spite, they were manna to a particular milieu: the male cynic, the angry and backwardly rockist, and the people too irony-damaged to get with the program. I hear Christgau tut-tutting as I write this paragraph. I imagine him looking up at the positive rating and shaking his head. Goddamn that guy.

No single frontman in indie quite possesses Falkous‚Äôs unique blend of obnoxious charisma, and that fact alone makes 
 a sometimes engaging listen, but he‚Äôs still made an album that steers dangerously close to emulating the bros he‚Äôs spent his entire career railing against.
perfect late night sad boi hours music
This was actually pretty enjoyable imo. Good songwriting, a couple of standout tracks with some alright replay value, good indie rock sound.

title: A Walk with Love and Death

reviews.content:
There's a very good Melvins album leading off 
, but the rest of it is only going to agree with a tiny numbers of fans, though it could make an effective musical backdrop for your next Halloween spook house.

I'm going to sorely miss Caleb's voice, but Gloom's first album with Stephen Brodsky might be the one of the easiest entry points into the band's catalog thus far. Still sludgy and abstract as ever, but not without its own unique flavor.

OMG never disappoints.
This album took me a while to win me over. 
This listen is a bit of a journey the way the album is structured.
Positives- each song is unique and different not what I was expecting.

i have that cassette, it's pretty cool!
Climbing up the walls demo sounds like kinda stuff you'd hear playing during a sex scene in a movie
Someone help this guy is the best song on here by far
fav: True love waits (both loops), someone help this guy..., Motion Picture soundtrack demo, climbing up the walls (sexy version), No surprises (soundcheck somewhere), thom acoustic guitar as microphone
displays the continuation of these experiments, but in a much more focused and fruitful direction.
You‚Äôll find records this year of greater agency, but you‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find one that renders pleasure with such poignant lightness, control, and willful attention to difference.

Although it isn't as radical a change as some might claim, this is the sound of an invigorated band, breathing new life into traditional rock and pop structures and pushing those boundaries as they do it.
more 2/3 minute psych pop gems from these prolific folks. Not my favorite album from them, but they are one of my favorites. Always loved "Back to the Stone" & "Impossible Sky"

An uncompromising state-of-the-nation address from Datblygu. New album 
 confirms them as an important and revitalised musical force.
It's a treasure trove of Britpop and English musical history, a veritable panoply of musical goodness.¬†
may lack an apostrophe but there‚Äôs nothing missing from his musical grammar. He‚Äôs still in his prime as a musician.

In modern terms we can‚Äôt really call 
 a 'masterpiece.' That would be hyperbole, it‚Äôs a phrase we need to keep in reserve so it doesn‚Äôt wear out, but in the classic sense this is yet another worthy piece from an undeniable master.

The willful, harmonious collisions of history and the future give 
 its kick, while the warm thrum of the grooves gives it its soul.

Weller's 12th solo album is a robust binding of the experimental tangents on 2008's 
 and 2012's 
 into taut, acid-flecked turbulence and modern-dance synthesis.
Twelfth solo album ‚ÄòSaturns Pattern‚Äô backs up recent promises of another shift in sound, sending him into uncharted, acid-spiked waters.

Just a classic sound by Full of Hell, this time in a split with Gasp. There is drone and dirty sludge metal with somber atmosphere mixed with noisy guitars. But that's known and trite and doesn't bring anything fresh if you look on past FoH albums.
https://rateyourmusic.com/release/album/full-of-hell-gasp/full-of-hell-gasp/
is a very impressive rock LP that easily takes Polizze and Purling Hiss to another level and bears comparison to the best of the nation‚Äôs numerous indie rock luminaries.

While Purling Hiss may not being purveying unchartered territory on the musical map, it‚Äôs refreshing to see a band that can put out a very good rock record, one that is not mired by pretentiousness or a desire to do whatever it takes to cash in for popularity.¬†
Love this dirty lo-fi vibe. Interesting voice
The album ends up being a testament to what Presley has learned in terms of home recording: It's his best-sounding and most easily accessible album to date.
With the overall fuzz and lo-fi sheen that, at times, adds cherubic consonance to his vocal, Presley‚Äôs sonically vintage considerations compensate for the album‚Äôs lack of cohesion.¬†

A forgotten gem from a one-and-done band that was more of a layover between members' more notable groups like There Were Wires and Doomriders. Basically it's just a really solid sludge record that paces itself well between some gritty sounding ragers and doomy instrumentals. Worth your time if any of this sounds like your bag.

Ian Brown's solo work is pretty fine, Quite a few solid tracks here and memorable ones too such as "Stellify" and "In the year 2525". Solid beats, nothing amazingly special but still, tis fine tis fine.
Although the lyrical quips might be the best part of An Argument With Myself, the music on some of the tracks is close to Lekman‚Äôs finest work to date.
There‚Äôs no one big overarching idea, no head-explodingly poptastic lead single, no clutch of earworm choruses, no absurdist swinging from texture to texture.

Bubbling, female pop with a touch of melancholy.
Sweet and ephemeral.
So many classic Jens songs here....such a pity the samples weren't legal and it had to be adapted.

As they move closer to the middle ground, Saint Etienne are far from re-inventing the wheel, but in writing delectable pop hooks about a place as decidely uncool as the home counties, that was never really the point.
Thematically the album's tight and the catchy hooks and danceable rhythms drip with just the right amount of psychedelic dance-pop sweetness.

Saint Etienne never identified as Britpop, and fair enough. But with 
, they give us a glimpse of what cutting-edge ‚Äô90s pop could have become if it had evolved into adult music with a more earthbound point of view.
has much to offer in the way their greatest records always have-infectious hits, interesting soundscapes, nods to musical history, all under the sprawling umbrella of pop.
Throughout it all, Sarah Cracknell‚Äôs voice ‚Äì coolly observational with a hint of gossip ‚Äì remains a uniquely beautiful sound in British pop.

The band relocated to the outskirts of London where the air is clean and life is easy and made a cool soundtrack for the welcome garden-party: carefree, pop tunes that would satisfy the whole community of Sweet Arcadia.
It's absolutely incomplete the best of, but it had acoustic versions of songs that have accompanied me since I was a teenager and I remember them fondly.

is a worldly, global, and harmonious 43 minutes. Marela's fascination lies with sound manipulation and digital music creation tools, techniques (like vocal looping) she employs throughout the album to deepen her already full sound.
Almost a decade after their latest album, the american band sounds as british as ever, which is not necessarily bad and suggests an ultramarine tone to its lovable nostalgia, which is also not bad.

Take Souls at Zero, throw even more tribal elements in there, throw even more badass riffage in there, and make it a little more evil.
Neurosis sharpened those classic sludge metal roots with every album, and this is one of the staples in their "golden era". It's a monster.

Of Monsters and Men use 
 to reject the expectation that they‚Äôre nothing more than a ‚Äúmade-for-radio‚Äù indie folk band, and based on these results I‚Äôd tend to agree with them. This could be the group‚Äôs strongest offering to date, and it‚Äôs a noticeable few steps outside of their comfort zone.

With 
, Of Monsters and Men took a chance and rediscovered their creativity, embarking in a colorful and bold direction without sacrificing their heart and soul in the process.
is evident of OMAM‚Äôs artistic growth, as the music features their unique fairytale fantasy narrative, but it is expressed through a more matured sound.

Surprisingly, "Soothsayer" ends 
 on a strong send-off, but it isn't enough to save the album. The steady tempo, faint piano and striking guitar make this one of the unique tracks. It only gives hope that Of Monsters and Men can find a more experimental avenue next time.

Understandably, Of Monsters and Men desire to break through as more than a (admittedly sizable) blip on the musical radar of the 2010s. Suffice it to say 
 will fail to accomplish this, though its decent musicianship should allow them at least another chance to try again in the 2020s.

It's really sad how this band has fallen apart. From a somewhat unique sound, Of Monsters and Men is now a mediocre and middle-of-the-road group.
Strong 4
They took a turn that I hated. Went on a pop journey and ruined what they're good at. Sadly, compared to the first two, this album is frankly laughable.
Sunflower Bean have once again created an album that is unique and fresh, while still keeping to a tradition that evokes some of the greatest achievements is modern music history.
The focus is always on the smart, economical, classically constructed songs, boasting memorable verses, catchy choruses, intriguing lyrics and peppered with tremendous instrumental breaks.

Everything on 
 fits together perfectly; from the songs to the sounds to the performances, it's indie rock and pop at their thoughtful, searching, sweet, and punchy best.

A well-rounded and ultimately engaging listen, 
 is (hopefully) just the start of the line for Sunflower Bean as they look to develop into one of this generation's most interesting and chameleonic indie rock acts.
Sunflower Bean may struggle to maintain that glam rock posture, but they sure have gotten better at writing wholesome power pop songs.

Drifting guitars, a sweet singing harmonization and old-school pop tempos is exposed on Twentytwo at its best of its own. There are out many projects with the same vibe and it would be loose it as going on the time. But this particular release has its uniqueness that makes a big difference among others.
FAVS: Burn It, Twentytwo, Memoria, Puppet Strings, Only a Moment, Human For
LEAST FAV: Crisis Fest

to think this is from 2011 is surprising because it sounds super refreshing. this is my first project with sky and i think it was great and positive. this is like Lorde but underrated and no one knows who this is. everything is embarrassing is on repeated for days. ghost is absolutely amazing as well.

people my find not cohesive but I love how each song goes from different directions. she‚Äôs acing every one of them and it shows how open is her inspiration and her versatility to produce and pull out such different tracks.

A nice introduction to Chevelle (thanks again Mace!), every track has something to offer, and nothing feels like a filler, even if there's no real standout points. It's a solid project where everything sounds great and cohesive overall.
is a beautiful stroke of orchestrated music, a three dimensional portrait of an ever-questioning soul, which goes out with a graceful, trickster smile.

takes a hazy trip down memory lane, though its overarching strengths could also be its main downfall - that the record often feels like a pastiche of so many musical genres and influences - mainly drawing on the intoxicating sounds of Sixties and Seventies psychedelia.

On 
, her solo debut, Hilton turns her gaze to a renewable kind of death: that of our morphing identities.
While Deschanel‚Äôs songwriting is classically strong, the performances spot-on, and the arrangements undeniably impressive, She and Him don‚Äôt offer much of an update to this classic sound.¬†
The third chapter in She & Him‚Äôs discography won‚Äôt convert those who dislike the genre and it won‚Äôt alienate fans of it either.¬†

If She & Him are hellbent in playing nostalgia to the genres and styles of the ‚Äò50s and ‚Äò60s, well, there is more than enough raw material for them to sift through that can keep their albums sounding different and relevant.¬†

Nice indie-pop/folk-pop album which profits from its perfect length of 14 songs, thus being not too long and not too short. Also the production is uplifting which I really like. The vocal performance is also good with nice melodies across the 14 songs, but sadly the album slowly decreases in quality towards the end.
Favs: I¬¥ve Got Your Number Son, Never Wanted Your Love

A pop note from the past with pastel colours.
Sweet and tasty.

While 
 houses a number of Barnes' most flamboyantly weird musical ideas, they're also frequently some of his hollowest

sees the trio perfect what they started to build on their debut. The murky allure of the Northwest is still a prominent aesthetic, yet second time round they have the confidence to shed more light on what was previously kept quietly in the shadows.

An illuminating effort in absolutely every regard, 
 is easily one of the most memorable musical encounters you‚Äôll hear this year.
Anyone who labours the point that this band don‚Äôt recast any musical wheels is missing their purpose.

In a Chainsmokers-era of blatantly commercial synthpop, Foster the People decided to hop on the bandwagon as well, with three tracks that are nearly impossible to tell apart. The band, who I have been a pretty big fan of in the past 6 years, took on painfully generic electro-trap beats and offered next to no lyrical value at all. It's a shame to see coming from a band with this much potential, but as one of the song titles says, they were Doing It For The Money.

It's rare for a band so far into its career to make an album that can still surprise listeners as the group gleefully makes its way from beginning to end. Field Music are masters of that neat trick, and 
 is no exception. It stands with their best work -- some songs would no doubt end up on a greatest-hits collection -- and in that regard is some of the best pop music anyone could hope to hear in 2018 or any time after.
Painstakingly crafted, cerebral pop.

is too nuanced and complex to be called a kids‚Äô record, but coming from a band whose work has often been clouded by emotional and lyrical ambiguity, it‚Äôs remarkably straight-ahead. This album bears the earnest directness of artists whose sense of the world has been nudged into focus in a new way.

Never quite hits it's stride. It's interesting at points but falls easily into the background. just nothing really here to set it apart, fairly straightforward jangle pop that's not quite as clever as it thinks it is.
Standouts: Open Here, Find a Way to Keep Me, Time in Joy

Some marvellous instrumentation you have given us, Field Music.
First Impressions:
Time In Joy 94
Count It Up 88
Front Of House 90
Share A Pillow 96
Open Here 93
Goodbye To The Country 95
Checking On A Message 96
No King No Princess 87
Cameraman 94
Daylight Saving 93
Find A Way To Keep Me 97
Top 5:
5. Time In Joy
4. Goodbye To The Country
3. Checking On A Message
2. Share A Pilow
1. Find A Way To Keep Me

title: The Louder I Call, The Faster It Runs

reviews.content:
There‚Äôs the wistfulness of 
, the urgency of 
, and the synth emphasis of 
. It‚Äôs not a hodgepodge, though. Instead, it‚Äôs a culmination of just about every texture they‚Äôve explored before, fostered through unmistakable maturity.
... is another step forward for Wye Oak, a duo who still carry plenty of vision to inject some life into a form of indie rock that you don't hear that often anymore.

Simplistic but not to its detriment, Wye Oak hit out with an album that spends most of its energy in the first few tracks and waits until the final few before regaining it. The middle slump doesn't stop this from being a delightfully solid indie pop record.
Different than the others, not upbeat per se but certainly closer to a pop-ish sound.

Feels like a synthesis of their previous three albums. More accessible, a bit mellow, but there's still a hint of Civilian's abrasive guitars. Didn't like it at all initially, but after several listens I think it's a solid and rather sensitive indie rock record.
‚ÄòFever Dreams‚Äô is very possibly Villagers‚Äô most ambitious and endearing record to date.
The whole is a dense, complex collection full of unexpected riches.
By weirding up his trademark magic, he somehow sounds closer to himself than ever.
While it occasionally loses its footing in the throes of musical abandon, the sheer immensity of some of these moments are testament to O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs growth as an artist.
is a bold and ambitious statement for Villagers‚Äô fifth album, a record full of risks at a time in the lifespan of a band when many artists have found their groove and are happy to play it safe.
It‚Äôs well-executed and well-timed, ambitious and meticulously polished yet more effortless, organic and free-flowing than ever.
A thrilling and unpredictable addition to Villagers‚Äô gleaming canon.

EraX recommends 2021 albums that deserve more ratings! [Part 1]
i mean yeah its got a bear on the cover and so simpatico is one of the best songs ever so who cares about the rest 10/10
For real though, this is a pretty sweet indie pop album! I can promise that the album is just as charming as the album cover! And if you don't want to listen to the album, please check out So Simpatico it is definitely one of the best songs of the year. :)
it definitely isn‚Äôt perfect however So Simpatico is one of the most beautiful songs I have ever heard. There are other fantastic songs here but man‚Ä¶ that one is special
Beautiful pop music with a psychedelic flare

It's not a perfect album but there's always so much I find interesting here. For quite a mellow album, Conor O'Brien experiments quite a bit with different sounds and textures. It makes for a record that has some unexpected moments, complex yet serene. So Simpatico in particular is a glorious 7 minutes of music. 
Faves: The First Day, So Simpatico, Circles in the Firing Line, Fever Dreams
Very unique atmosphere, i dig it a lot. You gotta respect the uniqueness. Looking forward to other records from these guys.

Even if Quilt don't always find the answers they're looking for on 
, they've found some of their most confident and cohesive music.
is indie rock with a pop sensibility and a slick edge, with guitars rippling through the tight conduits of Anna Fox Rochinski and Shane Butler‚Äôs songwriting machine.

The four write their songs collaboratively and share vocals; the collective approach to making music has resulted in an incredibly cohesive album with 10 tracks that flow naturally from one to the next for 41 minutes.

It would have been nice if the band took a chance on the new record by pushing these boundaries of empty space and release. Instead, 
 is a steadfast pop record in structure and vocals.

Paisley-shirted pop hasn‚Äôt been remotely fashionable for some time, and while Quilt aren‚Äôt likely to irk the purists with a radical take on a once-radical sound, it‚Äôs comforting to know that psychedelia is in safe hands.

The 10-song opus is a throwback to a time when records were complete collections of great songs instead of the usual tossed-together block of ethereal ‚Äúvibe‚Äù noodling. The four-piece that hails from Boston has a modern take on psych rock that gives nods to ‚Äô60s-‚Äô70s acts like The Byrds and Fleetwood Mac. They sound as if Quasi had sex with The Shins and gave birth to a smarter, more fit, more tuneful version of Of Montreal.

It's a perfect vocal vibe for music that can recall the very late Beatles and 
-era Dylan, but ultimately evokes nothing so much as what might happen if the cover art from Van Morrison's 
 had a weekend fling with the cover art from Yo La Tengo's 
.

Press materials for the record cite ubiquitous influences like Neil Young, George Harrison and Van Morrison, and while in most cases that might be cause for concern, 
 is a lush and beautiful record that stands comfortably in such heady company.
is a warm and rustic listen, Friedberger dressing sharply drawn narratives in a classic folk sound that makes the album as cosy as an old jumper.
's warm, reassuring atmosphere is a perfect fit for Friedberger's affably rambling songwriting.

While 
 may be musically somewhat muted, sonically a touch predictable and backward-looking, Friedberger still crafts utterly charming songs with brilliantly observed moments and a real sense of life‚Äôs great adventure.
.. is nothing less ‚Äì but little more ‚Äì than a continuation of the work begun over Friedberger‚Äôs first solo albums.
The third solo album of American musician, she dated previously Britt Daniel from Spoon ;-). The favorite song is the first one - Never Is A Long Time.

Glasgow-based duo Sacred Paws's sophomore release is aptly titled as it suggest: it flawlessly encapsulates a warm kind of tempo, bright and kinetic with instrumentation that reverberates throughout the track listing, sharing dual vocal work that seamlessly interweaves effervescent, robust guitar tones and urgent drumming techniques so organic sounding and immediate as ever. This is indie rock at its most swelling, joyful and brooding.

This album is an artistic masterpiece that weds Danger Mouse's incredible storytelling with Karen O's ambitious vocal presence in a 9-track journey that truly sheds the first light into the minds of these two icons.

There‚Äôs obvious chemistry between these two in the studio, and 
 sounds more dynamic than even the most optimistic fan could have hoped.
Burton‚Äôs trademark retro touches are here ‚Äî dreamy disco, ghostly synths and a crackly soulfulness.
‚Äã is a welcome departure from O's recent, fledgling solo output, and Danger Mouse is the perfect conduit for her larger-than-life voice, message and ideas.
An album that feels storied, complex and, crucially, intentional.

While the sound of 
 feels unexpected based off these artists‚Äô distinct histories, Karen O and Danger Mouse have unlocked a new creative force within each other.
‚ÄòLux Prima‚Äô is a hypnotic listen.

Repeated plays make it a lovable record as the subtle, ultra-cool textures creep into your consciousness and make for dynamic and vibrant tunes that leave swirling, seraphic sensations playing inside your head.
The innate desire of musical exploration of both artists is clear for all to see on ‚ÄòLux Prima‚Äô; a complex but ultimately rewarding listen.

Despite its flawless production, 
 is a noticeably restrained affair, considering what a feral creature Karen O has always been.

While it is endearing to hear Karen O working with a more patient form of songwriting, the raw energy and emotion of her best work isn‚Äôt present on 
.
It serviceably denotes grandeur and romance but without any real melodic invention.
Karen O has such a playful and gorgeous voice with so much sincerity and range. I instantly fell in love with it when she sang the inspirational and tender Song for a Warri -AH FUCK I DID IT AGAIN!
Karen O has such a playful and gorgeous voice with so much sincerity and range. I instantly fell in love with it when she sang the inspirational and tender Song for a Warri -AH FUCK I DID IT AGAIN!
Pretty beautiful track list honestly. Definitely underrated, but I understand how the first couple tracks outshine the rest which may make for a boring experience

i sometimes still can't believe just how beautiful some of these songs sound (lux prima and ministry, for example). overall, this is an incredibly successful collab which makes me happy to have explored both of the artists involved.
presents the strongest possible evidence of his status as not just interesting or unique or inventive, but a songwriter of the highest standing.

This is another remnant of my pre-pubescent years. Dodie's voice is very pretty, very relaxing. She is a very talented individual and we MUST acknowledge this. It's impressive. These songs are very cute. I think this is the best way of describing this: cute. It's sweet. Life Lesson feels very out of place though.
BEST: Intertwined, Sick of Losing Soulmates, When
WORST: Life Lesson

It's not Panopticon but it's pretty great for a debut EP. There is almost none of the post-metal that shows up so heavily in future Isis. This album is more or less straight sludge. Pleasant listen. Vocals are rough compared to future albums where his screams are more controlled. Here, it sounds at times like he's tearing his vocal cords apart.
is not flawless ... But the album is still a victory and an ode to the discomforts, pains, and ecstasies of Pierce‚Äôs queerness.

has wandered through various modes, ultimately coming off like a thoroughly pleasant but unexpected long walk on a summer evening, with Tatum stopping for a moment to say hello to all his various different inclinations for a moment before moving on.

It‚Äôs no 
 or 
, but Tatum still proves to be a visionary consistent in his trajectory of progressing confidence. It‚Äôs hard to call this a misstep at all, but its best quality is keeping hope alive for what will come next.

There are certain playful eccentricities found on 
 that haven‚Äôt been explored too often in the past.
'Empty Estate' is a great listen, where experimentation is handled with admirable subtlety and each track delivers immense instrumental detail and care.¬†

Empty Estate capitalizes on that funky 80's synth vibe they have crafted over the year. Abandoning drifting guitar melodies for big beats and funky bass lines and dream like states of ecstasy and wonder.
Lorde shows here that she has a knack for brooding paeans, and not just the sunny side of pop - she's not afraid to dig a little deeper.
With a style all her own and a unique voice ‚Äì both musically and lyrically ‚Äì expect Lorde‚Äôs ‚Äúfalse confidence‚Äù to become real confidence fairly soon.¬†
The lo-fi bedroom rock project from Indiana brings smooth guitar licks into clearer focus with their Fat Possum debut, a light and bright collection of weaving, winding psych-pop.
is a superb collection of effortless songs, and like their closest contemporaries Real Estate earlier in 2017, Hoops have delivered a leading example of guitar pop.
Hoops are a pleasant break from the norm, indie easy-listening, escapism when it‚Äôs arguably needed most.
Divertido y soleado,pero le hace falta m√°s variedad pues solo una cancion suena diferente al resto, un album solo para veranear.

The main attraction of 
 is just how eclectic it is. Trying to fence Belle and Sebastian in to one genre would be a fruitless exercise.¬†
Inside you‚Äôll find very little deviation from the wistful, narrative-led pop they‚Äôve made a career from.
Essentially, what we‚Äôre dealing with is a shameless indie pop record created by a shameless indie pop band.

In a musical climate where many bands create a fuss with a string of catchy forward-thinking singles and fail to deliver an album capable of justifying the fervour, Theme Park have emerged clutching the victory flag from beneath the rubble.

A catchy debut with sunny tunes and a holiday sense. 
Today, let's enjoy that good feeling. 
Tomorrow is just another day!

Super underrated art pop/dance record.
Almost every track on this record is something special whether it be the star-striking production or the beautifully sung performances by Inara George. It honestly sounds ahead of its time. I wonder if this work had any influence on the likes of Jockstrap's new pop sound today, especially with songs like "F-cking Boyfriend"
Hospitality is full of these moments, flashes of raucous, messy humanity trampling through otherwise flawlessly melodic songwriting

it is actually mind-numbing how the industry was able to completely rewire this guy from a gangster rap artist to some sensitive indie-rock/pop artist.
No complaints, he definitely has the right foot forward, especially for an industry plant

For demos, these are decent, but its still just boring indie pop.
(Favorites: "Babydoll", "King of Everything")
(Least Favorites: "Batshit", "Falling Asleep")

The trio of Brisbane teenagers all share songwriting duties on their debut album, 
, and a millennial apathy prevails as the jangle pop three-piece churn out their terse hook-laden compositions.
Up to anything is simply pop perfection. Weird, quirky and annoyingly catchy. The same formula seems to be repeated throughout the album but never fails to make you groove.

Self-produced and recorded, 
 is the most hermetic LP James Mercer has released since 2001‚Äôs 
. His gift for making fussy arrangements seem effortless remains unparalleled.

This dynamic is the engine that powers 
, with subject matter frequently much heavier than the psychedelia-tinged pop its bathed in.
is an understated and charming production of orchestral rock, surfy riffs cresting summery melodies and experimental streaks of reverb.

While 
 has its melodic pop moments and the band tries to remain indie-rock stalwarts, there seems to be a lack of cohesiveness between the songs. But one thing that remains strong is Mercer's ability to craft songs that are always interesting, otherworldly, and transport you to another universe.

The Shins are normally focused on the future, but 
, their first album in five years and fifth since 2001, takes a small step into the past.
Special effects and studiously flamboyant vocals result in surrealist, cartoon pop that‚Äôs stuck in the adolescent.

As the elder statesman of indie pop, James Mercer has earned his right to wiggle his toes in previously undisturbed waters, but too often on 
 he sounds less like a genius gracefully growing old and more like Wayne Coyne in full mid-life crisis mode.

It's really interesting listening to indie bands that were huge in the early 2000s flail around trying to stay relevant. Modest Mouse, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins. They all just keep trying to remain relevant, but their time has passed.
This is an album from The Shins. That's about it. It sounds like what you expect The Shins to sound like.

An ok album, but I wish the shins went out on more of a high note. Mercer's voice in this album is clearly a step below what it had been previously. Most songs are ok but forgettable. The only quintessential song from this album for me is So Now What, a beautiful and nostalgic song that almost feels like New Slang 2.0. Rest of the album is unfortunately all too forgettable.
Truly one of the most underrated albums of all time. It's heartwarming, beautiful and powerful. I love it!

title: Street of the Love of Days

reviews.content: There is a fine tuning of musical frequencies that makes this side project a delight.

Is it safe to say I am not a fan of this album? I do like ethereal and space sounding music, however for Jim's type of music this really is not my thing at all. A lot of cool sounds however, those sounds combined with Jim's style does not suit me. (Although there are a few incredible sounding songs here, I can't help but feel like it clashes too much).

as usual, the songs are beautiful and superbly crafted, but M&PC has never mastered the ironic twistiness of indie pop lyricism (listen to Camera Obscura for a master-class in this) and as a result they can sound like a sleepy emo band. underwhelming lyrics undercut the beautiful song structures and it all dissolves into mid-tempo sameness.

One suspects they‚Äôve never heard of Black Flag, but their DIY ethos at least means the blame for this turgid heap can be placed squarely on their own shoulders ‚Äì not that hired help would have been able to solve the dearth of musical and lyrical innovation on show here.

title: Songs in the Key of Animals

reviews.content:
Benji Hughes pulls this off without pause as he merges his comedic commentary with his poetic earnestness, reaching a well blended middle ground on his latest record, 
.

Taken altogether, the various sounds and moods on 
 are a nice progression from her debut, and show Green wrestling with some pretty big issues while still dishing out really good pop songs that'll have you singing along after the first spin.

Nothing groundbreaking about this album, but sometimes less will do. This is a good solid album, with some good tunes, and a couple of very good tunes. Definitely Greens most accomplished work to date. 
Favorite moments: Wild One, Deeper Than Love, Grind My Teeth, Whatever I Want.

Ra Ra Riot‚Äôs sophomore disc, 
, offers every bit of the rolling rural hills that its title suggests; with sky-wide, spacious arrangements, it‚Äôs a cool autumn cruise through the Adirondacks with the top down. Unfortunately, the record is too much forest and too few breathtaking mountaintop vistas.

Though hardly a radical departure from the baroque-pop template set by that debut,
