This album is hands down the best trash of the decade. Honestly is up there as an all time trash great and might even be metals best album this decade imo
Every thing screams epic beyond belief here. From Civilization collapse to the title track. The high points of some of these tracks feel as if they reach my soul

Glass Bead goes unreasonably hard. Neverland is a great track in its own right too, while White borders on complete dud territory had it not been for that super loveable synth melody, regardless both pale in comparison to even the instrumental version of Glass Bead.

He has the energy and talent to rap amusing circles around most of his peers, but seems to need a stable collaborator to come up with the sort of consistent bash that Quavo and crew made look effortless this past January. Instead, 
 seems to pull in every direction at once.

Despite the band's downsizing, 
 demonstrates that Andrew has always been the beating heart of Liars. This time, the unexpected was hearing him bare his without any uncertainty.

might well be an Angus Andrew solo album under the Liars banner, but what he‚Äôs achieved here fits within the his band‚Äôs remit for consistently morphing and confounding expectation. More importantly, it‚Äôs heartening to see an album as intriguing as this emerge from such a traumatic time.

It has sufficient new features, sweepingly introduced so as to constitute a more-than-satisfying reinvention. So acoustic instrumentation, something Liars had hitherto generally eschewed, can be found here and found in diverse forms.
Despite the departure of Aaron Hemphill, the band still bring a lot of mesmerizing tones while at times feeling a little out of reach for new listeners.
This is probably one of the more accessible Liars records. But accessible Liars is still odd, experimental, and out there.

title: Golden Sings That Have Been Sung

reviews.content: Set aside all of ‚ÄòPrimrose Green‚Äô‚Äôs whimsy strains, Walker has finally blossomed into the mature and talented songwriter he is today, putting together eight almost flawless tracks of solid and structured folk.
is a personal best for Walker, innovation for the genre and in general, just a damn good listen.

is a great listen. It strikes an unusual balance between the focused and the meditative, keeps the ears engaged for its duration, and suggests a compelling avenue for free improvisation by reinventing itself with a renewed focus on process and prolonged gestures.

What makes 
 particularly satisfying is that it doesn't fall into the traps that other records on Erased Tapes do: a rarefied neo-classical tone, an over-emphasis on wafting melody over rhythm and timbre.

The ultimate irony of 
 is that by playing with musical restraint, they discover whole new avenues of sound that's focused on rhythm, dismantling jazz with the tools that built it.¬†

Conceptually, the band has rendered a queer but inevitable inversion of influence on 
¬†‚Äî they are playing acoustic music influenced structurally and tonally by automatic, electronic composition.
Mr. Impossible feels like a collection of instrumentals that has a clear if seriously bent relationship to pop music.
This one actually has discernible melodies and some semblance of structure, flirting with pop but never straying too far from their own bizarro world of relentless distortion.
Mr. Impossible accomplishes the improbable: being more accessible and more alienating at the same time.¬†
The trio‚Äôs sixth album Mr Impossible finds Black Dice at their most accessible and most aggravating.

Whilst arguably Beam's most consistent album for some years, there are fewer moments of raw beauty here than on past excursions, resulting in a whole that is somehow less than its impressive component parts.¬†
Former earnest acoustic-type Sam Beam's fifth album sees him taking further, grander steps in the shiny loafers of a cheesy 1970s crooner with a fondness for symphonic folk and a soul groove.

It may be palatable and generally inoffensive on a whole, but 
 really goes down best when viewed as a supplement to other better, more transcendent material already out there.

Ghost on Ghost is certainly more focused than the previous record, but overall its still just too forgettable and not interesting enough to return to besides some tracks. My favorite track is Baby Center Stage.

I really love her music but in terms of musical approach she is playing so incredibly safe in every single album that it is almost meaningless if she does something new or she does not. Enjoyable as usual but no more than that.

Blake Mills is a name we should hear WAY more often in the online music discourse on indie folk.
FAVORITE TRACKS: ALL.
LEAST FAVORITE TRACKS: N/A.

title: The Double EP: The Sea of Split Peas

reviews.content: This release, which combines two recent EPs, introduces a unique new songwriting voice.
An assured predebut that is archetypal of 'slacker' indie rock. Excellent set of tunes.

Retro is the word. 
Hell more than that derivative is the word. 
This does not equate to a 'bad' thing in the slightest in this instance though - in actual fact this is a sublime listen showing great artistry despite cribbing from many, oh so many, ‚Äò70s folk and soft rock touchstones.
What sets this record apart from others is its ability to be dynamic in composition and concise in lyrics. Everything is purposeful. That is a rare quality when it comes to modern music.

There is some devastating music on 
, and there is some beautiful music, too; often these passages are one and the same. It sounds like a natural progression for Andrew Bird, yet in places it‚Äôs like nothing you‚Äôd expect from the singer.¬†
Here, with his marriage pressing on the frontlines of his memory, love rises to the surface of his lyrical repertoire, assuming a significance it has yet to achieve in his discography.

Bird is an instrumental painter and 
 is another adventure book in his impressively detailed series.

isn‚Äôt perfect by any stretch, but on this record, Andrew Bird has compiled 11 good songs. Every track is well-produced. Every track has competent lyrics. Every track is melodically solid. Every track exhibits Bird‚Äôs impressive performing abilities. Every track is individually memorable.

While Bird could putter along on smug displays of his technical prowess, the sort he nodded to in his earliest records, he only grows more inclusive with age ... He slots his conservatory chops into increasingly accessible pop melodies, aiming for kinship over virtuosity.

I wish I could whistle as well as Andrew Bird. Jokes aside, this was a very fun and poetic album. There's some really interesting wordplay and I love the sardonic and/or gentle tones of the songs. The title track is the standout for me.
FAVORITE SONGS
Capsized
Are You Serious
Bellevue

I wish I could whistle as well as Andrew Bird. Jokes aside, this was a very fun and poetic album. There's some really interesting wordplay and I love the sardonic and/or gentle tones of the songs. The title track is the standout for me.
FAVORITE SONGS
Capsized
Are You Serious
Bellevue

It would be hard to see this album not making any end-of-year lists, partly down to the fact that this is one of the most beautiful albums to come out of 2012 so far, and also partly down to the fact that this is Efterklang's landmark album.¬†
This is the album where Efterklang reconcile their imaginative orchestration with a noticeable step up in lyrical meaning and thought.¬†
This shift results in music that on its surface feels ambitious and sophisticated but which manages never to take any real chances.

The thorough arrangements on 
 continue to be the reason to come to an Efterklang disc, but they are rarely matched with equally strong pop components.
This might be BMSR's most accessible effort, but if you couldn't get past the vocoder and voodoo before, it's unlikely that you will now.
is the most technically focused that Black Moth Super Rainbow have ever been, but it also lacks an important degree of their trademark self-contradiction.

title: They Moved In Shadow All Together

reviews.content: Thank you Spotify for making me discover this wonderful album. I don't have the exact words to say how beautiful this album is. I just know this is the kind of sound that I long and crave for. I am delighted.

EDIT: I'm enjoying this one a lot more as time goes on. Definitely one of their best albums and definitely their best since Bark Like A Dog. It's so much fun!
I'm still adapting to this one. I tend to enjoy the 80s to early 90s stuff from Screeching Weasel because it knows what pop punk should be. Catchy tunes with the usual pop punk topics while still keeping those sick vocals and punk instrumentals. I don't doubt this one is good, I just prefer early punk over the 00's pop punk scene.
The best album they‚Äôve made since emo. It‚Äôs full of classic punk hooks.
another very correct album from this veteran band. classic full punk rock
Sun And Shade proves far more complex than the label of psych-folk would indicate, to the point that its small flaws are easily forgivable.

On 
, the almost unbelievable set of circumstances and experiences that have shaped CocoRosie‚Äôs lives and musical styles to date are as influential as they have always been - eccentric, diverse, challenging and beautiful.

In the main 
 is an invigorating listen, a patchwork of shifting moods and genres
Side project of The Story So Far front man Parker Cannon. Sounds a lot like Early TSSF. Fast and fun pop punk. If you like that I'm sure you'll enjoy this as well.

A really melancholic but also beautiful listen, Dragonchaser sports absolutely incredible instrumentals and some gorgeous vocal performances and lyricism, and while the pacing is slightly uneven, it doesn't stop this album from being an absolutely amazing album that needs to be heard by more people.
It's a shame that this band is so unknown. The emotion is pounding, the rhythm and riffs are on point, and this serves as a pretty good Shoegaze/Doomgaze album.
has produced the rare indie pop record that seizes you on the first listen but also rewards repeated playing.
UMO manages a unique immersive and psychedelic quality without relying on the usual array of bong-ripping effects.
Their songs offer a relaxing escape that‚Äôs perfect for the summer.
is not Blake‚Äôs most dynamic or genre-defying work, but neither is it a definitive statement of what is to come. Instead, it is a snapshot of a period of his creativity, a peek into his sketchbook.
For those who adored Blake's heavier, more rhythmic early material, Enough Thunder could easily turn into Not Enough Thunder.

All in all, 
 sounds like an ‚ÄúEverything Must Go‚Äù musical yard sale, Blake clearing house of all his unused ideas that couldn‚Äôt fit on a proper record.
Close to a perfect album, Christmas' voice is ever fantastic

This is surprisingly decent. It has a very charming and sweet little tone to it; very DIY-esque. Despite the obvious simplicity of this project, Cera actually shows a little experimentation with different sounds and samples, which is probably the most surprising aspect of this record.

With his debut LP, Gesaffelstein is not only taking aim at ending the loudness wars, he is fortifying the roots of a very successful career. With production credits on 
 already on his resume, Gesaffelstein possesses the talent to produce hits across a wide range of genres and still find the time to destroy the most pretentious of techno clubs.

In the end, "Vena Sera" is a showcase for this band's tight, punchy sound, Peter Loeffler's fluid vocals and the trio's not-to-be- dismissed songwriting skills, even if the tunes don't have the staying power of truly great rock music.

I actually really like this record. I like it more than 'Wonder What's Next' and 'This Type Of Thinking'. It feels more upbeat, cohesive and layered. I love how huge the bass sounds on this record. Plus there are some really great hooks and vocal harmonies on Vena Sera. 'I Get It' is one of my favorite Chevelle songs.
Favorites: Brainiac, The Fad, I Get It, Saturdays

Descriptions of 
 undoubtedly make it sound like an odd mix, to say the least, but in reality it‚Äôs strong and polished, not so much musical variety hour as it is the work of a clever artist in pursuit of a million different ideas and capturing at least a thousand of them at once.
On his third solo album Ronson drops a fun hodgepodge of original material, the first on which he both writes and sings.
Paranoia produces, if not a great album, a respectable transition from love-him-or-hate-him brass-toting berk into a genuine, bona fide pop maverick.
But like anyone‚Äôs record collection, Record Collection has more hits than misses. It‚Äôs future pop with a foot firmly in the past.

Ronson‚Äôs strength has always been in surrounding himself with like-minded artists, both burgeoning and established, and that‚Äôs largely true on 
, a typically ambitious if uneven effort.
It retains all the elements that are recognisably Squarepusher but manages to filter them through this newly polished lens and thrusts it into a new, invigorating stream of light.
‚ÄòLove in the 4th Dimension‚Äô is the kind of musical roast that‚Äôd have Nigella beaming with pride, letting loose mildly suggestive monologues praising the technique and tantalising going on here.

Debut album ‚ÄòLove In The 4th Dimension‚Äô from The Big Moon is a non-stop pleasure to listen to from the moment the guitar shredding starts on ‚ÄòSucker‚Äô. It‚Äôs fresh and fun, consisting of improved renditions of fan favourites, whacky touches and new numbers.

Fun pop bangers :) Honestly don't have much else to say about this one but that's not the worst thing in the world
Favourites: Sucker, Pull the Other One, Happy New Year
Least Favourites: Silent Movie Suzie

The 1st baby of this beautiful beautiful band aww, of course they¬¥ve impoved SO MUCH after this but this still was pretty.
Fav tracks:
- The Road 
- Formidable
- Sucker
- Zeds
- Happy New Year

Fun pop bangers :) Honestly don't have much else to say about this one but that's not the worst thing in the world
Favourites: Sucker, Pull the Other One, Happy New Year
Least Favourites: Silent Movie Suzie

While a few tracks sound too similar to each other, 
's best moments deliver pop accessibility without sacrificing any of MS MR's identity.

Although 
 is far more subdued and inconsistent than 
, MS MR still has no peer in its ability to twist retro and modern influences in fresh ways.
Stronger than its predecessor, wider vocal range and more interesting lyrics, the sound is not innovative but I sure enjoy this and that's what matters.

This makes me appreciate In Rainbows more than I already did and that‚Äôs saying something considering I think it‚Äôs a perfect album. I would also like to thank the band for doing Myxomatosis. I loved it before but in this performance I feel Thom puts a lot of emotion into it, making it even better.
This is not a record for quick thrills, or for sombre introspection; it is an album that creates a rich, layered sonic space, in which it invites its audience to lose themselves awhile.
lacks the deft, enchanting musical nuance of The National or Beirut but it does make for enjoyable, if not startling, interim listening.

Whilst they are mostly good cuts, the vocal tracks are disappointing in comparison (with the exception of Beneath The Black Sea); ultimately, there‚Äôs likely to be a few yawns and subsequent yearning for a new album by The National instead.

As a producer and studio musician, Bayston has proved he's worth his salt (and then some). As a solo artist, he's definitely worth keeping an eye on. Undoubtedly, 
 is only the beginning.

With 
, Bayston comes as close as anyone in creating cerebral dance pop that works for the non-EDM dance music enthusiast as much as the experimental electronic rock enthusiast.
Some oddly charming songs here. Listenable, but with tight drums and driving bass that carry the songs nicely.
While it isn‚Äôt an instant classic like its predecessor, the album serves as a strong victory lap that highlights everything good about Raekwon.

Everything about this album is alright: the beats, the rhymes, the features. Raekwon is obviously trying to emulate that classic Wu-Tang sound; and while it works, there‚Äôs nothing very exciting or engaging about it. Shaolin vs. Wu-Tang is just kinda‚Ä¶ predictable.
Mind Bokeh is a pop album in the best sense of the word: it‚Äôs fun to listen to whether you‚Äôre at the beach or in a club on the dancefloor.
Mind Bokeh is an ugly stepchild of a record, neither diverting enough to work as pop nor novel enough to satisfy as pure electronic music.

A funky soundtrack to your most vivid daydreams, with each track having a distinct flavour while also building a cohesive soundscape.
‚ô° Take Off Your Shirt, K Is For Kelson, Anything New

His effortless melodies and hooks continue to set him apart on this third album, which absorbs musical references such as Paul Simon, Philly soul and R&B ... without pushing him too far from his core jangle-pop aesthetic.

Such confident, experimental songwriting points to a rebirth for Wild Nothing, and means ‚ÄòLife Of Pause‚Äô can be considered alongside indie records like Tame Impala‚Äôs ‚ÄòCurrents‚Äô and Unknown Mortal Orchestra‚Äôs ‚ÄòMulti-Love‚Äô.

might have provided an opportune moment to veer left off course into the unknown, but the album doesn‚Äôt chase after new horizons so much as it absorbs their reflection into Wild Nothing‚Äôs fondly familiar dream pop bubble.

Compared to the low-key and at times melancholic 
, 
 is a rich and expansive step up that balances the old and the new perfectly to create Wild Nothing‚Äôs best album yet.

While Tatum's attempts at candor are sometimes at odds with his sonic ambitions, this tension lends 
's strongest moments an unexpected layer of emotional immediacy.

You leave this record thinking about how complex and refined it is, or maybe about how much Jack Tatum has grown as a songwriter. But at the end of the day, the album doesn‚Äôt embed itself into your daily life in the way 
 or 
 did.
Spacey vocals low in the mix and a slowed-heartrate pace mean much of the third album by Jack Tatum‚Äôs indie outfit feels like a half-remembered dream.
is certainly different on an aesthetic level, acting as a departure from the indie/dream/goth pop 80s concoction many of us have come to love and expect from Wild Nothing.
It likely won‚Äôt be topping anyone‚Äôs charts this year, but it‚Äôll get spins from people who like smartly crafted, catchy indie background pop.

Wild Nothing goes more into new wave, I have to agree that the songwriting is more weak on this one, but still I think it's a good chill album with lush instrumentals, great atmosphere and catchy songs, even though there are some forgettable songs in this one.

Despite Wild Nothing's best attempts in Steely Dan worship on 'Life of Pause' through its' seeming increase in budget and lavish instrumentation, it is hampered by his weak songwriting and flatness in production. A few catchy songs aside, this album is ephemeral and inessential.
Favourite songs: Lady Blue, Life of Pause, To Know You, Whenever I

I hold Nocturne in such high esteem that even if this album were really good I'd probably have been irrationally disappointed. Luckily Jack Tatum made it easy for me by simply releasing an album so bland that nobody seemed to be impressed. Wild Nothing will remain one of my favorite indie pop acts ever, but this marked a descent into a kind of featureless muzak from which they never fully emerged.
Nice enough: the run from To Know You through TV Queen

I hold Nocturne in such high esteem that even if this album were really good I'd probably have been irrationally disappointed. Luckily Jack Tatum made it easy for me by simply releasing an album so bland that nobody seemed to be impressed. Wild Nothing will remain one of my favorite indie pop acts ever, but this marked a descent into a kind of featureless muzak from which they never fully emerged.
Nice enough: the run from To Know You through TV Queen

Wild Nothing goes more into new wave, I have to agree that the songwriting is more weak on this one, but still I think it's a good chill album with lush instrumentals, great atmosphere and catchy songs, even though there are some forgettable songs in this one.
Oceanic synths, wobbly basslines, and precise snare drums cohere into a crisp pop sound, while his high, expressive voice bobs brightly above the surface.

It‚Äôs perfectly easy to listen to Porches on a superficial level and find beautiful hooks to hang on to, but the real joy of this album is to dip beneath the surface, and see what‚Äôs going on underneath.

Maine seems to have spent the time since 
 studying classic soft rock and the inner workings of the recording studio. That change saps the warmth out of his lo-fi style, and the Auto-Tune and synths slow his already flat delivery and lyrical meditations on slowness even further.
His boyish sensibilities alongside his weary, romantic croon does grate, and especially so considering he‚Äôs taking a musical approach that automatically puts him in a more vulnerable place.

The high points on Pool are incredibly worthwhile (first 4 tracks, Glow, Car, Shaver), but there is too much filler here for me to return to this album often. It's catchy yet forlorn and definitely unique in its more somber synthpop approach, but this is far from perfecting that sound.
moody

The high points on Pool are incredibly worthwhile (first 4 tracks, Glow, Car, Shaver), but there is too much filler here for me to return to this album often. It's catchy yet forlorn and definitely unique in its more somber synthpop approach, but this is far from perfecting that sound.
It‚Äôs ... one of the most infectious collections of pop songs written on an electric guitar this year.
Amber Arcades uses reverb, jangling chords and drifting, repetitive musical figures to enhance what are mostly typical pop songs.

Such a brave and bold debut, Amber cleverly manipulates the clinical production with simple yet deep lyrical contents. It's 2021 and Fading Lines still sounds fresh and I don't mind revisiting it over and over again.
Key tracks : Constant's Dream, I Will Follow, This Time

Amber Arcades makes wistful, very pretty dream pop music that is a lot more dreamy than it is poppy. Especially for a debut album, the sound is impressively focused and cohesive, and Amber Arcades display some solid songwriting chops. The album does sort of seem to float away on its own lightweight-ness, however, and the melodies don't stick as much as you'd hope.

There are some things about Club 8 records that are always the same. The line-up, for one thing-- Johan Angerg√•rd is the composer, and Karolina Komstedt is the singer. Her voice is always polite and gentle; his songs are consistently tuneful in the low-key way that characterizes contemporary Scandinavian indie pop. Within this template, the duo have gone through a surprising number of stylistic shifts-- at various time slipping comfortably into trip-hop, twee, bossanova, dub, and dance-pop. Their experimentation has yielded hit-or-miss results, but their willingness to explore and ability to change up their formula without sacrificing the band's essential character is commendable.

It definitely is a project of its' own!
Having a similar cinematic sense of danger and tension to Portishead's, Unloved elevate that and offer an instrumental palette which, apart from being quite unique and full of personality, is theatrical and playful.
Highlights: Heartbreak, Love, (Sigh), Bill, Lee and Danger.
The Human Condition is really shallow album, with boring overblown production and corny vocal performance and pretty not good lyrics.

Jon Bellion may not be perfect, but he and this album have incredible heart and some truly unique moments that are not replicable. The heart and passion you feel in this project is tangible. It has made for an album I have listened to countless times, can see the flaws in, but am still brought to sincere moments of emotion and contemplation at its conclusion.

As musical collaborations go, the one embarked upon by James Mercer, mercurial singer/songwriter with esteemed Portlanders The Shins, and Brian Burton, better known as producer extraordinaire Danger Mouse, has to go down as one of the most unlikely. While perhaps not in the sublime bracket of ridiculousness inhabited by Burt Bacharach's mutual love-in with Elvis Costello and Dr Dre that reared 2005's ill-advised At This Time or Bing Crosby and David Bowie uttering Christmas carols to one another, it certainly set the proverbial cat amongst the pigeons late last year when Mercer announced Broken Bells was a fully projected work in progress and an album would be imminent.

Broken Balls??? Indie pop from the 2010s????? WOAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH. 
It‚Äôs pretty good lmao
The High Road - 8
Vaporize - 7
Your Head Is On Fire - 7.5

Successful little project by two big names in the indie music industry. Crazy catchy with great melodies, songs and solid production (not a surprise coming from danger mouse).

A surprising gem this one. Led by the fantastic opening track, the quality and pleasant summer vibe continues throughout.
Essential Track - The High Road.
In terms of ideology and commitment to making progressive music that challenges and, at times, unsettles their audience they remain as relevant as ever.¬†
is a relatively strong release from a classic band, albeit one that never really got popular with the masses.¬†

58 is as high as I can give Big Sean's songwriting ability, he's usually a solid 45. This has no filler, easily his most focused album, he hones his bars to trim the fat, leaving the corny punchlines by the wayside. The first time since Detroit he's cleaned it up and delivered something well-crafted. Thanks again, Hit-Boy.

In an era where artists hype up projects that turn out to be nothing but half-baked playlists, 6LACK‚Äôs thoughtful embrace of the album format is refreshing. 
 is a moody masterpiece that may very well take the artist‚Äôs career to new heights.
On one of the best rapper/producer collaborations of the year, the Atlanta MC remains a perfect fit for Pi‚Äôerre Bourne‚Äôs weird and heavy beats.

People calling this Die Lit 2 didn‚Äôt even listen to it, just saw Pierre Bourne‚Äôs name and made some bs comparison.
This is a very creative trap rap album filled with quirky and colorful beats, a lot of standout personality from Nudy and a great variety in vocal delivery. This thing is so replayable, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a single filler track on here. Very well made
Some of the songs on here are so catchy it's unreal
Its an intriguing and welcome change, despite the fact that it isn‚Äôt the most groundbreaking album we‚Äôve heard this year.
A fun and exciting post-punk record with catchy songs.
These songs stand bare on their own for what they are: punk rock with an ear for pop catchiness.

What keeps 
 fresh is that to the side of Williams‚Äô now familiar monster hooks ... he continues to weave in off-kilter grungy noise and oddities without ever threatening to knock the train off the rails.

With 
, Williams reasserts his status as one of pop punk‚Äôs preeminent songwriters, even if this version of pop punk has more in common with Black Flag on 
 than with Blink-182.
Her flow is amazing! I'm sad there are just a few tracks that I actually enjoyed, but she's good.

Pretty solid pop punk album. It has some ideas and features that are really interesting and the execution of them are good, but I believe these ideas were better developed in Home Like Noplace Is There. It also shares the same problem I think a lot of pop punk music has, and it's that the sound doesn't age that well, but The Hotelier had a unique sound, which is something i personally think a lot of pop punk artists didn't have.
funky and fun woohoo

28 minutes of Catchy and energtic power pop / garage pop punk with great use of lo-fi production to really make it in your face which works lovely with how utterly catchy some of these riffs and hooks are for just a super fun listen.

What marks this album out from Slaves‚Äô first two records is the range Holman and Vincent have proven they possess: where 2016‚Äôs 
 ... felt like one big raging scream, 
 sees the band showing their sensitive side as well.

Memphis post-punk band's third release highlights the mundane day-to-day existence in its monotony and the desire for change. With its bustling bass lines, warbling synths and icy guitar tones, the tracks moves at a dynamic pace, maintaining its punk framework and sense of urgency.

Fabulous atmosphere on this record. Like a glistening gem stone in the sunlight. The vocals are a super afterthought again but the highlight is their progressive abilities on the instruments. Sapphire, Levitation, and Chemical Cave are all excellent. Great hearing those tracks live as well.
The place where the anthemic, the noisy and the epic meet is where The Men sound most naturally positioned.
Overdriven, overblown and utterly exciting, it might be nothing new, but it‚Äôs a thunderous reminder as to why rock is so enduring.
Rado might be derivative, but at least there‚Äôs an admirable consistency to his prodigious output. Studying the masters has taught him how to put together catchy songs seemingly at will.
It‚Äôs an ambitious record that didn‚Äôt need to be ambitious. Too many quirky ideas plague it from finding an identity, which says more about Rado than his own music.¬†
The first solo effort from a Foxygen member, and it is not half bad. Rado is not a bad singer. He throws in some Foxygen influence, but also adds an electronic side to it.
is their least specific album‚Äîno granular references to obscure Jersey baseball teams‚Äîbut their most universal, less dependent on empathizing with the suburban sad sack.

presents an abstracted story as its emotional core, and it‚Äôs significantly harder to respond to that more distant lyrical perspective. Taken on its own, however, the album is one of the more compassionate, prideful and ultimately moving depictions of mental illness on record in recent years.

At 93 minutes, Titus Andronicus's latest may scare off those who believe punk rock should be compartmentalized into accessible pieces.¬†There's not much that's accessible about 
, but that's a good thing.

Where 
 was a punk rock 
 for a different generation, full of sprawling ‚ÄúJungleland‚Äù revamps, 
 is an epic of different means. It‚Äôs comprised of the punchiest, most direct songs this band has yet unleashed.

A massive, sprawling mess of styles and genres, all rooted in Stickles‚Äô wordy lyrical catharsis, 
 reflects the wild mood swings associated with those suffering from bipolar disorder; raging one moment, euphoric the next before settling into a seemingly bottomless depression.

I will try to find some time to write something better about this album, but for now, just giving you guys the alert that this seems to be an unfortunately overlooked release.
Kind of in the punk/hardcore corner, with a lot of energy, raw feeling, some nice atmospheres here and there and more than a couple of very elegant moves. Interesting and versatile ride.
Check on it, at least for me was a nice surprise.
Though it often feels 50% exploration and 50% classic Allie Hanlon, it will prove fun for her fans nonetheless.
allie has expanded her songwriting but only slightly. cleaner sounding for sure, a lil more varied instrumentation. same quick, cute, fun pop songs. probably one of her better projects to date

You know what? The hold steady can still write some pretty catchy little rock songs.
In fact this genre is so out of fashion at this point that they've kind of come full circle to being a real hipster act.
Un resurgimiento del pop meloso en espa√±ol, Movidas es un disco hecho por y para adolescentes el cual claramente adoro.

As both a quintessential entry into his catalog and a striking entry into mainstream popular culture, 
 once again cements Beck as a clever, ever-dynamic and enduring artist.

As his first upbeat album in nearly a decade, 
 proves that Beck is still one of rock‚Äôs most intrepid inventors.

is a varied and blissful pop album that finds joy in our times, and Beck expectedly makes it interesting and vibrant to experience. He has decided to make something optimistic in the midst of so much unrest, and it succeeds in bringing a celebratory presence to a world that need it.

If you've missed Beck the musical collage artist, 
 is the one that should bring you back.

Whether 
 will be a success within the pop world it is clearly aimed at remains to be seen, but one suspects even pop fans will see through this for it appears to be: an album documenting a mid-life crisis.

The problem with 
 is that where once he innovated, Beck now seems to be imitating the slew of fizzing faceless pop clogging the airwaves buried under a mesh of corporate production.

The version of pop foregrounded on 
 is status-quo male pop with occasional musical tweaks and turns, but with an overarching affect of moderate joy. Nothing about 
 substantially provides evidence of disruption or exploration.

youre probably wondering why i scored this higher than morning phase and that's because at least some of the songs here are the funniest shit ever
like bro.. "Wow"? i was crying
most of this album does suck but at least I wasn't borderline sleeping throughout the whole thing
Dreams is still a hood classic tho

The problem here is that, while Abe Vigoda have done a great job nailing their stylistic transition, the new direction has brought them a lot closer to a sound which, for me, is far less fresh and innovative than what they were doing on Skeleton.
When Fish Ride Bicycles is deceptively simple by design but essentially entertaining by default.
This is a tightly-crafted showcase for the unique sound and style of The Cool Kids.

The result is amiable, catchy tracks like the funkified ‚ÄúGas Station‚Äù and the feather-light poolside jam ‚ÄúSwimsuits.‚Äù But the balls-out swagger of 
 has been replaced by a sense of obligatory mark-hitting that saps some‚Äîthough certainly not all‚Äîof the songs‚Äô energy.
Bigger, bolder but still retaining an engaging charm, it is a highly impressive melodic triumph.
With a production assist from the Black Keys‚Äô Patrick Carney, it‚Äôs a grown-up sophomore effort that embraces broader pop sensibilities.
The fact that the music is written by two talented people in love is something that can outlast the gimmick.
Despite a few missteps, Acousmatic Sorcery is still a unique debut announcing the emergence of a fresh talent worthy of the buzz Beal has been receiving.¬†
Epic pop punk. üòé

Effusive, highly danceable and crammed with hooks, 
 plays like a greatest hits from a parallel universe.
Sound Kapital, in its deepest essence, is the perfect stroke of mature artistry.
Sound Kapitol is a successful, if slightly creatively stifling refinement of a fruitful and unique musical partnership.
Very enjoyable; every song is a jammer. However, it does get very repetitive. Still, definitely worth listening to if you like the late '90s and early 2000s pop punk sound.

Witty rockers Art Brut return with a fresh batch of songs about drinking, reading comic books, and facing off against Satan. Following the band's split with EMI last year, it's not hard to figure out who the titular Dark Prince is, but the album as a whole doesn't get bogged down with music business politics.

title: Two Lefts Don't Make a Right... But Three Do

reviews.content: Amazing album, so good that I decided to buy it three times on CD. Much better than the first 2 albums. It does kinda get a bit boring as the album progresses but this is probably just the length of the album. I really enjoyed the first 5 or so tracks. and also the funny rap part at the very end of the album. What an amazing album by one of my favorite pop punk bands Relient K!

Her voice flutters, bounces, and hiccups through the twelve songs on 
, and her singing is dynamic and never boring.
is the product of a stock-taking pause, it's clear the former Canadian indie scenester had rediscovered her bearings.

On her latest album, 
, Canadian singer-songwriter Leslie Feist brings a set of songs that feel much older than the tracks that were on her last album, 
. That album was released only four years ago, but 
' dreary, grey aesthetic makes the distance between these two albums feel so much wider.

8/10
exceptional
Fav tracks: The Bad In Each Other, Graveyard, Caught A Long Wind, How Come You Never Got There, A Commotion, Bittersweet Melodies, Undiscovered First, Comfort Me

POLARIS MUSIC PRIZE WINNERS DEEP DIVE (for @Dax_Wilder): 2012
Feist's fourth album (the first album by a female solo artist to win the Polaris Prize), shows her taking her typical folk pop into a more sprawling, sombre and naturalistic direction, compared to the more immediate, catchy sensibilities of The Reminder. It's a sound that really works well on her. Super relaxing and Autumnal in sound

With its genre manipulation and intensely poetic, socially aware lyrics, 
 is a stronger, more assertive record with more to say for itself.¬†
As the band continues to evolve around and with her, Speedy Ortiz‚Äôs music finally sounds as complex as its leader dares to be.
Even if Speedy Ortiz isn‚Äôt afraid to take chances, its strength still lies in ‚Äô90s-minded indie rock that‚Äôs become its calling card. For the slackers of the world, that‚Äôs good enough.
Considering how much Twin Shadow excels as a project of pristine, highly addictive pop bangers, ‚ÄòEclipse‚Äô falls flat too often.

On 
, Twin Shadow hasn‚Äôt completely lost the plot ‚Äì scattered across the album are some nice little melodic turns. But while his debut album sounded wonderfully effortless, this one feels effortful in the worst possible way.

is at times a desperate album, frantic to show off the limits of emotional and musical turbulence it's capable of reaching, and so the remaining glimmers of restrained cool lingering from Lewis's dominant influences are further diminished.

Unfortunately, 
‚Äô thematic depth hasn‚Äôt quite caught up to the rest of his ambition. It‚Äôs not a fatal flaw, but it does make for a record that‚Äôs not quite as transcendent as it was built up to be.

Bad timing for his fifth solo album, 
, a funky, country-laced experiment that‚Äôs not nearly as bad as its already damned reputation suggests. Though the lyrics might be.

With his fifth studio album, Timberlake isn‚Äôt re-inventing the wheel, but he solidly continues to experiment with R&B, funk, pop and soul, with Americana creating an interesting layer. 
 does make certain that Timberlake will never stop challenging himself to enter into new territory.

Add this to Taylor Swift‚Äôs recent 
 as a surprisingly unhandsome contribution from a great pop star.

Previously Timberlake has confounded expectations, both in his solo work and even as far back as his boyband days as resident heartthrob in NSYNC. But 
 is stuck in the past; guilty of basically being a JT nostalgia-fest, a compilation of familiar and safe tracks that encompass all the stuff that the boys think you like Justin Timberlake doing.

It‚Äôs remarkable how few ideas are contained within this hour-plus Blue Ridge Mountains mood board of an album. 
 is a misstep large enough to merit relitigating Justin Timberlake‚Äôs status as a pop superstar.

His latest album, portrayed dramatically as a grand return ‚Äì as well as some ambiguous, imagined ‚Äúreturn to his roots‚Äù (sigh) ‚Äì 
, could more accurately be titled 'What Happened?: The Album'.
is not merely his worst but quite possibly the worst statement by a major pop star this decade.

Tory Lanez manages to inject 
 with a few quality tracks, but overall it misses the mark on classic appeal.

These dudes are sure channeling some mythical backwoods vibe and really should have ended up in the conversation with Fleet Foxes, Grizzly Bear, MMJ and the rest.
Not quite sure why they flew so far beneath the radar.
Amazing how a group of guys from Oklahoma can make a perfect album for being deep in the woods.

Really unique instrumentation that makes a one-of-a-kind aesthetic. Nothing sounds quite like this album. Not a bad song on it, and nothing I've heard before. The soundtrack of Cormac McCarthy's Blood Meridian.

title: Music Inspired by Illumination & Dr. Seuss‚Äô The Grinch

reviews.content: Who thought Tyler, The Creator, the troll who rapped about eating dead bodies would be perfect to make a christmas inspired censored soundtrack for The Grinch Movie?

title: Heard It In A Past Life

reviews.content: Maggie Rogers is a pure pop star and a deserving one, at that. She‚Äôs self-assured in a way other radio stars aren‚Äôt, never afraid to fold in her folk background and do whatever she wants. And you just can‚Äôt help but root for her.
These are warm, well crafted pop tunes that I don‚Äôt doubt we‚Äôll be hearing in heavy rotation on Ken Bruce‚Äôs show as Record Of The Week between Popmaster rounds.

The effortless feel of Rogers‚Äô debut no doubt comes from the way it follows modern pop guidelines, but it also stems from Rogers‚Äô own innate talent, one you hope she decides to start taking chances with in the future.

While often precious, it‚Äôs never bad or incompetent, but there‚Äôs a frustrating sense of bets being hedged, particularly once the more ambitious production gives way to mildly anguished stadium boom towards the end.

Unfortunately, what made Rogers stand out ‚Äì a warmly idiosyncratic voice and a strong grasp of melody made less conventional with looping samples and unexpected beats ‚Äì is still best showcased by her 2017 EP, 
.
The perfect backdrop to the time I spent in forever21
a beautiful pop album that has some cool moments like Overnight or Give A little and it may not be a pop changer but it's extremely enjoyable
finds Khruangbin coming into their own, thanks to the band‚Äôs lyrical development and the honing of their fusion of intercontinental influences.
Musically, Khruangbin maintain their unwavering ability to weave a tapestry of diverse styles and sounds into their musical output.

Khruangbin have always made music that rewards close listening. With the vocal hooks and dancing boots of 
, they‚Äôre making it easier than ever for us to love them.
literally expands Khruangbin‚Äôs vocabulary, while the group‚Äôs eclectic whirl continues to soar through a soulful stratosphere. First class, all the way.
Even for an instrumental album, the sheer inoffensiveness of the music leaves you feeling adrift.
On their third album, the dubby band‚Äôs feel for a groove remains intact, but they often render vibrant sounds from all over the world as impeccably stylish mood music.
Mordechai is the embodiment of chill. The album is vibrant and stylish genre-bending music. The music of Khruangbin isn't particularly deep, but it's good and that's all that matters.
There's nothing deep here, it's just perfect background music for anything.
funky

, this deep and danceable delight, ends with two searing six minute tracks: the razor-blade blues of the White Stripes-ish The Evil Has Landed, and a sunrise-of-the-ancients pop final√© called Villains Of Circumstance.

The band have retained their brusque character but it‚Äôs less ponderous than before, with several tracks taken at an unfeasibly rapid tempo; while Ronson has brought production clarity and a punchy funk sensibility that transforms QOTSA‚Äôs trademark robot-rock rhythms into something much more dynamic and danceable.

is by far their most danceable and commercial to date. However, stoner rock purists needn‚Äôt worry that Palm Desert‚Äôs finest have suddenly discovered a taste for tropical house. 
 still possesses plenty of the band‚Äôs trademark pulverizing guitar riffs and sludgy basslines.

‚ÄòVillains‚Äô is Queens Of The Stone Age at their darkly seductive best, from the garish cover art to its well-crafted production, this is an album that proves that there is still a place for rock music in the mainstream of 2017.

A much more cohesive album than 
, one that seems hell-bent on turning out an incendiary dance-rock record rather than constantly shifting stylistic shape in the way that last LP did.
With production flourishes from Mark Ronson, Josh Homme leads the band's most accessible album in decades. It‚Äôs equal parts disco inferno and devil-may-care experimentation.
The result is not ‚ÄúQOTSA go pop‚Äù, but Ronson‚Äôs fresh ears do bring out the playfulness in their mean and muscular, feline and sensual sound, adding an extra-rubbery bounce to their rhythms.
feels sophisticated yet elemental in its fine construction. It sounds like the work of a band who know themselves and trust their instincts.

An immaculately recorded album. So warm and lush. Love the production. I should love this album. Autumnal folk with a psych edge. But it just didn‚Äôt quite hit all the marks. There‚Äôs definitely some beautiful moments and a bit to come back to but it didn‚Äôt blow me away. I suppose that ok. This album is enough. Enough is ok these days.
A boring retread of the musical themes of Dancing in Your Head, but everything on Body Meta sounds more or less the same.
Makes me want to dress like a disco ball and grow whiskers. Shit is funky as a mf

Another solid release by one of the more overlooked Jazz artist with one of his more iconic works especially with the self-titled track or side A being absolutely mind melting complex and straight up manic inducing. Space is the Place is a beautifully blend of science fiction soundscape with avant-garde jazz.
Track Review
Space is The Place 9/10
Images 8/10
Discipline 33 7.5/10.
Sea Of Sound 7/10
Rocket Number Nine 8/10
Average: 7.9/10
finds the band louder, darker, and more unpredictable than they have sounded in awhile

I don't like the sound, but 
Respect for a cool and unique style and persistence
And it has fun lyrics and spoken word on the fifth track
delivers riveting drama in a rousing pop package
Rather than an album you could expect to be performed by a young, charismatic band on some beach in LA, you get an album much like any nice, tidy pop album you‚Äôll hear this year.
Here they‚Äôre going through the motions, missionary style, with mechanical jangly pop and the wince-inducing triteness of Cosentino‚Äôs lyrics.
is more polished than the debut, but its songs just aren't as catchy, and there aren't any new tricks being tested.
Despite being overly long and some fairly banal lyrical content, Kodak Black seems to have developed an ear for beats that complement his vocal range.
Lots of classic strut tracks on here. May be their best record to date

Though certainly a busy album on the whole, 
 finds the band pursuing their musical vision with all the fresh-faced enthusiasm that one would expect from them, and much more besides.

Psychedelic San Francisco guitars and harmonies, along with a collection of intricate tambourines, horns, and whiskey chatter all prove a sound far more complex than that of, say, the commercial freight folk train Mumford and Sons.
a modern house classic
indie folk album, many excellent songs, the female vocalist has a beautiful voice, excellent debut album
His voice is something of an acquired taste but, this minor caveat aside, ‚ÄòThe Year Of Hibernation‚Äô is a genuinely unique debut.
To launch it to greatness, this album needs details, images, even more defined musical parts that make this specific anxiety something we can all recognize.
Upon release, this was supposed to bring about nostalgia for childhood memories collecting dust in your mind. Looking back, it just gives me nostalgia for the 2011 indie scene.
hauntingly beautiful

Tara Jane O‚ÄôNeil‚Äôs self-titled album is a work of intimacy, fragility, subtlety and delicacy. There are no fireworks here, no grand arrangements, no heart-wrenching symphonies. Just beauty of toned-down folk music. Guitar, wonderful melodies, late-night tunes, and her voice. It‚Äôs a straightforward piece of ethereal charm. Very personal, very fragile, tender and stirring.
Listen to: Blow, Laugh, Cali, Great
The proof is in a finished product where nothing feels out of place or approached half-heartedly. It‚Äôs as perfect a pop album as you‚Äôre going to get this year. Savor every last bit of it.
This album might not do anything particularly revolutionary, but as an example of affable, nuanced power-pop, it is hard to beat.
The album is full of catchy guitar rock anthems that recall their '90s alt-rock heyday but also showcases some of the maturity and experience they've gotten since then.

The highs aren't quite as high as they might have been ten years ago, but Nada Surf are dependable purveyors of indie rock, and on 
, they are as solid as ever.
is a beautiful combination of pop sensibility and daring exploration, the kind that may have been overlooked at the time, but now a decade on has proven itself timeless.

Such artistry could only be released by Grace Jones, and although there were more experiments than hits, she achieved the greatest success in her career. This project may have instilled in many people a love for the more ambitious side of music, as in the case of " The Crossing - Ohh The Action" in the style of Hiroshi Yoshimura's ambient works
The second case is the momentum of the production and the sound, which hardly any musician had at that time.

A Sun Ra classic, doesn't disappoint. It's a great listen, and one of Sun Ra's most funky works. 
By the early 70s, Sun Ra's pallet of sound and afro-futuristic ideas have been fully realized and make a long string of very solid and iconic albums, this one included. 
Favourite: Celestial Road, I'll Wait for You
Least favourite: Say

Liked the perfect lengths of the tracks, lush instrumentation throughout and although there are some moments where I just zone out on this listen I think it‚Äôs pretty damn good overall.
Each one of them is sturdy, fusing and switching between smart pop and R&B constructions as Cara sings about growing up and falling in love.
Here is one of my favorite songs of this year. The rest is pretty good. Not exactly groundbreaking but promising.

Most of the EP consisted of songs about teenage angst and love, but Here is a resounding masterpiece, a retro lounge song that defies the ‚Äúlife of the party‚Äù lifestyle.

Patrick stump really collects his amazing vocals from fall out boy and puts a really unique spin on them best tracks are run dry, spotlights and greed. also living for how amazing Patrick looked in the era of this album but I won't let personal bias get in the way
Frontman Patrick Stump takes his portion of Fall Out Boy‚Äôs catchy quirk and personality, tosses it in a synthesizer stew, and locks it in a watertight electro pop/rnb container.
For the most part this is pretty enjoyable, upbeat stuff, albeit with pretty inconsequential content. There are some missteps though, with some House influenced beats, and a very dubious ballad.

While undoubtedly a bit too long, 
 reaffirms Craig David‚Äôs standing as a fine and flexible pop songwriter with all sorts of hooks up his sleeve. He is a more versatile singer these days, able to home in on an urban style, but moulding himself into different shapes, sizes and speeds. We should value him more than we do.

Following My Intuition, Craig David's first album of original material in nearly a decade, returned the singer to the top of the U.K. pop chart for the first time since his 2000 debut. David was shrewd to quickly capitalize on the commercial resurgence with 
, a set that is less scattered stylistically -- dominated by tropical house and trap stylings -- yet less consistent quality-wise.
Far too long + far too bland + Bastille = an absolute dud of a pop record

HOOOOOOOLY SHIIIIIIIIIIIIIT THIS SLAPPED!!!
‚ÄúOne-Room Survival‚Äù is a collection of pure j-pop BANGERS! This whole album was able to captivate me throughout its entire runtime, with some really simple yet GROOOOVY production ideas that just sound so good! Once this album locks you into its sound, it really holds you tight and does not let go. It‚Äôs such an immensely fun j-pop record, def something to check out if ur into this kinda stuff!
Best Tracks: all
Worst Track: none
The best thing here are the jazzy parts cause they elevate the tracks so damn much, the rest is a little underwhelming compared to the rest of their discography but it's still nice nonetheless
such a nice chill album. appreciate the jazzy parts, really help boost the vibes. other than that, good indie pop
I liked the jazzy instrumentation on this but everything else was a little under done in my eyes. Still have yet to come close to their debut so far in my trip.
Solid production and engaging vocal performances with sounds/lyrics you'll catch on a million other classic releases. I Desire and My Mic Sounds Nice are especially good.
delightful little album, every track makes me feel cute and happy
is a bold and distinctive artistic statement, but the excessive 21-song tracklist is overwhelming.

Much of 
 contains the gleefully slapdash spirit that characterized the preceding EPs and commercial mixtapes, but there are -- for better and worse -- signs that the rapper might evade binary characterization as a delightful reveler or one-dimensional prankster.
A horrifically awful and suffocatingly empty piece of pop trash.

Clocking in at 82 minutes and 7 seconds, 
 is certainly ambitious, but it by no means emulates the classic double LPs of yesteryear, try as it might.

oh my god the first half was just so catchy , just like cute cinema it has such a sugary boppy sound you get hooked on. 
 favorites: cosmic cooking, Ice Cream, weekend in my ROOM, RGB
mehs: swing 54321, end of summer, idol fancy

While 
 isn‚Äôt the defibrillator that Eminem needed to revive his dominance, the album has enough highlights to maintain decent replay value and enough lyrical miracles to keep mindful rap from totally flat lining. His pen game hasn't lost even half of a step, and he still possesses the neurotic edge that's always made him such a driving force in hip-hop.

In some ways, 
 almost feels like 
 2.0. While not focused entirely on sobriety, 
 is equally emotional and reflective, with touches of darkness stemming from Em‚Äôs continued feelings of guilt and self-recrimination.
This is Dawn in full-on mystic mode, as these four new songs offer variations on a fairly precise idea of ethereal electronic pop.
Most of this album is frequently brilliant, just as catchy as Love King or Love vs. Money, while revealing a much more personal side of Nash‚Äôs considerable songwriting talents

His witty lyrics and gruffly gratifying beats on 
 draw listeners into the borough‚Äôs lifestyle with poetic efficiency.

Took like 15 listens to fully digest over the course of 5 years, not including stray tracks here and there. Every beat is top tier, every flow is untouchable, every hook lands, every bar is well crafted and thought out. It‚Äôs sorta just the perfect rap album. Like staring at a diamond.

title: The Ballad of Hamantha / Today Today / Al Dente

reviews.content:
The Ballad of Hamamtha - complete classic, great story and phenomenal instrumentation
Today Today - a real grower, listen to it enough and you‚Äôre singing it forever
Al Dente - just slightly too strange for me

An equilibrated, concept album, entitled by Claude Lalanne's sculpture of the same name, which tells the story of Marilou, a love story with a tragic end, narrated by Serge Gainsbourg in his own, unique way.

a LOT of this album gets lost if you don't know what he's saying, since it's a conceptual spoken word album. there's way less poppy songs like there was on melody nelson to keep you distracted that you don't really know what he's saying, but that album at least had translations of its songs online. still, he managed to captivate me once again. I just wish I knew what the hell is being said.
, Cindy Lee‚Äôs fifth and undoubtedly best album to date, is the culmination of this project, a haunting and surreal exploration of gender dysphoria and expression set to spectral pop textures.
On their fourth solo release in three years, the former Women member strikes a provocative balance of ‚Äô60s pop bliss and horror-show unease.

they really did that... they made the thing haunted. 
listening to cindy lee is absolutely mesmerizing in the amount of sheer agony. they are rushing through a universe full of pain and suffering
Give Me a Moment is a great little ep by Dean Blunt that showcases great production, hypnotic vocals, and just short songs from Dean Blunt. I want more tracks too.
The groove is unstoppable in this, some of the best prog pop from the 70s right here!

'Il nostro caro angelo' continues the development of 'libero' with the instrumental passages often revealing themselves as the most interesting element of Battisti's songs. 
The album really does feel like the bridge between his early work and 'Anima latina' though even then it hardly hints at just how experimental and expansive that next effort would end up.
There's no need to use any kind of camouflage because his annoyingly ready-made, pop outfit is completely obvious, no matter which side you look at it.
is, in the most rewarding and challenging ways, an impactful journey. Through dedicated sonic craft and vocal tenderness, Luke Temple has delivered an album that is both intimate and wild.

title: The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway

reviews.content: There's a great album in here somewhere. But the concept/lyrics are total bullshit and someone simply just needed to tell Peter Gabriel no on this one in nearly every respect. Phil Collins really was the saving grace of this album though, and some of my personal favorite Genesis cuts as well as prog cuts show up on this album. Just a bit bloated, a bit pretentious, really disorganized, and ambitious to a fault.

Where Floyd's two most recognizable albums made their mark with operatic aggression and fear, 
 deals in dirt-under-the-fingernails reality, the common smallness that simultaneously binds and repels us all.

Most of the LP is typical vibraphone jazz padding, but the title track is one of my absolute favourite third stream numbers amidst all the loftiness. It runs the gamut from engrossing emotion to dainty fun as though it were a jazzy Mozart, with even the quality to boot. Made my entire listen very rewarding, to hear something so well-done in such a rare style.

Great Avant-Prog record with lots of personality and absolutely unique! It is surely more pop and less experimental than their previous records apart from the last song (it's absolutely creative and insane)
I liked the groovy and fusion of jazz and rock on most of the tracks on here, while some of the songs might be a bit less focused and interesting, in particular in the middle section

The effusive debut full-length album from Australia's Toni Watson (aka Tones and I), 2021's 
 finds her further expanding the uplifting electronic pop she first showcased on her 2019 EP 
.

This music is painfully hard to listen to. The beats are all very similar, and the only thing that makes it tolerable is Ken‚Äôs sense of humor. His voice and vocal production is vomit inducing. I found this so hard to complete a full listen to. I gave up rating songs at some point.

Dear god‚Ä¶ 
Rage music can be very mind numbing and bland but production and beats and make it better. This fails to do that, it is actually the most painful rage album to sit through. I don‚Äôt know if there is worse out there. The distortion and vocal effects sound incomplete and this was released on a major label. Absolute trash
1-/10

In my opinion, easily Portugal The Man‚Äôs worst project to date. Everything that was previously good about their music was turned to shit here. It‚Äôs incredibly dry and boring in the indie rock world. The songwriting hit a new low on here as well. The instrumental element of the project is probably the best part about it. Yes, there are in fact a very small amount of decent-good songs on here. It‚Äôs just really, really bad songwriting.

Rating: No Balls
PTM‚Äôs American Ghetto will leave a pit in your stomach. This album is compiled with a mess of bland indie and alternative rock. Everything fuses into a giant mush. PTM sounds more and more like they have no identity more than ever. Really nothing to talk about, since the record doesn‚Äôt seem to try to do anything remotely interesting.

Third time‚Äôs the charm for horrorcore rapper Hopsin, as the angry and often awful character balances his aggressive, violent vocal style with more pop and approachable music during the rewarding 
.

This album could be the first Hopsin album in a long line of really great Hopsin albums. Or it can be the last Hopsin album. Only he can decide. In either case, 
 will, at the very least, serve as a peek into the wildly entertaining thought process of one of hip-hop‚Äôs most misunderstood characters.

The political nails are hidden deeply enough in the candy that sometimes it's hard to tell whether the juxtaposition is truly bracingly subversive or oddly self-defeating. Depending on your mood or disposition, maybe it's neither, either or both. A musical Rorschach test if there ever was one.

This album made me nostalgic for a blissful death I never experienced. All Black Everything was cold tho, and I guess you can get worse hits then The Show Goes On... that's all I got on compliments, man, ignore this album like the plague. You can see 'featuring Skylar Grey' yourself, notice a red flag when you see it!

I am so glad albums like this just don't get made any more. Back in like 2017 I bemoaned the fall of this style of pop rap but I don't think we, collectively, could've taken another half decade of overproduced Pixie Stix music.

Lords Never Worry continues off that LiveLoveA$AP sound with even more trippy, spacey cloud rap production. This mixtape got lots of hate when it first dropped, although I think it aged pretty well. Most members here do their part really well. The aesthetic and overall sound of the album is really unique but also swaggy as hell. A few inconsistencies, but when this album reaches its highest peaks, it‚Äôs some of cloud rap's absolute best.

One of Rae Sremmurd‚Äôs greatest strengths has always been their ability to create incessantly catchy material and deliver it with a casual confidence that makes their meticulously crafted hits seem effortless. That gift is clearer than ever on 
.
A few alright songs, but overall this is the weakest project from the Duo. The magic is not as fresh as it used to be. Production absolutely carried. There are some horrible songs on here as well. Eh

i‚Äôm ngl.. swae lee ruined the shit out of this. his hooks sounds horrible, he sounds dead in his verses, and i swear swae lee always sounds weirdly mixed and drowned in reverb. slim jxmmi is the huge highlight here, even though he has some cringy bars and sounds pretty shit with auto tune. hearing them over a rage beat was pretty entertaining tho.

title: Quazarz: Born on a Gangster Star

reviews.content:
is a curious new entry for the group. It expands the space-age palate of 
, but slips in the unique tunefulness of 
. And yet it doesn‚Äôt quite sound like either, and ‚Äî maybe unsurprisingly, at this point ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt sound like any other record you‚Äôll hear this year.
No gimmicks, no shortcuts, just a profuse mass of rich, literate lyricism, propped up by an overflowing bounty of complex musical accompaniment.

For what could be a masturbatory exercise or a cheap way to create buzz for what is ultimately weird-ass inaccessible hip-hop, there‚Äôs very little filler to be found. These are sprawling works with clear focus.
Corny asf. Also catchy asf. This is the reason I was motivated to check out blaze in the first place (I somewhat regret that). But I like this for some reason.
This is versatile, dynamic party music, made by masters of their craft.
For all of that blissful restraint, there‚Äôs a softness that serves as both the album‚Äôs wider appeal and general undoing.
Very crazy album with an unique sound and ugly lyrics. JAW was on his peak on this record and Hollywood Hank also delivered on a good level.
‚Äògraves‚Äô may not be a huge musical departure, but it‚Äôs a sign Purity Ring still have ideas left in them yet.

Hot take but Tuck is one of the best clean vocalists in metalcore and is VERY underutilized in everything FFAK has done since this album. The album itself aside from the vocals is also very well done and definitely some of their best work.
Highlights: Selfish Eyes, Young and Undeserving, The Final Thoughts of a Dying Man
Low Points: Cleanse My Soul

really good vocals, clean and harsh. delightfully nasty chugs and breakdowns. this is some cream of the crop metalcore. 
favorite tracks: Slave To Nothing, Hooked, A Greater Sense of Self
least favorite track: i honestly couldn't tell you. probably cleanse my soul if i have to choose

The material here doesn't always pay off, though it does make for an intriguing mixture of post-metal textures with a metalcore backbone. One of the most mature releases for the band, featuring unconventional structures and extra clean production.
The timing to properly use complex rhythms and simple rhythms is outstandingly good.
As an EP for the band to dip their toes back into the creative process of being a band again, it‚Äôs a thrilling piece of work, a preface to their national run of live shows.
Nothing is really wrong with this album, but it seemed less unique then what I expect out of this band. I found myself wanting to put on their original album the entire time I listened to this album.

Eclectic, but not without a clear display of musical talent. 
Notable Songs: "Automatic"; "Floating World"

On its skin, 
 is dense, and hot, and lovely. It contains more musical ideas in one place than anything Speedy Ortiz has done before. Guitar nerds will have fun. Poetry nerds, too.

With the cracks and crevices smoothed over by populist sheen, there's little here that plays to the rapper's exceptional talent. 
 places a three-dimensional artist in a two-dimensional box.

This third album, following last year‚Äôs astounding 
, acts as a heartfelt tribute to his hometown‚Äôs creative milieu, disillusionment in the face of excessive gentrification, and has the San Francisco native ruminating on his boundless capacity for intimate and intellectual stimulation.
is focused and melodic, sounding like a greatest-hits collection as song after song digs deep below the surface of heartache to uncover yet another painful memory or feeling.
it's pop punk but i like the melodies in this one, good if you don't pay too much attention to it

Add these gentle stylistic deviations to the less studied sound, the snappier songs, and the overall boost in energy and 
 ends up a clear improvement over the band's debut.
the virgin goat sample at the end of fine time vs the chad frog croaks in the middle of the perfect kiss

An electrifying, near flawless 30 minutes of thrash. Bonus points for starting with a bang, and ending with an absolute masterpiece. It makes it so much easier to want to return to. The pacing is genius.

Reign in blood is a great record I've listened to it all the way through multiple times but I have to be in the mood to listen to it cause it does a get a bit repetitive sometimes when you've heard the same oddly similar solo played almost every song I know they are different but after a while it all blends together some stand out tracks are angel of death and raining blood obviously this is a must listen to if you claim to be a metal fan

title: The Besnard Lakes are the Roaring Night

reviews.content:
More muscular, less ethereal than 2007's 
, it is no less exciting.

...
 is by no means a perfect record, and there are minor flaws to stand alongside the frequent moments of brilliance, but what cannot be questioned is how skilled they are at shaping layers of sound to form an enveloping whole, with each overlapping texture or shifting tempo plunging the listener further and further into the darkness.

The songs on 
 are typically catchy and help the vicious sentiments sink into your skin, but the most remarkable thing about the album is the sound -- Costello and the Attractions never rocked this hard, or this vengefully, ever again.
continues the theme of themeless epic suites with twisted stoner-prog anthems that rock as hard as the early days, but also hyperextended themselves in unexpected ways.
An innocent introduction of a young lady who's been trying to find her soul.

They didn‚Äôt call him the King of Blues for nothing.
There are many jams on this project. Nonetheless, I would‚Äôve appreciated it further if B.B. had abandoned the generic blues formula and incorporated more piano and symphonic sequences as he did on 'You‚Äôre Still My Woman'.

He's one of the gods of blues, B.B. King is deserving of that name. This record is full of soulful blues guitar licks, passionate croons and one of the genre's most immortal songs: The Thrill is Gone.

This is one of my favorite live blues albums I have heard so far. I will expand the review later.
Now is time to expand. The blues is an interesting genre. It is really easy for people, especially younger people like me, to write off the genre a little bit because many of the songs use similar standard progressions and themes but when you learn more about it and are going through something rough, it clicks. And this album is a strong performance from one of blues greatest legends in his prime.

BB King truly is a master at his craft. I tend to prefer The Blues on acoustic guitar but theres just something about this whole performance that really scratches an itch. Worry, Worry is such a legendary cut as well. While there are some songs here that I don‚Äôt care for I still love BB to death.
Super talented by most of his songs kinda sound the same. Classic album tho. Fav songs are promised land and you never can tell

Unlike 
, in which the repertoire selected by producer Marshall Chess was mostly unsuited, and the musical settings provided by Phil Upchurch, Pete Cosey et al. were too loud and too frenetic for Muddy's style of singing, 
 simply let him be Muddy Waters.

Such a super cool easy breezy bluesy record. So chilled out and effortless, could listen to this on repeat.
Essential Track - Call the Doctor

title: Big Bill Broonzy Sings Folk Songs

reviews.content: The recording quality being this crisp for something from 1962 is INSANE. The playing here is tip-top, not to mention BBB‚Äôs vocals suiting the acoustic playing perfectly. Cozy little cover album

The term I use to categorise this is 'Jools Holland-core'.
That faintly jazzy n' blues'y big vocal soul stuff with prominent piano - I mean it just ain't me. 
This is about as good as this sort of stuff gets but it's still a mild irritant.

title: Greatest of the Delta Blues Singers

reviews.content: Beautiful. Soft, cozy guitar playing, and an almost grandfatherly vocal presence come together to make probably my favorite delta blues album that I've heard so far.

title: I Got Dem Ol' Kozmic Blues Again Mama!

reviews.content: Sorry but none of Janis's solo shit comes close to Cheap Thrills by Big Brother and the Holding Company

She can do no wrong, can she?
The ol' kozmic blues Janis Joplin sings in her first solo album isn't as aggresively impactful as the blues rock she sang as a member of "Big Brother & The Holding Company" but it does feel more personal and, I would dare to say, even more consistently great.

Great delta blues album. I love how worn his voice sounds behind these very passionate performances. His guitar playing is very intriguing and I like the use of the slide a ton. Overall, it was a delta blues album I enjoyed quite a bit.

A classic record within the Delta Blues era, and I love how much wear is on Son House's voice on this album it really fits within the more spiritual and raw performance on the record and pulls everything together and was a huge influence for the Blues movement.

Tharpe was a remarkable artist, gifted as both a guitarist and a vocalist, who performed impressive songs with unique style. 
 marks a particular moment for her, but one that reveals that expanse of genius ‚Äì and entertainment ‚Äì she could provide.

One of the most important pieces of music for anyone even remotely interested in the history of rock and roll. I am not a religious person but when experiencing this album I feel a primal divine energy bursting from the record. I find this album to be quite underrated in the grand scheme of things. Sister Tharpe's energetic guitar playing captures this raw rock and roll energy that was way ahead of its time and her voice has a power to it that is indescribable through words alone.

Just not a pleasant listen. The vocal melodies rarely match the speed and frantic nature of the banjo, and many times the melody is just out of time, but not in a way that feels purposeful, more like he's trying to catch up with his own instrumental. And the lyrics just... look, I get it was the 50s but they just don't feel... right.

title: For the Sake of the Song

reviews.content: i've now discovered that talking blues is a whole ass genre lol

One of the first albums that leaves the electric guitar the center stage. However this feels more like a demonstration of that particular instrument than fully fleshed out songs. Little jazzy jamsessions over exotic beats create a chill album that, im afraid, most of the time just does not sound very interesting to me. At least it does not overstay its welcome.

Even though the title track is a career highlight this album sort of feels like a regression from Long Live Love, don't get me wrong, it's a good record however there are some duds in the middle while almost all of the tracks on her last album are great. One thing I love about this record though is how effortless it sounds.

Com esse √°lbum Olivia Newton-John mostrou uma vertente country mais pr√≥xima do pop e conseguiu dar uma verdadeira aula de interpreta√ß√£o vocal.

Oliva Newton-John, the woman that you were... Still heartbroken that we lost such a talent. To the most cynics, 'Have You Never Been Mellow' is just a collection of pleasing but standard country pop romantic tunes. However, her prowess elevates these songs to so much more and bridges a true connection to the heart of the listener who's paying attention.

Very 70's sounding soul-gospel influenced by not only Jesus, but may soul, pop and soft rock groups as well. Though very derivative of late-era Motown's song stylings, the vocals and instrumentation sound organic enough, & with that iconic 70's sounding mixing you'll find on the pop-soft-rock hits of the decade. A great crossover gospel sounding album for any 70's soul collector's collection.
Key Tracks: you Can Depend On Me, Take Me Back, Oh Saviour

Barbra's best album up to this point, the song selections are fantastic and some of them are her best songs. The production is current but compliments her voice extremely well. Her voice is at its peak here and the album is short but very sweet. The title track is an absolute career highlight and one of her best vocal moments.
Highlights: The Way We Were, All In Love Is Fair and What Are You Doing for the Rest of Your Life?.

is a terrific 13-track collection of the synth pop band's greatest hits, featuring all of the group's necessary singles.

Even if it duplicates two songs from the singer's debut, 
 is absolutely essential for Battisti fans -- and a milestone of Italian popular music -- as virtually every single track has achieved seminal classic status.

'Emozioni' is a bit less pop compared to the debut and instead ups the folk and rock influences in places. 
The strings are dominant and help make the title track a standout in particular.

One of the best albums of her career, it has a very serene and calming feel to it yet it never gets boring. Some of the songs on this record are the best of her career, they show how amazing her voice is. It's such a consistent body of work and really just a great listen. This album has an almost hypnotic sound to it, it really draws you in.
